div.ab:
GRete thankes lawde and honour / ought to be gy-
uen vnto the clerkes / poetes / and historiographs
that haue wreton many noble bokes of wysedom
of the lyues / passiōms / and myracles of holy sayntes
of hystoryes / of noble and famous Actes / and
faittes / And of the cronycles sith the begynnyng
of the creacion of the world / vnto thys present tyme / by whyche
we ben dayly enformed / and haue knowleche of many thynges /
of whom we shold not haue knowen / yf they had not left to vs
theyr monumentis wreton / Emong whom and inespecial to fore
alle other we ought to gyue a synguler laude vnto that noble ⁊
grete philosopher Gefferey chaucer the whiche for his ornate wry-
tyng in our tongue maye wel haue the name of a laureate poe-
te / For to fore that he by hys labour enbelysshyd / ornated / and
made faire our englisshe / in thys Royame was had rude speche ⁊
incongrue / as yet it appiereth by olde bookes / whyche at thys day
ought not to haue place ne be compred emōmg ne to hys beaute-
uous volumes / and aournate writynges / of whom he made ma-
ny bokes and treatyces of many a noble historye as wel in me-
tre as in ryme and prose / and them so craftyly made / that he cōm-
prehended hys maters in short / quyck and hye sentences / es-
chewyng prolyxyte / castyng away the chaf of superfluyte / and
shewyng the pyked grayn of sentence / vtteryd by crafty and su-
gred eloquence / of whom emong all other of hys bokes / I pur-
pose temprynte by the grace of god the book of the tales of caun
tyrburye / in whiche I fynde many a noble hystorye / of euery asta
te and degre / fyrst rehercyng the condictiōms / and tharraye of eche
of them as properly as possyble is to be sayd / And after theyr
tales whyche ben of noblesse / wysedom / gentylesse / Myrthe / and
also of veray holynesse and vertue / wherin he fynysshyth thys
sayd booke / whyche book I haue dylygently ouersen and duly
examyned to thende that it be made acordyng vnto his owen ma
kyng / for I fynde many of the sayd bookes / whyche wry -
ters haue abrydgyd it and many thynges left out / And in
some place haue sette certayn versys / that he neuer made ne sette
in hys booke / of whyche bookes so incorrecte was one brought to
me vj yere passyd / whyche I supposed had ben veray true ⁊ cor-
recte / And accordyng to the same I dyde do enprynte a certayn
a ij
Prohemye
nombre of them / whyche anon were sold to many and dyuerse
gentyl men / of whome one gentylman cam to me / and said that
this book was not accordyng in many places vnto the book that
Gefferey chaucer had made / To whom I answerd that I had ma-
de it accordyng to my copye / and by me was nothyng added ne
mynusshyd / Thenne he sayd he knewe a book whyche hys fader
had and moche louyd / that was very trewe / and accordyng vn-
to hys owen first book by hym made / and sayd more yf I wold
enprynte it agayn he wold gete me the same book for a copye /
how be it he wyst wel / that hys fader wold not gladly departe
fro it / To whom I said / in caas that he coude gete me suche a book
trewe and correcte / yet I wold ones endeuoyre me to enprynte it
agayn / for to saysfye thauctour / where as to fore by ygnouraūnce
I erryd in hurtyng and dyffamyng his book in dyuerce places
in settyng in some thynges that he neuer sayd ne made / and le -
utyng out many thynges that he made whyche ben requysite to be
sette in it / And thys we fyll at accord / And he ful gentylly
gate of hys fader the said book / and delyuerd it to me / by whiche
I haue corrected my book / as here after alle alonge by thayde of
almyghty god shal folowe / whom I humbly beseche to gyue me
grace and ayde to achyeue / and accomplysshe / to hys lawde ho -
nour and glorye / and that alle ye that shal in thys book rede or
heere / wyll of your charyte emong your dedes of mercy / remem-
bre the sowle of the sayd Gefferey chaucer first auctour / and ma
ker of thys book / And also that alle we that shal see and rede
therin / may so take and vnderstōmde the good and vertuous ta-
les / that it may so prouffyte / vnto the helthe of our sowles / that
after thys short and transitorye lyf we may come to euerlastyng
lyf in heuen / Amen
By Wylliam Caxton

div.l: WHan that Apryll wyth hys shouris sote
The droughte of marche hath percyd the rote
And bathyd euery veyne in suche lycour
Of whyche vertue engendryd is the flour
Whanne Zepherus eke wyth hys sote breth
Enspyrid hath in euery holte and heth
The tendyr croppis / and the yong sonne
Hath in the ram half hys cours y ronne
And smale foulies make melodye
That slepyn al nyght wyth opyn eye
So prykyth hem nature in her corages
Than longyn folk to gon on pylgremages
And palmers to seche straunge strondis
To serue halowys couthe in sondry londis
And specyally fro euery shyris ende
Of engelond to Cauntirbury thy wende
The holy blysful martir for to seke
That them hath holpyn when they were seke
BYfyl in that seson on a day
In Suthwerk atte tabard as I lay
Redy to wenden on my pylgremage
To Cauntirbury wyth deuout corage
That nyght was come in to that hostelrye
Wel nyne and twenty in a companye
Of sondry folk by auenture y falle
In feleshyp and pylgrymys were they alle
That toward Cauntirbury wolden ryde
The chambrys and the stablys were wyde
And wel were we esid atte beste
And shortly whan the sonne was at reste
So had I spokyn wyth hem euerychon
That I was of her feleshyp anon
And made forward erly for to ryse
To take our wey there as I you deuyse
But natheles whyles I haue tyme and space
Or that I ferthyr in thys tale pace
Me thynketh it accordaunt to reson
To telle you al the condicion
Of eche of hem so as it semed me
And whyche they were and of what degre
And in what aray eke they weren ynne
And at a knyght thenne I wyl begynne
A Knyght ther was a worthy man
That fro the tyme that he first began
To ryden out / he loued chyualrye
Trouthe ⁊ honour fredom and curtesye
Ful worthy he was in hys lordis werre
And therto hadde he ryden noman ferre
And as wel in crystendom as in hethenesse
And euer hadde honour for hys worthynesse
At alisaundre he was whan it was wonne
Ful ofte tyme he hadde the boord begonne
Abouen alle nacions in pruce
In lettowe hadde he reysed and in Ruse
No crysten man so often tymes as he
Ingarnade at the sege eke hadde he be
At Algezir / and ryden in Belmarye
At leyeys was he and eke at Satalye
Whan they were wonne and in the grete see
At many at nobyl arme hadde be he
At mortal batayllis had he be fyftene
And foughte for our feyth at Tramyssene
In listys thryes and ay sleyn hys foo
Thys ylke worthy knyght hadde be also
Som tyme wyth the lord of Palathye
Agayn another hethen man in Turkye
And euermore he hadde a souerayn prys
And though he was worthy he was wys
And of hys port as meke as a mayde
He neuer yet no vylaynye he sayde
In al hys lyf vnto no maner wyght
He was a very gentyl parfyght knyght
Forto telle you of hys aray
Hys hors were good but he was not gay
Of fustian he wered a gyppion
Al be smered wyth hys habergeon
For he was late come fro hys vyage
And sente for to do hys pylgremage
WYth hym ther was hys sone a yong squyer
A louer and a lusty bacheler
Wyth lockys crulle as they were leyd in presse
Of twenty yer of age he was I gesse
Of hys stature he was of euene lengthe
And wonderly delyuer and of greet strengthe
And he had be som tyme in chyuauchye
In Flaundryz In Artoyse and in Pycardye
And born hym wel as of a lytyl space
In hope to stonden in hys ladyes grace
Enbrowded was he as it were a mede
Al ful of fresshe flourys whyte and rede
Syngynge he was or floytynge al the day
He was as fresshe as is the moneth of may
Short was hys gowne wyth sleuys longe ⁊ wyde
Wel couthe he sitte on hors ⁊ therto fayr ryde
He couthe songys make and wel endyte
Iouste and daunce portraye and eke wryte
So hote he loued that by nyghter tale
He slepte nomore than a nyghtyngale
Curteys he was lowly and seruysabyl
He carf beforn hys fader at the tabyl
A Yeman hadde he and seruauntis nomo
At that tyme for he lyst to ryde so
And he was clad in cote ⁊ hood of grene
A sheef of pecok arowes bryght and shene
Vnder hys belt he bare ful thryftyly
Wel coude he dresse hys takyl yomanly
Hys arowys drouped not wyth fetherys lowe
And in hys hond he baar a myghty bowe
A not hed he had wth a broun vysage
Of wodemannes craft coude he al the vsage
Vp on hys arme he bare a gay bracer
And by hys syde a swerd and a bokeler
And on that other syde a gay daggare
Harneysed wel and sharpe as poynt of spere
A Cristofir on hys brest of siluer shene
An horn he baar the bawdryk was of grene
A forster was he sothly as I gesse
THer was also a nonne a pryoresse
That of hyr smylynge was sympyl ⁊ koy
Here grettest oth was be saynt loy
And she was clepyd dame Eglentyn
Ful wel she songe the seruyse dyuyne
Entoyued in hyr voys ful semely
And frensh she spak ful fetously
Aftir the scole of stratforde at the bowe
For frensh of paris was to hyr vnknowe
At mete wel taught was she wyth al
She lete no morsel fro hyr lyppys fal
Ne wette hyre fyngres in hyr sauce depe
Wel coude she cary a morsel of mete
That no drope fyl vpon hyr brest
In curtesye was set ful mykyl hyr lest
Her ouerlyppe wyped she so clene
That in her cup ther was no ferthyng sene
Of grece / whan she hadde dronke her draugh
Ful semely after hyr mete she raught
And sekerly she was of grete dysport
Of plesaunce and amyable of port
And peyned her to countrefete chyere
Of courte and to be stately of manere
And to be holde dygne of reuerence
But for to speke of hyr conscience
She was so charytable and so pyetous
She wold wepe yf that she sawe a mous
Kawght in trappe yf it were deed or bledde
Of smale houndys hadde she that she fedde
Wyth rost flessh or mylke or wastel bred
But sore wepte she yf ony of them were ded
Or yf men smoot hem wyth yerd smert
And al was conscience and tendyr hert
Ful semely hyr wympyl pynched was
Her nose tretise here eyen grey as glas
Her mouth smal and therto softe and reed
But sykyrly she had a fayr forheed
It was almost a span brode I trowe
For hardly she was not vnder growe
Ful fetyce was her cloke as I was waar
Of smal coral aboute her harm she baar
A peyre of bedis / gauded al wyth grene
And there on heng a broche ful shene
On whyche first was wryte a crouned A
And aftyr that Amor vincit omnia
Another Nonne wyth her hath she
That was her chapelayn and prestis thre
A Monk ther was fayr for the maystrye
An out ryder that loued wel venorye
A manly man to be an abbote able
Ful many a deynte hors hadde he in stable
And when he rood men myghte hys brydyl here
Gyngelynge and whystelynge in the wynd clere
And eke as lowde as doth the chapel belle
There as thys lord was keper of the celle
The rewle of saynt Maure and of saynt Benet
Be cause he held it somwhat old and streyt
Thys ylke monke lete olde thynges pace
And held after the newe world the space
He yaf not of the text a pulled henne
That seyth that hunters be not holy men
Ne that a monk whenne he is rechelees
Is lyk to a fishe when it is waterlees
Thys is to saye a monke out of a cloystre
But that texte helde he not worth an oystre
And I say that hys opynyon was good
What shold he studye and make hym wood
Vpon a book alwey in cloystir to powre
Or swynke wyth hys hondis and laboure
As Austyn byddeth how shold the world be serued
Let Austyn haue hys swynk to hym reserued
Therfore he was a prycasour a ryght
Grehoundis he had as swyft as foul in flyght
Of prykynge and of huntynge for the hare
Was al hys luste for no coste wolde he spare
I sawe hys sleuys purfyled at the hond
Wyth grice and that the fynest of a lond
And to fastyn hys hood vnder the chynne
He hadde of gold wrought a curyous pynne
A loue knot in the gretter ende ther was
Hys heed was balled whyche shoon as glas
And eke hys face as he had ben anoynte
He was a lord fatte and in good poynt
Hys eyen steep and rollynge in hys heed
That stemyd as a furneys of a leed
Hys bootis sowpyl hys hors in grete astate
Now certenly he was a fayr prelate
He was not pale as a fourpyned ghoost
A fat swan loued he best of ony roost
Hys palfrey was as broun as a bery
A Frere ther was awanton and a mery
A lymytour and a ful solemne man
In alle the ordrys four is non that can
So moche of daliaunce and fair langage
He hadde made ful many a fair mariage
Of yong wymmen at hys owen cost
Vntil hys ordre he was a nobil post
Ful welbeloued and ful famylier was he
Wyth frankeleyns ouer al in hys contre
And eke wyth worthy yemen of the toun
For he had power of confession
As sayd hym self more than a curat
And of hys ordre he was licenciat
Ful swetly herd he confession
And plesaunt was hys absolucion
And an esy man to gyue penaunce
There he wyste to haue good pitaunce
For vnto a poure ordre forto gyue
Is signe that a man is wel I shryue
For yf he yaf / he durste make a vaunt
He wyst that a man was repentaunt
Many a man so hard is of herte
He may not wepe thought he sore smerte
Therfore in stede of wepynge and prayers
Men moste yeue siluer to the poure freris
Hys tipet was I farsed ful of knyuys
And wyth pynnys to gyue fayre wyuys
And certayn he hadde a mery note
Meryly coude he synge and pleye at the rote
Of yeddyngis he baar utterly the prys
Hys necke was whyt as the flour delys
Therto stronge he was as a champioun
And knewe the tauernys wel in euery toun
And euery osteler and tapstere
Better than a lazer or a beggestere
Forto vnto suche a worthy man as he
Accordyth not as by hys faculte
To haue of suche sike lazers acqueyntaunce
It is not honest it may not auaunce
Forto dele wyth suche poraylle
But wyth riche and sellers of vytaylle
And ouer al there as richesse shold aryse
Curteys he was and lowly of seruyse
Ther was no man nowhere so vertuous
He was the beste beggere in hys hous
And yaf a certayn ferme for the graunt
Noon of hys brethern cam in hys haunt
For though a wydowe had not a shoo
So plesaunt was hys in principio
Yet wold he haue a ferthyng or he went
Hys purchace was bettir than hys rent
And barke he couthe as it were a whelpe
In louedayes there coude he mykyl helpe
For there he nas lyke a cloysterer
Wyth a threedbare cope as a poure frere
But he was lyke a mayster or a pope
Of dubbyl worstede was hys semy cope
That round was as a belle out of presse
Somwhat he lispyd for hys wantownesse
To make hys englysshe swete vpon hys tonge
And in hys harpyng whan he hadde I sunge
Hys eyen twynklyd in hys hed a ryght
As doon the sterris in the frosty nyght
Thys worthy frere was callyd hubberd
A Marchaunt ther was wyth a forkyd berd
In motley on hygh on hys hors he sat
Vp on his hed a flaundres beuer hat
Hys bootis claspyd feyr and fetously
Hys resons he spack ful solempnely
Shewynge alway the encresse of hys wynnynge
He wolde the see were kept for ony thynge
Betwyx Myddelburgh and orewelle
Welle coude he in hys eschaunges selle
Thys worthy man hys wytte ful wel besette
Ther wyst no wyght that he was in dette
So estatly he was of gouernaunce
Wyth hys bargayns and wyth gys cheuesaunce
Forsothe he was a worthy man wyth alle
But soth to say I not how men hym calle
A Clerk ther was of Oxenford also
That vnto logik hadde longe I go
As lene was hys hors as a rake
And he was not ryght fat I vndertake
But lokyd holow and therto sobyrly
Ful threedbare was hys ouerest courtby
For he hadde gote hym yet no benefyce
Ne was not worldly to haue an offyce
For hym was leuyr to haue at hys beddys heed
Twenty bokys I clad in whyt and reed
Of Aristotle and of hys phylosophye
Than Robys riche or fydyl or sawtrye
But al be that he was a phylosophre
Yet hadde he but lytyl gold in cofre
But al that he myghte of hys frendys hent
On bokys and on lernynge he it spent
And besely gan for the soulis praye
Of hem that yaf hym wherwyth to scolaye
Of study took he most cure and hede
Not a worde spak he more than nede
And that was sayd in fourme and reuerence
Short and quyk and ful of hygh sentence
Sownyng moral vertu was hys speche
And gladly wold he lerne and gladly teche
A Sergeante of lawe waar and wyse
Was there that ofte hadde be at the peruyse
Tat was also ful riche of excellence
Discrete he was and of grete reuerence
He semyd suche hys wordys were so wyse
Iustyce he was ful ofte in assyse
By patent and be playn commyssion
For hys science and hys hygh renoun
Of fees and Robys hadde he many on
So gret a purchasour was there nowher non
Al was fee symple to hym in effecte
Hys purchace myghte not be to hym suspecte
Nowhere so besy aman as he ther nas
And yet he semyd besyer than he was
In teermes hadde he caas and domes alle
That fro the tyme of kyng wylliam were falle
Therto he coude endyte and make a thyng
Ther coude no wyght pynche at hys wrytyng
And euery statute coude he pleyn by rote
He rood but homely in a medle cote
A gyrt wyth a seynt of silk wyth barris smale
Of hys aray telle I no lenger tale
A Frankeleyn was in hys companye
Whyte was hys berd as is the deysie
And of hys complexion was sanguyn
Wel loued he by the morow a cup wyn
To lyue in delyte was euer hys wone
For he was epycuryes owen sone
That held opynyon that pleyn delyte
Was verray felicyte parfyte
An housholder and that a grete was he
Saynt Iulian he was in hys contre
Hys brede hys ale was allewey aftyr one
A bettyr vyned man was nowher none
Wythoute bake mete was he neuer in his hous
Hys fissh hys flessh and that so plentuous
It snewed in hys hows of mete and drynke
Of alle deyntees that men couthe thynke
Aftyr the sondry seson of the yeer
So chaunged he hys mete and hys soper
Ful many a fat partrych hadde he in mewe
And many a breme and luce in stewe
Wo was hys cook but hys sawce were
Poynant and sharp and redy al hys gere
Hys tabyl dormaunt in hys halle alway
Was redy couered al the longe day
At sessions ther was he lord and sire
Ful ofte tyme he was knyght of the shyre
A anlace and a gypser al of silk
Hyng at hys gyrdyl as whyte as morow mylk
A shereue hadde he ben and a coronour
Was nowhere suche a worthy vauesour
AN habyrdassher ther was and a carpenter
A webbe a dyer and a tapyser
And they were clothed alle in o lyuere
Of a solempne and grete fraternyte
Ful fressh and newe her geer pyked was
Here knyuys chapyd were not wyth bras
But al wyth siluer wrought ful clene and wel
Here gyrdelis and hyr powchys euerydel
Wel semed eche of hem a fayr burgeys
To sitten in the yeld halle at the deys
Euerych for the wysdom that he can
Was happely forto be an aldyrman
For cateyll hadde they ynow and rent
And here wyuys wold it wel assent
And ellis certayn they were to blame
Hyt is ful fayr to be callyd madame
And go to the vygyllis al before
And haue a mantel rially I fore
A Cook they hadde wyth hem for the nonys
To boylle the chykens ⁊ the mary bonys
And powder marchaunt tart and galyngale
Wel knew he a draughte of london ale
He coude roste sethe broylle and frye
Make mortrewys and wel bake a pye
But grete harm was it as it thoughte me
For on hys shynne a mormal hod he
And blank manger made he wyth the best
A Sypman was there that woned fer be weste
For ought I wot he was of derthemouthe
He rood vp a rowncy as he couth
In a gowne foldynge to the kne
A daggar on a lace hangynge had he
Aboute hys necke vnder hys arm adoun
The hote somer hadde made hys hewe al broun
And certaynly he was a good felawe
Ful many a draughte wyn he hadde drawe
Fro burdeux ward whyle the chapman sleep
Of nyce conscyence toke he no keep
Yf that he faught and had the hygher hond
By water he sent hem hom to euery lond
But of hys craft to reken wel hys tydes
Hys stremys and hys daungers hym besides
Hys herberugh hys mone and hys lodemanage
Ther was none suche from hulle to Cartage
Hardy he was and waar to vndertake
Wyth many a tempest hys berd hath be shake
He knewe all the hauenes that there were
Fro gotelond in to the Capfenestre
And euery cryke in brytayne and in spayne
Hys barge was called the Maudeleyne
WYth vs ther was a doctour in physik
In the world was ther none hym lyk
To speke of physik and surgerye
For he was groundyd in Astronomye
He kepte hys paciente a greet deel
In houres by magyk natureel
Wel couthe he of fortune the assendent
Of hys ymages for hys pacient
He knewe the cause of euery maladye
Were it of cold hete moyst or drye
And were engendred of what humour
He was a very parfight practesour
The cause y know and of hys harm the rote
Anon he yaf to the sik man hys bote
For redy alway be hys apotecaryes
To sende hym drugges ⁊ hys lectewaryes
For eche of them made other for to wynne
Her frendshyp was not newe to begynne
Ful wel knewe he the olde Esculapius
And dyscorydes and eke Rusus
Olde ypocras / haly and Galiene
Serapion Rasis and eke Auicene
Auerroys damascene and constantyn
Bernard Gatisden and Gylbertyn
Of hys dyete mesurable was he
For it was of no superfluyte
But of grete nourisshynge and dygestyble
Hys stody was but lytyl on the byble
In sangweyn and in perce I clad wyth all
Lyned wyth taffata and wyth sandall
And lytyl he was of hys dyspence
He kepte that he whan in the pestelence
For gold in physik is a cordyal
Therfor he loued gold in especyal
A Good wyf ther was of beside bathe
And she was somdeel deef ⁊ that was scathe
Of cloth makynge had she suche an haunt
She passyd them of ypre and of gaunt
In al the parisshe wyf was ther non

And home wente euery man the right way
Ther was no more but farwel haue good day
OF this batayl I wyl nomore endyte
But speke of palamon and of arcyte
Swellyth the brest of arcyte and the sore
Encrecyth at hys hert ay more and more
The cloteryd blod for ony lechecraft
Coruptyth and in hys bowk is laft
That neyther veyne blood ne ventusynge
Ne drynke of herbis may be hys helpynge
The vertu expulsif or anymall
Fro that vertu y clepyd naturall
Ne may the venym voyde ne expelle
The pypis of hys longis gan to swelle
And euery lacert in hys brest a doun
Is shent wyth venyme and corrupcioun
Hym gayneth nothyng forto gete hys lyf
Vomyte vpward and dounward laxatyf
Al is to brosten thylke regyon
Nature hath in hym no domynacion
And certaynly there nature wol not wirche
Fare wel phesyk go bere the man to chyrche
Thys is al and som arcyte muste dye
For whyche he sendyth aftyr Emelye
And palamon that was hys cosyn dere
Than sayd he thus as ye shul aftyr here
Not may the woful spyrit in my hert
Declare a poynt of al my sorowys smert
To you my lady that I loue most
But be quethe the seruyse of my gost
To yow abouen euery creature
Sythnes that my lyf may no lenger dure
Alas the woo alas the payne strong
That I for you haue suffrid and so long
Alas the deth / Alas my Emelye
Allas the departyng of our companye
Alas my hertis quene / alas my wyf
My hertis lady ender of my lyf
What is this world what axith men to haue
Now wyth hys loue now cold in hys graue
Alone wythouten ony company
Fare wel my swete foo my Emely
And softe take me in your armes tweye
For the loue of god ⁊ herkenyth what I seye
I haue here wyth my cosyn palamon
Had stryf and rancour many aday agoon
For loue of you / and of my Ielowsye
And Iupyter so wysly my soule gye
To speken of a seruaunt properly
Wyth circumstaunces alle truly
That is to sayn trouth honour ⁊ knygthede
Wysdom humblesse estate and hye kynrede
Fredom and alle that longeth to that arte
So Iupyter haue of my sowle parte
As in thys world right now knowe I non
So worthy to be loued as palamon
That serueth you and wyl do al hys lyf
And yf that euer ye shul be a wyf
Foryetith not palamon the gentyl man
And wyth that word hys speche fayle gan
For fro hys feet vnto hys brest was come
The colde of deth that hath hym ouercome
And yet more ouer for in hys armes two
The vytal strengthe is lost and al ago
Only the intellectis withouten more
That dwellyth in hys herte syke and sore
Gan fayle whan the herte felyth deth
Dusshyd hys eyen to and fayleth hys breth
But on hys lady yet caste he hys eye
Hys laste word was mercy Emelye
Hys spirit chaungyd the hous and wente there
As I cam neuer I can not telle where
There y stynte I am not deuynyster
Of soulis fynde I not in thys regystre
Ne me lyst the opynyons to tell
Of thēm though þt they writen where they dwell
Arcyte is cold there mars hys soule guye
Now wyl I speke forth of Emelye
Shryhte Emelye and howleth palamon
And Theseus hys sustyr toke anon
Swownynge and bare hyr fro the cors away
What helpyth it to tary forth the day
To telle how she wepte bothe eue and morow
For in suche caas wommen haue suche sorow
Whan that her husbondis be fro hem ago
That for the more part they sorowen so
Or ellis falle in suche a maladye
That at the laste certaynly they dye
Infynyt ben the sorowys and the teris
Or olde folk and folk of tendre yeris
In al the toun for deth of thys theban
For hym ther wepyth bothe the chyld and man
So greet wepyng was ther non certayn
Whan Ector was brought al fresh I slayn
To troye allas the pyte that was there
Cratchynge of chekys rentynge eke of here
Why woldest thou be ded thys wymmen crye
And haddest gold ynough and Emelye
No man myght gladen theseus
Sauynge hys olde fader egeus
That knew thys worldis transmutacion
As he hadde seen it chaunge vp and doun
Ioye aftyr woo and woo aftyr gladnesse
And shewde hym ensaumple and liknesse
Ryght so ther deyde neuer man quod he
That he ne lyued in erthe in some degre
Ryght so ther lyued neuer man he seyde
In al this world that some tyme he ne deyde
Thys world is but a thorow fare ful of wo
And we be pylgryms passyng to and fro
Deth is an ende of euery worldis sore
And ouer al thys yet sayde he mykyl more
To this effect ful wysely to enhorte
The pepyl that they shold hem recomforte
Duke Theseus wyth al hys besy cure
Caste now where that the sepulture
Of good arcyte may best y makyd be
And eke most honourable in hys degre
And at the last he took conclusion
That there as fyrst arcyte and Palamon
Hadden for loue the bataylle hem between
That in that selue groue swete and green
There as he hadde hys amerous desirys
Hys complaynt and for loue hys hote firys
He wold make a fyre in whyche the office
Funeral he myght fully accomplyce
And comanded anon to hacke and to hewe
The okis olde and ley hem on a rewe
In culpyns wel arayd for to brenne
Hys offycers wyth swyft feet they renne
And ryden anon at hys comaundement
And aftyr thys theseus hath sent
Aftyr a bere and he it ouer sprad
Wyth clothys of gold the rychest that he had
And of the same sute he clothyd arcyte
Vp on hys hondys hys glouys whyte
And on hys hed a crowne of lawrer grene
And in hys hond a swerd ful bryght ⁊ kene
He layde hym bare the vysage on the bere
Ther wyth he wepte that pyte was to here
And for the pepyl shold se hym alle
Whan it was day / he brought hym in the halle
That roreth of the cryyng and the sown
Tho cam thys woful theban Palamoun
Wyth floterid berd / and ruggid asshy heris
In clothis blak dropped al wyth teris
And passyng other of wepyng Emelye
The rewfullest of alle the companye
And in as muche as the seruyse shuld be
The more nobyl and Ryche in hys degre
Duke Theseus leet thre stedis forth brynge
That trappyd were in steel al glyterynge
And couered wyth the armys of arcyte
And eke vp on the stedys grete and whyte
Ther satyn folk of whyche one bare hys sheld
Anothyr a spere vpon hys sholdres held
The thyrde bare wyth hym hys bowe turkeys
Of brend gold was the caas and the harneys
Aud ryden forth a paas wyth sorouful chere
Toward the groue as ye shul aftyr here
The noblest of the grekes that there were
Vpon theyr backes caryden the bere
Wyth slak paas and eyen rede and weet
Thorow out the cyte by the mayster strete
That spred was al wyth blak ⁊ wonder hye
Ryght of the same is the strete y wrye
Vp on the ryght hond wente old Egeus
And on that othyr syde duke Theseus
Wyth vessellis of gold in hyr hond ful fyne
And ful of hony mylk / blood and wyne
Eke Palamon wyth ful grete companye
And aftyr that cam woful Emelye
Wyth fyre in hond as was that tyme the gyse
To do the offyce of the funeral seruyse
Hygh labour and ful greet apparelynge
Was at the seruyse of that fyre makynge
That wyth his grene top the heuen raughte
And twēmty fadom of brede þe armys straughte
Thys is to saye the bowes were so brood
Of strawe fyrst was layd meny a lood
But how the fyre was made vp an heyghte
Ne eke the names how the trees hyghte
As ook firre / birche assh / alder holm popeler
Mapil thorn bech aspe box chesteyn lynd laurer
Wylow / elme / plane / hasil and whypultre
How they were fellyd shal not be told for me
Ne how the goddis rennyn vp and doun
Disheryted of their habytacioun
In whyche they woned in reste and pees
Nymphes faunes and a madrides
Ne how the bestis and the bryddes alle
Fledden for feer whan the wode gan falle
Ne how the ground agast was of the lyhgt
That was not wont to se the sonne bryght
Ne how the fyre was cowchyd first wyth stre
And than wyth drye stickys clouen on thre
And than wyth grene wode and spycery
And than with cloth of gold and with perry
And garlondis hangynge with many a flour
The myrre the encence wyth swete odour
Ne how arcyte lay among al thys
Ne what rychesse abowte hys body ther is
Ne how that Emelye as was the gyse
Put in the fyre of funeral seruyse
Ne how she swowned whan made was þe fyre
Ne what she spak ne what was her desyre
Ne what Iewellis men in to the fyre caste
Whan that the fyre was gret ⁊ brende faste
Ne how some caste her shelde ⁊ some her spere
And of her vestimentis whych that they were
And cuppis ful of mylk wyne and blood
In to the fyre that brent as it were wood
Ne how the grekys wyth an huge route
Thryes ryden al the fyre aboute
Vp on þe lyft hond wyth an hygh showtynge
And thryes wyth here speris claterynge
And thryes how the ladyes gan crye
Ne how that led was homward Emelye
Ne how arcyte is brent to asshen cold
Ne how the lych wakys were y hold
That ylke nyght ne how the grekys pleye
The wake pleyes ne kepe I not to seye
Which wrastelith best naked with oyl anoynt
Ne how that bare hym best at the poynt
I wyl not telle al how they goon
Home to Athenes when the pley is doon
But shorthly to the poynt than wol I wende
And make of my long tale an ende
BY proces ⁊ by lengthe of certeyn yeris
Al stynt is the mornyng ⁊ the cheris
Of grekys by one general assent
Than semyth me ther was a parlement
At athenes vpon a certeyn poynt and caas
And among the whiche poyntis spokyn was
To haue wyth certayn contrees alyaunce
And haue fully of thebans obeyssaunce
For whyche thys nobyl Theseus anon
Leet sende aftyr gentyl Palamon
Vnwyst of hym what was the cause and why
But in hys blake clothis sorowfully
He cam at hys comaundement an hye
Tho sent theseus for Emelye
Whan they were set ⁊ hust was al the place
And Theseus abyden hath a space
Or ony word cam from hys wyse brest
Hys eyen sette he there as hym lyst
And wyth a sad vysage he sighed stylle
And aftyr that ryght thus he said his wylle
The fyrst mouer of the cause aboue
Whan he fyrst made the fayre cheyne of loue
Greet was the effect ⁊ hygh was hys entent
Wel wyste he why ⁊ what ther of he ment
For wyth that fayr cheyne of loue he bond
The fyre the eyr the water and the lond
In certeyn bondis that may not fle
That same prynce and that mouer quod he
Hath stablisshed in this wretchid world adoun
Certayn dayes and duracioun
To all that is engendrid in thys place
Ouer the whyche day they mow not pace
Al mowe they yet tho dayes abrygge
Ther nedyth non auctoryte to legge
For it is proued by experience
But that me lyst to declare my sentence
Than may wel men by thys ordre dyscerne
That thylke mouer stabyl is and eterne
Wel may men knowe but it be a fool
That euery party is deryued fro hys hool
For nature hath not take hys begynnyng
Of one part or of a cantel of a thyng
But of a thyng that parfyght is and stable
Descendyng so tyl it be corumpabyl
And therfore for hys wyse purueaunce
He hath so wel be set hys ordenaunce
That speces of thyng and progressions
Sholden endure by successions
And nought etern wythoute ony lye
Thys mayst thou vnderstonde and se at eye
Lo the ook that hath so long a norysshynge
Fro the tyme that it first gynneth to sprynge
And hath so long lyf as ye may se
Yet at the laste wastid is the tre
Considereth eke how that the hard stoon
Vnder our feet / on which we trede and go on
Yet wastyth it as it lyeth by the wey
The brood ryuer somtyme wexyth drey
The grete townes se we wane and wende
Than ye se that al thyng hath an ende
Of man of womman se we wel also
That nedis in one of thyse termys two
Thys is to saye in yongthe or ellis in age
He moot be ded the kyng as shal a page
Some in hys bed some in the depe see
Some in the large feld as men may se
Ther helpyth nought / alle gon that ilke weye
Than may I say al thyng mot nedes deye
What makyth thys but Iupiter the kyng
That is prynce and cause of al thyng
Conuertynge alle vnto hys propre wyl
For whyche it is deryued soth to tel
And here agayns no creature alyue
Of no degre auayleth forto stryue
Than is it wysedom as thynketh me
To make vertu of necessyte
And take it wel that we may not eschewe
And namely that to vs alle is due
And who so grutchyth ought he doth folye
And rebel is to hym that al may gye
And certeynly a man hath most honour
To dyen in his most excellent flour
Whan he is sykir of his good name
Than hath he do hys frend ne hym no shame
And gladder ought his frend be of hys deth
Whan wyth honour so vp yolden is hys breth
Than whan hys name appallid is for age
For alle foryeten is than hys vasselage
Than is hyt best as for a worthy fame
To dyen whan a man is best of name
The contrary of al thys is wylfulnesse
Why grutche we why haue we heuynesse
That good arcite of cheualrye the flour
Departid is wyth duete and honour
Out of the fowle pryson of thys lyf
Why grutchyd hys cosyn and hys wyf
Of hys welfare that loueth hym so weel
Can he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
That bothe hys soule and eke hem offende
And yet they mowe her lustys not amende
What may I conclude of thys long sery
But aftyr wo I rede vs to be mery
And thonke Iupyter of al hys grace
And er we departen from thys place
I rede that we make of sorowys two
O parfyt Ioye lastyng euer mo
And loketh now where most sorow is ynne
There wyl I fyrst amende and begynne
Sustyr quod he thys is my ful assent
Wyth al the auyse of my parlement
That gentyl palamon your owen knyght
That serueth you wyth hert and myght
And euer hath do syn ye fyrst hym knew
That ye shul of your grace on hym rew
And take hym for husbond and for lord
Lene me your hond for thys is our accord
Let see now of your wommanly pyte
He is a kyngis brother sone parde
And though he were a poure bacheler
Syn he hath serued you so meny a yeer
And hadde for you so gret aduersyte
It mot be consydered leuyth me
For gentyl mercy ought to passe ryght
Than sayd he thus to palamon the knyght
I trow ther nedyth lytyl sermonynge
To make you assent to thys thynge
Cometh ner ⁊ takyth your lady by the honde
And thus of hem bothe was made the bonde
That hyght matrymony or maryage
By al the counseyl of the baronage
And thus wyth al blis and melodye
Hath Palamon wedded Emelye
And god that al thys world hath wrought
Sente hym hys loue that he dere had bought
For now is palamon in alle wele
Lyuyng in blis in Ryches and in hele
And Emely hym loueth so tenderly
And he here seruyth agayn so gentylly
That ther was no word hem betwene
Of Ielousye or of ony othyr tene
Thus endyth Palamon and Emelye
And god saue alle thys companye
Here endyth the knyghtys tale :
Here endyth the knyghtys tale : And here begynneth the Myllers prolog
Whan þt the knyght had thus his tale told
In al the cōmpanye nas ther yong ne old
That he ne sayd it was a nobyl story
And worthy to be drawe in memory
And namely the gentylis euerichon
Our hoost lowgh and swoor so mot I goon
Thys goth aright vnbokelid is the male
Let se now who shal telle another tale
For treuly the game is wel begonne
Now telle ye syr monk yf that ye konne
Som what to quyte the knyght hys tale
The Mylward that fordronkyn was al pale
To that vnnethys vp on hys hors he sat
He nolde auale nother hood ne hat
Ne abyde noman for hys curtesye
But in pylatis voys he gan crye
And swoor by armys blood and bonys
I can a nobyl tale for the nonys
With whiche I wol now quyte þe knyghts tale
Our hoost saw that he was dronke of ale
And sayd abyde Robyn leue brothyr
Sum bettyr man shal telle fyrst anothyr
Abyde and let vs werke thryftely
Be cokkis soule quod he that nyl not I
For I wyl speke or ellis go my wey
Our hoost answerd tel on a deuyl wey
Thou art a fool thy wytte is ouercome
Now herkeneth quod the myllere alle ⁊ some
But fyrst I make a protestacioun
That I am dronke I knowe by my soun
And therfore yf I aught mys speke or say
Wyte it the ale of suthwerk I you pray
For I wol telle a legende and a lyf
Bothe of a carpenter and of hys wyf
How that a clerk hath set the wryghtis cappe
The reue answerd and sayd stynt thy clappe
Let be thy lewd dronkyn harlottrye
Hyt is a synne and eke greet folye
To appeyre ony man or hym defame
And eke brynge wyuys in suche a name
Thou mayst Inowgh of othyr thyngis sayn
This dronkyn mylward spak ful sone agayn
And sayd O leue brothyr Oswold
Who hath no wyf he is no cokeold
But I say not therfor that thou art one
Ther ben gode wyuys many on
Why art thou angry wyth my tale now
I haue a wyf parde as wel as thow
Yet nolde I not for the oxen in my plow
Take vp on me more than ynow
As deme of my self that I were one
I wol beleue wel that I am none
An husbond shold not be inquysytyf
Of goddis pryuyte ne of hys wyf
So he may fynde goddys fuson there
Of the remenaunt nedyth not to enquere
What shold I more say but thys Mllere
He nolde hys word for noman forbere
But told hys chorlis tale in hys manere
Me at thynketh that I shal reherce it here
And therfore euery gentyl wyght I pray
Demeth not for goddis loue that I say
Of euyl entent but that I most reherce
Here talis al be they better or werce
Or ellis falsen some of my matere
And therfore who so lystyth not to here
Turne ouer the leef and chees another tale
For he shal fynde ynowe bothe grete and smale
Of hystoryal thyng that towchyth gentylnesse
And eke moralyte and holynesse
Blameth not me yf that ye chese amys
The Myllere is a chorle ye know wel thys
So is the reue and eke other mo
And harlottrye they tolde bothe two
Auysyth you and put me out of blame
And eke men shul not make ernest of game
¶ Here begynneth the mylleres tale
WHylom ther was dwellyng in Oxenforde
A ryche gnof that gestis hadde to borde
And of hys craft was he a carpenter
With hym ther was dwelling a pour scoler
Hadde lernyd art but al hys fantesye
Was turnyd to lerne astrologye
And coude a certayn of conclusions
To demyn by interrogacions
If that men axed hym certayn houres
Whether they shold haue drought or shoures
Or yf that men axed hym what shold befalle
Of euery thyng I may no rekene alle
Thys clerk was clepyd hende Nycholas
Of dern loue he couthe and of solas
And therto he was sly and ful pryue
And lyk a mayden meke for to se
A chambyr hadde he in that hostelrye
Alone wythout ony companye
Ful fetously y dight wyth herbys sote
And he hym self was swete as is the rote
Of lycoryce or of ony Cetewale
Hys almegeste hys bokys grete and smale
Hys astrologye / longynge for hys art
Hys awgrym stones lay feyre a part
On sheluys cowchyd at hys beddis hed
Hys presse ycouered wyth a foldyng reed
And al aboue ther lay a gay sawtrye
On whyche he made a nyghtis melodye
So swetely that al the chambyr rong
And angelus ad virginem he song
And aftyr that he song the kyngis note
Ful often blyssyd was hys mery throte
And thys swete clerk hys tyme spent
Aftyr hys frendes fyndyng ⁊ hys rent
Thys carpenter hadde weddyd newe a wyf
Whyche that he louyd more than hys lyf
Of xvin yeer she was of age
Ielous he was ⁊ held her narow in cage
For she was wyld and yong ⁊ he was olde
And demed hym self lyk to be a cokewolde
He knew not Caton for hys wyt was rude
That badde a mān shold wedde hys symylytude
Men shold wedde aftyr hyr astate
For yongthe and old ben often at debate
But sythen he was fallen in the snare
He muste endure as othyr folk hys care
Fayr was this yong wyf and there wyth all
As ony wesyl hyr body gent and small
A seynt she weryd barryd alle of sylk
A barmecloth as whyte as morow mylk
Vp on hyr lendys wyth ful meny agore
Whyte was her smok and broyden al before
And eke behynde on hyr coler aboute
Of coleblak sylk wythynne ⁊ eke wythoute
The tapettis of her whyte voluper
Were of the same sute of the coler
Her filet brood of silk and set ful hye
And sikyrly she hadde a lykerous eye
Ful smale y pullyd were here browis two
And they were bente and blak as ony slo
She was moche more blysful on to see
Than is the newe pere genet tree
And softer than is the wulle of a weder
And by hyr gyrdyl hangyth a purs of leder
Tarselyd wyth sylk and perlyd wyth laton
In al thys world to seke vp and doun
Ther is noman so wyse that coude thenche
So gay a pupelot or so praty a wenche
Ful bryghter was she shynynge of her hue
Than in the tour the nobyl forgyd newe
But of her song it was as lowde ⁊ yern
As ony swalow sittynge on the bern
Therto she coude skyppe and make game
As ony kyd or calf folowyng hys dame
Her mouth was swete as braket or methe
Or hord of appelis leyd on hey or heth
Wynsynge she was as is a Ioly colt
Long as a mast and vpryght as a bolt
A broche she baar vp on hyr low coler
As brood as is the boos of a bokeler
Here shoon were laced on hyr leggis hye
She was a prymerolle a pyggis nye
For ony lord to liggen in hys bed
Or yet for ony good yeman to wed
Now syre and eft syre so befyl the caas
That on a day thys hend Nycholas
Fyl wyth thys yong wyf to rage ⁊ to pleye
Whylys that her husbond was at Oseneye
As clerkys be ful subtyl and ful queynt
And pryuely he caughte hyr the by queynt
And sayd ywys but yf I haue my wylle
For dern loue of the lemman I spylle
And held here hard by the shank bones
And sayd lemman loue me all at onys
Or I wold dye al so god me saue
And she sprong as a colt doth in the traue
And wyth her heed she wryeth faste away
She sayd I wol not kysse the by my fay
Why let be quod she let be Nycholas
Or I wyl crye out harow and allas
Do wey your hondis for your curtesye
Thys Nycholas gan mercy for to crye
And spak so fayre ⁊ profered her so faste
That she her loue graunted hym at the last
And swere her oth by saynt Thomas of kent
That she wold be at hys comaundement
Whan that she may her leyser wel espye
Myn husbond is so ful of Ielousye
That but ye wayte wel and be pryue
I wot ryght wel I nam but ded quod she
Ye must be ful dern as in thys caas
Nay therof care the not quod Nycholas
Lythyrly a clerk had beset hys whyle
But yf he coude a carpenter begyle
And thus they ben accorded and y sworn
To wayte a tyme as I haue told beforn
Whan Nycholas hadde do thus euerydeel
And thackyd her aboute the lendys wel
He kyste her swete and took hys sawtrye
And pleyde faste and made melodye
Than fyl it thus that to the parysh chyrche
Crystys owen werkis for to werche

Syngyth ful meryer than the Popyngeay
Yow loue I best and shal and othyr none
So longe aboute the aleyys is he goone
Tyl he was come ayens that ylk pery
Where as thys Damyan sittyth ful mery
And hygh among the fressh leuys grene
Thys fressh may that is so bryght and shene
Gan forto sighe and sayd allas my syde
Now syre quod she for aught that may betyde
I muste haue of the peris that I se
Or I must dye so sore longyth me
To ete of the smale peris grene
Help for hyr loue that is of heuen quene
I telle you wel a womman in my plyt
May haue in fruyt so gret an appetyt
That she may dyen but she of it haue
Allas quod he that I ne hadde here a knaue
That coude clymbe allas allas quod he
That I am blynd ye sire no force quod she
But wold ye vouchesauf for goddis sake
The pery wyth ynne your armys forto take
For wel I woot that ye mystruste me
Than sholde I clymbe wel ynough quod she
So I my feet myght sette vp on your bak
Certis quod he therof shal be no lak
Myghte I you helpyn wyth myn herte blood
He stoupyth adoun and on hys bak she stood
And caughte her by a twyste ⁊ vp she goth
Ladyes I pray you be not wroth
I can not glose I am a rude man
And sodenly anone thys Damyan
Gan pulle vp the smok ⁊ in he throng
And whan that Pluto saw that wrong
To Ianuary yaf ayeen hys sighte
And made hym se as wel as euyr he myghte
And whan þt he had caught hys sight agayn
Ne was there noman of thyng so fayn
But on hys wyf hys thought was euyr mo
Vp to the tre he cast hys eyen two
And saw how damyan hys wyf hath dressyd
In suche maner it may not be expressyd
But yf I wold speke vncurteysly
Out help allas harow he gan cry
O stronge lady hore what dost thou
And she answerd syre what eylith you
Haue pacience and reson in your mynde
I haue you holpyn on bothe your eyen blynde
Vp peril of my soule I shal not lyen
As me was taught to hele wyth your eyen
Was nothyng bet to make you to se
Than forto strogyl wyth a man in a tre
God woot I dede it in ful good entent
Strogyl quod he ye algate in it went
God you yeue bothe a shamys deth to dyen
He dyde the so I saw it wyth myn eyen
And ellis be I hangyd by the hals
Than is quod she my medycyne fals
For certeynly yf ye myght see
Ye wolde not sey thyse wordes to me
Ye haue some glymsynge and no parfit sight
I see quod he as wel as euer I myght
Thankid be god wyth bothe myn eyen two
And by my trowthe me thoughte he dyd so
Ye maas good sere quod she
Thys thank haue I for I made you se
Allas quod she that euyr I was so kynde
Now dame quod he lat al passe out of mynde
Come doun my leef and yf I haue myssayde
God help me so as I am euyl apayde
But by my fader soule I wente haue seyn
How that thys Damyan had by the leyn
And that thy smok he leyde vpon hys brest
Ye sire qod she ye may wene as ye lost
But sere quod she a mān þt wakith of his sleep
He may not so sodenly take keep
Vp on a thyng ne se it so parfitly
Tyl that he be wel adawed veryly
Ryght so a man that long blynde hath be
Ne may not sodenly so sone wel se
Fyrst when hys sight is newe comyn ageyn
As he that hath a day or tweyne y seyn
Tyl that your sighte y satelid be a whyle
Ther may ful many a sighte you begyle
Bewaar I pray you for by heuyn kyng
Ful meny a man wenyth to see a thyng
And yet it is al anothyr than it semyth
He that mysconceyueth ofte mys demyth
And wyth that word she lepte fro the tre
Thys Ianuary who is glad but he
He kysseth her and clyppyth hyr ful ofte
And on hyr wombe he strikyth her ful softe
And to hys Paleys hoom he hath her lad
Now good men I pray you be mery ⁊ glad
Thus endyth here my tale of Ianuary
God blisse vs alle and hys moder Mary
Here endeth the Marchauntes tale / And
foloweth the prologe of the squyers
OVr hoost in his stiroppis stondith anon
And said godemen herkeneth euerichon
This was a sharp tale for the nonys
Syre parissh preest quod he for goddis bonys
Tel vs a tale as was thy forward yore
I se wel that laboured men in lore
Knowe moche thyng by goddis dygnyte
The person hym answerd benedycite
What eylyth the man so synfully to swere
Oure hoost answerd o Iankyn be ye there
I smelle a lollere in the wynde quod he
Now good men quod our hoost herkneth me
Abydyth for goddys dygne passioun
For we shul haue now a predicaoun
Thys lollare wol preche vs here sumwhat
Nay by my fader soule that shal he not
Sayde the Squyer he shal not here preche
He shal no gospel glose here ne teche
We leue alle in the grete god quod he
He wolde sowe some difficulte
Or spryngen cokyl in our clene corn
And therfore hoost I warne the beforn
My Ioly body shal a tale telle
And I shal clynke yow so mery a belle
That it shal wakyn al thys company
But it shal not be of phylosophy
Ne of physlias ne termes queynte of lawe
There is but lytyl latyn in my mawe
Here begynneth the squyers tale
AAt surrey in the lond of Tartarye
There dwellyd a kyng that warryd russy
Thorow whyche there dyde many a doughty man
Thys nobyl kyng was clepyd Cambuscan
Whyche in hys tyme was of so greet renoun
That ther was nowhere in no regioun
So excellent a lord in alle thyng
He lackid nought that longed to a kyng
As of the secte of whyche he was born
He kepte hys lay to whyche he was sworn
And therto he was hardy wyse and ryche
Pytous Iuste and alwey y lyche
Soth of hys word benygne and honourable
Of hys corage as ony center stabyl
Yong fressh strong in armys desirous
As ony bacheler dwellyng in hys hous
A fayr persone he was and fortunate
And kepte alway so wel Ryal astate
That there was nowhere suche a man
Thys nobyl kyng thys tartyr Cambuscan
He hadde two sones on alphete hys wyf
Of whyche the eldest hyghte Algarsif
That othyr sone was clepyd Camballo
A doughter hadde thys worthy kyng also
That yongest was and hyghte Canace
But forto telle you of hyr beaute
It lyth not in my tunge nyn my connyng
I dar not take on me so hygh a thyng
And also myn englyssh eke is insuffycient
It muste be a clerk and rethour excellent
That knewe the colours longyng to that art
If he sholde dyscrye her in euery part
I am no suche I must speke as I can
And so befyl thys Cambuscan
Hath twenty wynter bore hys dyademe
As he wente fro yeer to yeer y deme
He leet the feste of hys natyuyte
Done crye thorow out saray the cyte
The laste Idus of marche aftyr the yeer
Phebus the sonne ful Ioly was and cleer
For he was nyghe hys exaltacion
In martis face and in hys mansion
In aries the hote colerik signe
Ful lusty was the wethyr and benygne
For whyche the foulis ayens the sonne shene
What for the seson and the yong grene
Full loude songen here affections
Hem semyd to getyn them protections
Agayn the swerd of wynter kene and cold
Thys Cambuscan of whyche I you told
In ryal vestymentis sat on hys deys
Wyth dyademe ful hygh in hys paleys
And holte hys feste so solempne and ryche
That in thys world was there none it lyche
Of whyche yf I shold telle al the ray
Than wold it occupye a someris day
And eke it nedyth not to deuyse
At euery cours the ordre of her seruyse
I wol not telle of her strange sewys
Ne of her swannys ne of her heronsewis
Eke in that lond as tellen knyghtis olde
Is some mete that is ful deynte holde
That in thys lond men recke of it but smal
There is noman that may reporten alle
I wol not tarye you for it is pryme
And for it is no fruyt but los of tyme
Vnto my first tale I wol haue my recours
And so befylle that aftyr the thrydde cours
Whyle thys kyng sat thus in hys nobleye
Herkenyng his mynstrallis here thynges pleye
Beforn hym at hys bord delyciously
In at the halle dore all sodeynly
There came a knyght vpon a stede of bras
And in hys hond a brood myrrour of glas
Vpon hys thombe he had of gold a ryng
And by hys syde a nakyd swerd hangyng
And vp he rydyth to the hygh borde
In al the halle ne was there spoke a word
For meruayll of thys knyght hym to beholde
And bysely they wayten yong and olde
The straunge knyght that cam so sodenly
Al armed saue hys hed ful Rychely
Saluyth kynge quene and lordis alle
By ordre as they sitten in the halle
Wyth so hygh reuerence and obeysaunce
As wel in speche as in contenaunce
That Gawen wyth hys olde curtesye
Though he were come ageyn out of feirye
Ne coude hym amende wyth a word
And aftyr thys before the hygh bord
He wyth manly voys sayd hys message
Aftyr the fourme vsed in hys langage
Wythoute vyce of sillabyl or lettyr
And for hys tale shold seme the bettyr
Accordant to hys wordys was hys chere
As techyth art of speche hem that it lere
Al be it that I can not sowne hys style
Ne I can not clymbe on so hygh an style
Than say I thus to the comyn entent
Thus muche amountyth al that he ment
If it so be that I haue it in mynde
He sayd the kyng of arabye and of ynde
My lyege lord on thys solempne day
Saleweth yow as he best can and may
And sendyth you honour at your feste
By me that am al redy at your heste
Thys stede of bras that esely and wel
Can in the space of a day naturel
Thys is to say in four ⁊ twenty houris
Where you lyste in droughte or in showris
Bere your body in to euery place
To whyche your herte wylneth forto pase
Wythoute wem of you thorough foul or fayr
Or yf you lyst to fle as hygh in the ayer
As doth an egyl whan hym lyst to sore
Thys same stede shal bere you euermore
Wythoute harm tyl ye be there ye lyst
Though that ye slepe on hys back or reste
And turne ageyn wyth wrythyng of a pyn
He that it wrought couthe many a gyn
He waytyd many a constellacion
Or he had wrought thys operacion
And knewe meny a seal and meny a bonde
Thys myrrour eke that I haue in myn hond
Hath suche a myght that men may in it se
When ther shal falle ony aduersite
Vnto your regne or vnto your self also
And openly who is your frend or foo
And ouer al thys yf ony lady bryght
Had set her herte on ony maner wyght
If he be fals she shal hys treson see
Hys newe loue and al hys subtylyte
So openly that ther shal no thyng hyde
Wherfore agayns thys lusty someris tyde
Thys myrrour and thys ryng as ye may se
He sente hath to my lady Canace
Your excellent doughter that is here
The vertu of thys ryng yf ye wol here
Is thys yf that her lyst it forto were
Vp on here thombe or in her purs it bere
There is no foul that fleeth vnder heuyn
That she ne shal vnderstonde hys steuyn
And knowe hys menyng openly and playn
And answere hym in hys langage agayn
And euery gras that growyth vpon the rote
She shal knowe and whom it wol do bote
Al be hys wounde neuer so deep or wyde
Thys nakyd swerd that hangyth by my syde
Suche vertu hath what man ye smyte
Thorow out hys armure it wol kerue ⁊ byte
Were it as thycke as a braunchyd ook
And what man is wounded wyth the strook
He shal neuer be hool tyl ye lyst of grace
To stroke hym wyth the plat in the same place
There he is hurt that is as mykyl to sayn
Ye moot wyth the plat swerd agayn
Stroke hym in the wounde and it wol close
Thys is a verray soth wythouten glose
It fayleth not whylis it is in your holde
And when þe knyght hath thus hys tale tolde
He rood out of the halle ⁊ doun he lighte
Hys stede whiche þt shoon as the sonne bryght
Stont in the court stylle as ony stoon
Thys knyght in to the chambyr is led anon
And is vnarmed and to mete y sette
The presentis be ryght rychely fette
Thys is to say the swerd and the myrrour
Been born anone in to the hygh tour
Wyth certeyn offycers ordeyned therfore
And vnto Canace thys ryng is bore
Solempnly there she sat at the tabyl
But sikyrly wythouten ony fabyl
The hors of bras that may not be remeuyd
It stont as it were in the ground y cleuyd
They may hyt not out of the place dryue
For none engynys wyndas ne polyue
And cause why for they con not the craft
And therfore in the place they haue it laft
Tyl þt the knyght haue taught hem the manere
To voyden hym as ye shul aftyr here
Greet was the prees þt swermyd to and fro
To gawryn on the hors that stood so
For it so hygh was so brood ⁊ so long
So wel proporcioned to be strong
Ryght as it were a steed of lumbardye
Therwyth so horsly and so quyk at eye
As it a gentyl poleyn courser were
For certis from hys tayl vnto hys ere
Nature ne art coude hym not amende
In no degre as al the pepyl wende
But euermore her most wonder was
How that it coude go and was of bras
It was a feyre as al the pepyl semyd
Dyuerse folk dyuersly they demed
As meny hedes / as meny wyttis ther been
They mormedyn as doth a swarm of been
And maken skyllis aftyr her fantesye
Rehersynge of the old poetrye
And sayd it was lyke the pegase
The hors that had wyngis forto fle
Or ellis it was the grekis hors Synon
That brought troye vnto destruction
As men in thyse olde gestis rede
Myn hert quod one is euermore in drede
I trow some men of armys be therynne
That shape hem thys cyte forto wynne
It were right good þt al such thyng were knowe
Another rowned to hys felow lowe
And sayd he lyed for it was rathyr lyke
An apparence maad be some magyke
As Iogelours pleyn at the festis grete
Of sondry doubtes thus they iangyl and trete
As lewd pepyl demen alday comonly
Of thyngis that been maad more subtilly
Than they konne in her lewdnes comprehende
They demyn gladly to the badder ende
And some of theym wondryd on the myrour
That born was vp in to the maystyr tour
How men myghte in it suche thyngis se
An other answerd and sayde it may wel be
Naturelly made by composicions
Of Aungelis and of sly reflections
And sayd that in rome was suche one
They spak of alocen and of vytelone
And of arystotill that wrytyn in her lyuys
Of queynte myrours and of prospectatyuys
As knowe they that haue her bokis herd
And othyr folk haue wondryd on the swerd
That wol peryssh thorough euery thyng
And fyl in speche of thelephus the kyng
And of Achylles wyth hys queynte spere
For he coude wyth it bothe hele and dere
Right in suche wise as men may with þe swerd
Of whyche ryght now ye haue your self herd
They speken of sondry hardyng of metal
And speken of medycynes ther wyth al
And how and whan it shold hardyd be
Whyche vnknowe is algate to me
Tho speke they than of Canaces ryng
And sayd that all suche wonder thyng
Of craft of ryngis herde they neuer non
Saue that he moyses and kyng Salamon
Hadde a maner connynge of suche an art
Thus seyn the pepyl and drawen hem a part
But neuertheles some sayde that it was
Wonder to make of fern asshes glas
And yet is glas not lyk asshen of fern
But for they haue knowe it so fern
Therfore secith her iangelyng ⁊ her wonder
As sore wondre some on cause of the thundyr
On ebbe on flood on gossomer and on myste
And on al thyng tyl the cause is wyst
Thus Iangelyn they and demyn and deuyse
Tyl that the kyng gan from hys bord aryse
Phebus hath lost the angle merydyonal
And yet ascendyng was the best ryal
The gentyl lioun wyth hys aldryan
Whan that thys tartyr kyng Cambuscan
Roos from hys bord there he sat ful hye
Beforn hym goth the lowd mynstralcye
Tyl that he cam to hys chambyr of parementis
There as they sownyn dyuers instrumentis
That is lyk an heuen forto here
Now daunsen lusty venus chyldren dere
For in the fyssh her lady sat ful hye
And lokyth on hem wyth a frendly eye
Thys nobyl kyng is set vp on hys trone
Thys straunge knyght is fet to hym ful sone
And on the daunce he goth with Canace
Here is the reuel and the Iolyte
That is nat abyl a dul man to deuyse
He muste haue knowe loue and hys seruyse
And be a festliche man as fressh as may
That shul you deuysen suche aray
Hou coude you telle the fourme of daunses
So vncouthe and so fressh contenaunces
Suche subtyl lokyng and dyssymylyngis
For drede of Ielousye mennys perseyuyngis
No man but Launcelot and he is ded
Therfore I passe ouer of al thys lustyhed
I say nomore but in thys Iolynesse
I lete hem tyl men to sopper hem dresse
The styward byddeth spycis forto hye
And eke the wyne in alle thys melodye
The vsshers and the squyerye ben gon
The spicis and the wyne is comen anon
They ete ⁊ drynke ⁊ whan thys was at ende
Vnto the tempyl as reson was they wende
The seruyse don they soupen al by day
What nedyth me to reherce here aray
Eche man woot wel that a kyngis feste
Hath plente to the moste and to the leste
And deyntees moo than be in my knowyng
And aftyr soupper goth thys nobyl kyng
To see thys hors of bras wyth all the route
Of lordis and of ladyes hym aboute
Suche wōmdryng was ther of this hors of bras
That sethen the grete sege of troye was
There as men saw suche an hors also
Ne was there suche wondryng as was tho
But fynally the kyng asked the knyght
The vertu of thys courser and the myght
And prayde to telle hym his gouernaunce
The hors anone gan to tryppe and daunce
Whan þt this knyght leyde hond on hys reyne
And sayd syre ther is nomore to sayne
But whan you list to ryden ony where
Ye muste trylle a pyn that stont in hys ere
Whyche I shal you telle betwyx vs two
Ye moot nempne hym to what place also
Or to what contre that ye lyste to ryde
And whan ye come there as ye lyste abyde
Byd hym descende and trylle another pyn
For there ynne lith the effect of al the gyn
And he wold doun descende and do your wyl
And in that place he wolle abyde styl
Theygh al the world hath the contrary swore
He shal not thens be drawe ne bore
And or yf you lyst bydde hym thens goon
Trylle thys pynne ⁊ he wol vanysshe anon
Oute of the sight of euery maner wyght
And come ayen be it by day or nyght
Whan that you lyst clepyn hym ageyn
In suche a gyse as I shal to you seyn
Betwene me and you and that ryght sone
Ryde when you lyst there is nomore to done
Enfourmed whan the kyng was of þe knyght
And hath conceyued in hys wyt a ryght
The maner and the fourme of al thys thyng
Ful glad and blythe was thys nobyl kyng
Repeyryng vnto hys reuel as beforn
The brydyl is to the tour yborn
And kept among hys Iewels leef and dere
The hors vanysshed I not in what manere
Out of her sighte ye gete nomore of me
But thus I lete in luste and in Iolyte
Thys Cambuscan hys lordys festeyng
Tyl wel nygh the day began to sprynge
