THe noryce of dygestion the sleep
Gan on hēm wynke ⁊ bad hem take kepe
That muche mete ⁊ labour wol haue rest
And wyth a gapyng mouth he hem alle keste
And sayd it was tyme to lye a doun
For blood was in hys domynacion
Cherysshe blood natures frend quod he
They thankyn hym galpynge by two by thre
And euery wyght gan drawe hym to hys rest
As sleep hem bad and toke it for the best
Here dremys shal not be told for me
Ful were here heedes of fumosite
That causith dreme of whyche ther is no charge
They slepyn tyl it was pryme large
The moste part but yf it were Canace
She was ful mesurable as wommen be
For of her fader hath she take her leue
To go to reste sone aftyr it was eue
Her list not appalled forto be
Ne on the morow vnfestliche for to see
And slepte her fyrste sleep and awook
For suche a Ioye she in her myrrour took
Bothe of her ryng and of her myrrour
That twenty tyme she chaungyd colour
And in her sleep ryght for the impression
Of hyr myrrour she had a vision
Wherfore or the sonne gan vp glyde
She clepyd vp her maystresse here beside
And sayd that her luste forto aryse
Thyse olde wommen that ben gladly wyse
As her maystresse answerd here anon
And sayd Madame whethyr wol ye goon
Thus erly for folk been alle in reste
I wol quod she aryse for me leste
No lengyr sleep but walken aboute
Her maystresse clepyth wommen a greet route
And vp they rysen wel ten or twelue
Vp risith fressh Canace hyr selue
As rody and bryght as the yong sonne
That in the ram is four degrees y ronne
No hygher was he whan she redy was
And forth she walkyth esely a paas
Arayd aftyr the lusty seson sote
Lyghtly forto pley and walkyn on fote
Not but wyth fyue or syxe of her meyne
And in a trenche forth in the park goth she
The vapour whyche fro the erthe glode
Makyth the sonne to seme rody and brood
But neuerthelesse it was fayr of sighte
That it made all her hertis for to lighte
What for the seson and the mornynge
And for the fowlis that she herde synge
For ryght anone she wyste what they ment
Ryght by here song and knewe al here entent
The knotte why that euery tale is told
If it be taried tyl the lust be colde
Of hem that haue it harkened aftyr yore
The sauour passyth and euer lenger the more
For fulsomnes of hys prolixyte
And by the same reson thynkyth me
I sholde vnto the knotte condescende
And make of her walkyng sone an ende
A mydde a tresord reyde as whyte as chalk
As Canace was pleyynge in her walk
There sat a fawcon ouer her hed ful hye
That wyth a pytous voys so gan to crye
That al the wood resowned of her crye
And beten hadde here self so pytouslye
Wyth bothe her wyngis tyl the reed blood
Ran endlong the tre there as she stood
And euyr in one she cryde alwey and shryght
And wyth her bek her self to twyght
That ther nas tygre nor so cruel beste
That dwellyth other in wood or in forest
That nold haue wepte yf he wepe coude
For sorow of her shryche alwey so lowde
For ther was neuer yet man on lyue
Yf that he coude a faucon wel descryue
That herde of suche anothyr of feyrnes
As wel of plumage as of gentylnes
Of shap and alle that myghte rekened be
A fawcon peregryn than semed she
Of fremd lond ⁊ euermore as she stood
She swowned now ⁊ now for lak of blood
Tyl wel nygh is she fallen fro the tre
Thys fayr kyngis doughter Canace
That on her fynger baar the queynte ryng
Thorow which she vnderstood wel euery thyng
That ony foul may in hys leden seyn
And coude answere in hys leden agayn
Hath vnderstonde what thys faucon seyde
And wel nygh for the routhe almost she deyde
And to the tre she goth ful hastely
And on thys faucon lokyth ful pytously
And held her lappe a brood for wel she wyste
The faucon muste falle fro the twyste
Whan that it swowned next for lak of blood
A longe whyle to wayte there she stood
Tyl at the laste she spak in thys manere
Vnto the hawke as ye shul aftyr here
What is the cause yf it be forto telle
That ye be in thys furial peyne of helle
Quod Canace vnto thys hauke aboue
Is thys sorow of deth or losse of loue
For as I trow thyse been the causis two
That causen most a gentyl herte wo
Of other harm it reckyth not to speke
For ye your self vpon your self ye wreke
Whyche preuyth wel that othyr loue or drede
Mot be encheson of your cruel dede
Syn that I se none other wyght you chace
For loue of god so do your self grace
Or what may be your help for west ne eest
Saw I neuyr or now bryd nor beest
That ferde wyth hym self so pytously
Ye sle me wyth your sorow veryly
I haue of you so gret compassion
For goddis loue come fro the tre a doun
And as I am a kynges doughter trewe
If that I veryly the causis knewe
Of your dysese yf it lay in my myght
I wolde amende it or it were nyght
As wys help me grete god of kynde
And herbis shal I ryght ynow fynde
To hele wyth your hurtis hastely
Tho shryght thys faucon yet more pytously
Than euer she dyd ⁊ fyl to ground anon
And lith aswowne as ded as ony stoon
Tyl Canace hath in her lappe here take
Vnto tyme she gan oute of her swowne awake
And aftyr that she out of swoun gan brayde
Ryght in her hawkis leden thus she sayde
That pyte rennyth sone in gentyl herte
Felyng hys symylitude in peynes smerte
Is prouyd alday as men may se
As wel by werk as by auctoryte
For gentyl herte kydyth gentylnesse
I se wel that ye haue of my dystresse
Compassioun my fayre Canace
Of verry wommanly benygnyte
That nature in your prynciplis hath set
But for no hope forto fare the bet
But forto obeye to your herte fre
And forto make other be waar by me
As by the the whelp chastysed is the lyon
Ryght for that cause and that conclusion
Whyle that I haue leyser and spaas
Myn harm I wyl confesse er I paas
And euer whyle that one her sorow tolde
That othyr wepte as she to water wolde
Tyl that the faucon bad hyr be styl
And wyth a sygh thus she sayd her wylle
There I was bred allas that hard day
And fostrid in a roche of marbyl gray
So tenderly that nothyng aylid me
I ne wyste what was aduersite
Tyl I coude fle ful hye vnder the sky
Tho dwellyd a tarcelet me faste by
That semed wel of al gentylnes
Al were he ful of treson and falsnes
It was so wrappid vnder humble chere
And vnder hue of trouthe in suche manere
Vnder plesaunce and vnder besy peyne
That I ne coude haue wend he coude feyne
So depe in greyn he dyed hys colours
Ryght as a serpent hydyth hym vnder flouris
Tyl he may se hys tyme forto byte
Ryght so this god of loues Ipocryte
Doth so hys serymonyes ⁊ hys obeysauncis
And kepyth in semblaūnce al his obseruauncis
That sowneth vnto gentylnesse of loue
As in a tombe is al the feyr aboue
And vnder is the corps suche as ye woot
Suche was thys Ipocryte bothe cold ⁊ hoot
And in thys wyse he seruyd hys entent
That saue the fend none wyste what he ment
Tyl he so longe hadde wepte ⁊ compleyned
And meny a yeer his seruyse vnto me feyned
Tyl that my herte to pytous and to nyce
Al Innocent of hys crowned malice
For ferd of hys deth as thoughte me
Vp on hys othys and hys suerte
Graunted hym loue vp on thys condicion
That euermo myn honour and my renon
Were saued bothe pryue and apert
Thys is to seyn that aftyr hys desert
I gaf hym al my herte and al my thought
Good woot and he ⁊ other wyse nought
And toke hys herte in change of myn for ay
But soth is sayd goon seth is many a day
A trewe wyght and a theef thynke not one
And whan he saw the thyng so fer agone
That I had grauntyd hym my loue
In suche a gyse as I haue sayd aboue
And yeue hym my trewe herte as fre
As he swoor he yaf hys herte to me
Anone thys tygre ful of doubylnesse
Fyl on his knees wyth so gret humblenesse
Wyth hygh reuerence and as by hys chere
So lyk a gentyl louer of manere
So rauysshed as it semed for the Ioye
That neuer Troylus ne Paris of Troye
Iason certis ne none other man
Syn lameth was that alderfirst began
To louen two as wryten folk beforn
Ne neuer sith that first man was born
Ne couthe man by twenty thousand part
Counterfete the sophyms of hys art
Ne worthy to vnbokelen hys galoche
There doublenes or faynyng shold approche
Ne so couthe thonke a wyght as he dyd me
Hys maner was an heuen for to see
To ony womman were she neuer so wyse
So payntyd he hys chere at poynt deuyce
As wel hys wordis as hys contenaunce
And so I loued hym for hys obeysaunce
And for the trowthe y demed in hys hert
That yf so were that ony thyng hym smert
Al were it neuer so lyte and I it wyste
Me thoughte I felte deth at my herte twyste
And shortly so ferforth thys thyng is went
That my wyl was hys wyllis instrument
Thys is to sey my wyl obeyed to hys wyl
In alle thyng as fer as reson fyl
Kepyng the boundis of my worshyp euer
Ne neuer had I thyng so leef ne leuer
As hym god woot ne neuer shal nomo
Thys lastyd lenger than a yeer or two
That I supposid of hym nothyng but good
But fynally thus at the laste it stood
That fortune wolde that he must twynne
Out of that place whyche I was ynne
Where me was woo it is no questioun
I can not make of it discripcioun
For o thyng dar I telle boldly
I knowe what the peyne of deth is therby
Suche harm I fette that he ne myght bleue
So on a day of me he took hys leue
So sorowfully eke that he wende veryly
That he hadde felt as muche sorow as I
When that I herd hym speke ⁊ saw hys hewe
But neuerthelesse I thoughte he was so trewe
And eke that he repayre shold agayn
Wyth ynne a lytyl whyle soth to sayn
And reson wolde eke that he moste go
For hys honour and ofte it fallyth so
That I made vertu of necessyte
And took it wel syn it nedes muste be
As I best myght I hyd fro hym my sorow
And took hym by þe hond seynt Iohn to borow
And I sayd thus lo I am youris al
Be ye suche as I haue be to you and shal
What he answerd nedyth not to reherce
Who can say bet than he that can do wers
Whan he hath al sayd than hath he doon
Therfore behoueth hym to haue a long spoon
That shal ete wyth a fend thus herd I say
So atte laste he muste forth hys way
And forth fleyth tyl he come there hym leste
Whan it cam hym to purpos for to reste
I trow he hadde the text in mynde
That al thyng repeyryng to hys kynde
Gladyth hyth self thus sey men as I gesse
Men loue of propyr kynde newefangylnesse
As bryddis doon that men in cagis fede
For theyh thou nyght ⁊ day take of hem hede
And straw her cage feyre ⁊ softe as silk
And yeue hem suger hony bred and mylk
Yet ryght anone as that hys dore is vp
He wyth hys feet spurneth doun hys cup
And to the wood he wol and wormes ete
So newfangyl ben they of her mete
And loue noueltees of proper kynde
No gentylnesse of blood may hym bynde
So ferde thys Tarcellet allas the day
Though he were gentyl born fressh and gay
And goodly forto see humble and fre
He saw vp on a tyme a kyte fle
And sodenly he louyd thys kyte so
That al hys loue is clene fro me go
And hath hys trouthe falsid in thys wyse
Thus hath the kyte my loue in hyr seruyse
And I am lorn wythoute remedy
And wyth that word thys faucon gan to cry
And swouned eft in canaces barm
Greet was the sorow for the hawkis harm
That Canace and all her wommen made
They nyste how they myght the fawcon glade
But Canace hoom beryth her in her lappe
And softly in plasteris gan her wrappe
There as she wyth her bek had hurt her selue
Now can not Canace but herbis delue
Out of the ground and make salues newe
Of herbis precious and fyne of hewe
To hele wyth the hawke fro day to nygt
She doth her besynes and al her myght
And by her beddis hed she made a mewe
And couered it wyth veluetis blewe
In signe of trouthe that is in wommen seen
And al wythout the mewe is peyntid green
In whyche were peynted al thyse false foulis
As been thyse tidyffis tarcellis and owlis
Ryght for despyt were peyntid her beside
Pyes on theym for to crye and to chyde
Thus lete I Canace her hawke kepyng
I wol as now nomore speke of her ryng
Tyl it come eft to purpoos forto sayn
How that thys fawcon gat her loue agayn
Repentyng as the story tellyth vs
By mediacion of cambalus
The kyngis sone of whyche I you told
But hens forth I wol my processe hold
To speken of auenturis and of batayllis
That yet was neuer herde so grete meruayllis
Fyrst I wol you telle of Cambuscan
That in hys tyme many a cyte wan
And aftyr wyl I speke of algarsyf
How that he wan theodora to hys wyf
For whom ful ofte in greet peryl he was
Ne hadde he be holpyn by the hors of bras
And aftyr wol I speke of Camballo
That faught in listis wyth bretheren two
For Canace or that he myghte here wynne
And there I lefte I wol ayen begynne
Explicit secunda pars
Incipit pars tercia
APpollo whyrlith vp hys chare so hygh
Tyl that god Mercurius hous the sligh
Ther is nomore of the squyers tale
The wordes of the frankeleyns
IN fayth squyer thou hast the wel y quyt
And gentylly I prayse wel thy wyt
Quod þe frankeleyn cōmsideryng thy youthe
So felyngly thou spekest / Syr I allowthe
As to my dome ther nys none that is here
Of Eloquence that shal be thy pere
Yf that thou lyue god gyue the right good chaūnce
And in vertu sende the contynuaunce
For of thy speche I haue ryght grete deynte
I haue a sone / And by the trynyte
I had leuer than twenty pound worth londe
Though it right now were fallen in my honde
He were a man of such dyscrescion
As that ye ben / Fy on possession
But yf a man be vertuous wyth all
I haue my sone snybbed / and yet shal
For he to vertu lysteth not tendende
But for to pleye at dyse and dyspende
And lese al that he hath / is hys vsage
And he had leuer talken wyth a page
Than to comyne wyth ony gentyl wyght
Where he myght lerne gentylnes aryght
Straw for your gentylnesse quod tho our hoost
What frankeleyn parde / Syr wel thou woost
That eche of you mote tellen at the lest
A tale or two / or breken hys beheste
That knowe I wel sire quod thys frankeleyn
I pray you haue ye not me in desdeyn
Though to thys man I speke a word or two
Telle on thy tale wythout wordes mo
Gladly sir hoost quod he I wyl obeye
Vnto your wyll / Now herkene what I seye
I wyl you not contraryen in no wyse
As fer as that my wytte wyl suffyse
I pray to god that it may plesen yow
Than woot I wel that it is good ynow
Here begynneth the Frankeleyns prologe
THyse old gentyl britons in her dayes
Of dyuers auctours maden her layes
Rymed fyrst in her owen bryton tunge
Suche layes wyth her instrumentis they sunge
Or ellis reddyn hem for her plesaunce
And one of hem haue I in remembraunce
Whyche I shal say wyth a good wyl as I can
But sires by cause I am a borel man
At my begynnyng first I you beseche
Haue me excusid of my rude speche
I lernyd neuer rethorik in certayn
Thyng that I speke muste be bare and pleyn
I slepte neuer in the mount of pernaso
Ne lerned marcus Tullius ne Cithero
Colowris knowe I noon wythouten drede
But suche colouris as growen in the mede
Or ellis suche as men dyen or peynte
Colours of rethoryk be to me queynte
My spyrite felyth in no suche matere
But and ye lyst my tale shul ye here
Here endyth the Frankeleyns prologe
And here begynneth hys tale
IN Armoryk that callyd is Brytayne
Ther was a knyght that louyd ⁊ dede his payne
To serue ladyes in hys best wyse
And many a labour and many a grete empryse
He for hys lady wrought or she was wonne
For she was one the fayrest wnder sonne
And eke therto comyn of so hygh kynrede
That wel vnnethe durste the knyght for drede
Telle here hys wo hys peyne and hys dystres
But atte last she for hys worthynes
And namely for hys meke obeyssaunce
Hath suche appetyt caught of hys penaunce
That she pryuely fyl of hys accorde
To take hym for hyr husbond and hyr lorde
Of such lordship as mēm haue ouyr hir wyuys
And forto lede in the more blysse her lyuys
Of his fre wyl he swoor her as a knyght
That neuer in al hys lyf he day ne nyght
Ne shold vpon hym take no maystrye
Ageyns her wyl ne kythe her Ielousye
But her obeye and folowe her wyl in al
As ony louer to hys lady shal
Saue that the name of souereynte
That wold he haue for shame of hys degre
She thankyth hym of hys humblenesse
She sayd syre sith of your gentylnesse
Ye profer me to haue so large a Reyne
Ne wold god neuer betwyx vs tweyne
As in my gylt were othyr werre or stryf
Syre I wyl be your humble trewe wyf
Haue here my trouthe tyl my herte breste
Thus ben they bothe in quyete and in reste
For one thyng sires sauely dar I say
That frendis eueriche other muste obeye
Yf they wyl lyue in pees and hold companye
Loue wyl not be constreyned by maystrye
When maystrye is come the god of loue anon
Betyth hys wyngis and fare wel it is goon
Loue is a thyng as ony thought fre
For wommen of kynde desiren lyberte
And nat to be constreyned as a thrall
And so doth men yf I the sothe telle shal
Loke who is most pacient in loue
He is at hys auauntage al a boue
Pacience is an hygh vertu certeyn
For it venquysseth as clerkis seyn
Thyngis that rigour shal neuer atteyne
For euery word men may not chyde or pleyne
Lernyth to suffre or ellis so mot I goon
Ye shal it lerne whethyr so ye wyl or noon
For in thys world certeyn no wyght is
That he ne doth or sayth somtyme amys
Ire siknes or constyllacioun
Wyne woo or chaungynge of complexioun
Causith ful ofte to do amys or spekyn
On euery wrong a man may not be wrekyn
Aftyr the tyme must be temperaunce
To euery wyght that can of gouernaunce
And therfore hath thys wyse worthy knyght
To lyuyn in ease suffraunce hyr behyght
Ande she to hym ful wysly gan swere
That neuer shold there be defaute in here
Here men may see in humble wyse accorde
Thus hath she take her seruaunt and her lord
Seruaunt in loue and lord in maryage
Than was he bothe in lorddship ⁊ in seruage
Seruage nay but in lordship aboue
Sythe he hath bothe hys lady and hys loue
Hys lady certis and hys wyf also
The whyche that lawe of loue accordyth therto
And when he was in thys prosperyte
Home wyth hys wyf he goth to hys contre
Not fer fro penmark ther hys dwellyng was
Where as he lyuyth in blis and in solas
Who coude telle but he that weddid had be
The Ioye the ese and the prosperyte
That is betwyx an husbond and hys wyf
A yeer or more lestyth thys blisful lyf
Tyl that thys knyght of whyche I spak thus
That of kayrud was clepyd Arueragus
Shoop hym to goon ⁊ dwell a yeer or twayne
In Englond þt clepid was eke Brytayne
To seke in armys worshyp and honour
For al hys lust he sette in suche labour
And dwellid there two yere þe book saith thus
Now wol I stynte of thys Arueragus
And speke I wol of dorygene hys wyf
That louyd her husbond as her hertes lyf
For hys absence wepyth she and sikyth
As doon thyse good wyuys when hem likyth
She morneth wakyth waylyth and playnyth
Desire of hys presence so her dystreynyth
That al thys wyde world she set at nought
Her frendis that knewe her heuy thought
Conforten her in al that euer they may
They prechyn here they techen here nyght ⁊ day
That causeles she sleth her self allas
And euery comfort possyble in that caas
They do to here and al her besynes
To auoyde her sorow and her heuynes
By processe as ye knowen euerychon
Men mowe so longe graue in a stoon
Tyl some fygure ther ynne prynted be
So long haue they conforted her tyl she
Receyued hath by hope and by reson
The enpryntynge of her consolacion
Thorow which her grete sorow begān to aswage
She may not alway duryn in suche arage
And eke Arueragus in al thys care
Hath sente her lettris home of hys welfare
And that he wol come hastely agayn
Or ellis hath thys sorow her hert slayn
Her frendes saw here sorowes gan for to slake
And prayd her on their knees for goddis sake
To come and Rome her in companye
Awey to dryuen her derk fantesye
And fynally she grauntyd that requeste
For wel she sawe it was for the beste
Now stood her castel faste by the see
And ofte wyth her frendis walkyth she
Here forto dysporte vpon the bank an hye
Where as she many shyppis and bargis sye
Saylyng her cours where hem lyst to go
But yet was that a parcel of her wo
For to her self ful ofte allas sayd she
Is ther no shyp so many as I see
Wold bryng hoom my lord than were my hert
Al warysshyd of hys byttyr peynys smert
Anothyr tyme she wold sitte and thynke
And caste her eyen dounward from the brynke
But whan she sawe the grysly rockys blake
For verry feer so wold her herte quake
That on her feet she myghte not sustene
Than wold she sit doun vp on the grene
And pytously in to the see beholde
And sayen right thus with sorouful sighes colde
Eterne god that thorow thy purueaunce
Ledyst the worlde by certeyn ordenaunce
In ydyl as men say ye no thyng make
But lord thys grysly fendly rockys blake
That sownen rathyr vnto foul confusion
Of werke than to ony fayr creacion
Of suche a parfyt wyse god and a stabyl
Why haue ye wrought this werk vnresonabyl
For by this werke North south west ne est
There nys y fostrid man ne bryd ne beest
It doth no good to my wyt but annoyeth
See ye not lord how mankynde it destroyeth
An hundryd thousand bodyes of mankynde
Haue rockis slayn al though they be not in mynde
Syn mankynde is so fayr a part of thy werk
Thou it maad first lyk to thyn owen merk
Than semyth it ye haue do a gret chyerte
Toward mankynde but how may it than be
That ye suche menys make it to destroyen
Suche menes ne do no good but annoyen
I woot wel clerkys wol say as hym lyst
By argumentis that al is for the best
Though I ne can the causis wel knowe
But that god that made the wynd to blowe
As kepe my lord thys is my conclusion
To clerkis lete I al dysputacion
But wold god that al thyse Rockis blake
Were sonkyn in to helle for hys sake
Thyse rockis sle my herte for feer
Thus wold she say wyth many a pytous teer
Here frendis sawe that it was no dysport
To romyn by the see but dyscomforte
And shapen forto pley somwhere ellis
They ledyn here by Ryueris and by wellis
And eke in other places dilectablis
They daunsyn ⁊ pleyn atte ches ⁊ atte tablis
So one a day right on the morow tyde
Vnto a gardyn that was there besyde
In whiche that they had made her ordynannce
Of vytayl and of othyr purueaunce
They goon and pleyn hem al the longe day
And thys was in the sixte morow of may
Which may hath peyntid with her soft showris
Thys gardyn ful of leuys and of flouris
And craft of mannys hond so coryously
Arayd hath thys gardyn trewly
That neuer was there gardyn of suche prys
But yf it were the verry paradyse
The odour of flouris and the fressh syghte
Wold haue maad ony herte lyghte
That euer was born but yf to gret siknes
Or to greet sorow held it in dystres
So ful it was of beaute wyth plesaunce
Anon aftyr dyner gonne they to daunce
And song also saue dorygene allone
Whyche maad alwey her compleynt ⁊ hir mone
For she ne saw hym in the daunce go
That was her husbond and her loue also
But natheles she muste her tyme abyde
And wyth good hope lete her sorowys slyde
Vp on thys daunce among other men
Daunsid a squyer before dorigene
That fressher was and Iolyer of arraye
As to my dome than is the monthe of Maye
He syngyth daunsyth passyng ony other man
That is or was syn the world began
Therwyth he was yf men shold hym dyscryue
One of the beste faryng men on lyue
Yong strong vertuous ryche and wyse
And wel belouyd and holdyn in gret pryce
And shortly yf I the soth telle shall
Vnwytyng of thys dorygene at all
Thys lusty squyer seruaunt to venus
Whyche that clepyd was Aurelius
Hath louyd her best of ony creature
Two yeer or more as was hys auenture
But neuer durste he telle her hys greuaunce
Wythoute the cup drank he al hys penaunce
He was despeyred nothyng durste he sey
Saue in hys songis somdele wold he wrey
Hys woo as in a general compleynynge
He sayd he louyd ⁊ was belouyd nothynge
Of suche mater made he meny layis
Songis compleyntis rondels vyrelayes
How that he durste not hys sorow telle
But languyng as a furye doth in helle
And dye he sayd he muste as dyd Ekko
For narcisus that durst not telle his wo
In other maner than ye here now say
Ne durste he not hys wo to hyr bewray
Saue parauenture at festes and daunsis
There yong folk kepyn her obseruauncis
It may weel ben he lokid in her face
In suche a wyse as men that axen grace
But nothyng wyste she of hys entent
Natheles it happid or they thens went
By cause that he was her neyghebour
And was a man of worshyp and honour
And hadde knowen hym of tymes yore
They fallen in speche ⁊ so more and more
In to hys purpos drewe Aurelius
And whan he saw hys tyme he sayd thus
Madame quod he by god þt this world made
So that I wyste I myght your herte glade
I wolde that day that your Arueragus
Went ouer the see that I Aurelius
Had gone there I sholde neuer come ageyn
For wel I woot my seruyse is in veyn
My guerdom is but brestyng of myn herte
Madame rewe on my peynys smerte
For wyth a word ye may me sleen or saue
Here at your feet god wold I were begraue
I ne haue as nowe nomore leyser to seye
Haue mercy swete and do me not to deye
She gan to loke vp on thys Aurelius
Is this your wyl quod she and say ye thus
Neuer erst quod she ne wyst I what ye ment
But now Aurelye I knowe your entent
By that god that yaf me soule and lyf
Ne shal I neuer be vntrewe wyf
In word ne in werk as fer as I haue wyt
I wyl be hys to whome that I am knyt
Take thys for fynal answere as of me
But aftyr than in pley thus sayd she
Aurely sayd she by hygh god a boue
Yet wol I graunte you to be your loue
Syn I se you so pytously compleyne
Loke what day that endlong brytayne
Ye remeue al the rockis stoon by stoon
That they ne lette shyp ne boot to goon
I say whan ye haue maad the coste so clene
Of rockis that there is no stoon I seen
Than wol I loue you best of ony man
Haue here my trouthe in al that euer I can
Is there none other grace in you quod he
No by that lord quod she that maked me
For wel I woot that it shal neuer betyde
Let suche folye out of your herte a slyde
What deynte shold a man haue in hys lyf
Forto go loue anothyr mannys wyf
That hath her body when so that hym likyth
Aurelius ful ofte sore sykyth

No fors quod he but tel me all your greef
Syre quod thys frere an odious myschyef
Thys day be tyd is to myn ordre and me
And so per consequens in eche degre
Of holy chyrche god amende it sone
Syr quod the lord ye woot what is to done
Dystempere you not ye be my confessour
Ye be the salt of the erthe and the sauour
For goddis loue your pacience now hold
Tel me your greef and he anon hym told
As ye haue herd beforn ye woot wel what
The lady of the hous ay stylle sat
Tyl she hadde herd what the frere had sayde
Ey goddis moder quod she the blissyd mayde
Is ther aught ellis tel me feythfully
Madame quod he how thynke ye ther by
How þt me thynkith quod she so god me spede
I say a chorl hath do a chorlis dede
What sholde I say god let hym neuer the
Hys syke heed is ful of vanyte
I holde hym in a maner of a fransye
Madame quod he by god I shal not lye
But I in ony wyse may on hym a wreke
I shal dyffame hym ouer al where I speke
That fals blasfemeur whiche that chargid me
To parte it that wol not departid be
To euery ylyke moche wyth myschaunce
The lord sat stylle as he were in a traunce
And in hys herte he rollid vp and doun
How that thys chorle hath ymagynacioun
To shewe suche a probleme to the frere
Neuer erst er now herd I of suche a matere
I trow the deuyl put it in hys mynde
In ars metryk shal there noman fynde
Beforn thys day of such a questioun
Who shold make a demonstracioun
That euery man shold haue lyke hys part
As of a soun or of sauour of a fart
O nyce prowd chorle I shrew hys face
Lo sirs quod the lord wyth hard grace
Who euer herd of such a thyng or now
To euery man y lyke tel me how
Hyt is an Impossyble it may not be
Ey nyce chorle god lete hym neuer the
The romblyng of a fart and euery soun
Nys but of ayer reuerberacioun
And euer it wastyth lyte and lyte away
Ther is noman can deme by my fey
Yf that it were departid equally
What lo my chorle lo yet how shrewdly
Vnto my confessour to day he spak
I holde hym certeyn a demonyak
Now ete your mete and let the chorle go pley
Lete hym go hange hym self a deuyl wey
Now stood the lordis squyer at hys bord
That carf hys mete and herd word by word
Of all thys thyng of whyche I haue you sayd
My lord quod he be ye not euyl apayd
For I coude telle for a gowne cloth
To you sire frere so ye be not wroth
How that thys fart shold euyn delid be
Among your couent yf it like sithee
Tel quod the lord and thou shalt haue anon
A gowne cloth by god and by saynt Iohn
My lord quod he when that the wedyr is fayr
Wythout wynde or perturbyng of ayer
Let brynge a carte whele right in to this halle
But so that it haue hys spokis alle
Twelf spokis hath a carte whele comynly
And bryng me thēmne xij freris woot ye why
For thertene is a couent as I gesse
Your confessour here for hys worthynesse
Shal parfourme vp þe noumbir of hys couent
Than shul they knele doun by one assent
And to euery spokis ende in thys manere
Ful sadly ley hys nose shal a frere
Your nobyl confessour ther god hym saue
Shal hold hys nose vpright vnder the naue
Than shal this chorle with bely styf ⁊ tought
As ony tabour hyder be y brought
And set hym on the wheel right of thys cart
Vp on the naue and make hym lete a fart
And ye shul see vp peryl of my lyf
By preef whyche that is demonstratyf
That equally the sound of it wol wende
And eke the stynk out at the spokis eende
Saue that thys worthy man your confessour
By cause he is a man of gret honour
Shal haue the first fruyt as reson is
The nobyl vsage of freris yet is thys
The worthiest man of theym shal first be seruyd
And certeynly he hath it wel deseruyd
He hath to day taught vs so muche good
Wyth prechyng in the pulpet there he stood
That I may vouchesauf I say for me
He hadde the first smel of fartis thre
And so wold all hys brethern hardely
He berith hym so fayre and so holyly
The lord the lady ⁊ eche man saue the frere
Sayde that Iankyn spak in thys matere
As wel as Ouyde or Ptholome
Towchyng the chorlis they sayd subtylte
And hye wyt made hym speke as he spak
He nys no fool ne no demonyak
And Iankyn hath y wonne a newe gowne
My tale is doon we be almost at toune
Here endeth the Sompnours tale

And foloweth the Prologe of the clerk
of Oxenford

Here begynneth the prologue
Of the clerke of Oxenford /
SIr clerk of Oxenford our ost sayde
Ye ride as quoy ⁊ stylle as doth a mayde
Were new spousid sittyng at the borde
This day ne herde I of your tunge a word
I trowe ye study abonte somme sophyme
But Salamon sayd that al thyng hath tyme
For goddys sake as be of good chere
It is no tyme now to study here
Tel vs somme mery tale by your fey
For what man is entrid in to a pley
He nedis moot in to the pley assente
But prechyth not as freris doo in lente
To make vs for our olde synnes wepe
Ne that thy tale make vs not to slepe
Tel vs som mery thyng of auenturis
Your termys your colouris and your figuris
Kepe hem in store til so be that ye endyte
High style is when men to kyngys write
Spekyth so playn at this tyme I yow pray
That we may vnderstonde what ye say
This worthy clerk benygnely answerde
Ost quod he I am vnder your yerde
Ye haue of vs as now the gouernaunce
And therfore I shal do you obeysaunce
As fer as reson askyth hardely
I wol you telle a tale whiche that I
Lernyd at Padow of a worthy clerke
As preuyd is by his wordes and his werke
He is now ded and nayled in his cheste
I pray to god yeue his soule good reste
Fraunceys petrark the laureat poete
Hight this clerk whoos rethorik swete
Enlumyned al ytayle of poetrye
As lynyan dyd of phylosophye
Or lawe or other arte particuler
But deth that wyl not suffre vs dwellen here
But as it were the twynkelyng of an eye
Hem bothe hath sleyn and al shal we deye
But forth to telle of thys worthy man
That taughte me this tale as I began
I say that first wyth high style he enditeth
Er he the body of his tale writeth
A prohemye in whiche discryueth he
Pemounte and of Saluces the contree
And spekyth of arpentyn the hylles hye
That ben the boundes of west lumbardye
And of mount vesulus in special
Where that the poo out of the welle smal
Takyng his first spryngyng and his sours
That Estward euer encresith in his cours
To Emeli ward to Ferrare and venyse
The whiche a long thyng were to deuyse
And trewly as to my Iugement
Me thynketh it a thyng inpertynent
Saue that hym list conueye his matere
But this is his tale as ye mow here
Here endyth the prologue

And begynneth the clerkis
tale of Oxonford
THere is in the west syde of Itayle
Doun at the rote of vesulus the colde
A lusty playn habundaunt of vitayl
where many a toun and tour thou mayst beholde
That fouuded were in tyme of faders old
And many another delyctable sight
And saluces thys noble contre hight
A markis somtyme lord was of that lond
As were his worthy eldris hym before
And obeysaunt ay redy to his hond
Were al his lieges bothe lasse and more
Thus in delyte he lyued and hath do yore
Beloued ⁊ drad thorough fauour of fortune
Both of his lordes and eke of his comune
Therwyth he was to speke as of lynage
The gentylest y born of lumbardye
A fair parsone and strong and yong of age of age73: There is a bar between these words
And ful of honour and of curtesye
Discrete ynow his contre for to gye
Saue in som thynges that he was to blame
And waltir was thys yong lordys name
I blame hym thus that he considered not
In tyme comyng what myght hym betyde
But on hys lust present was al his thought
As for to hauke and hunte on euery syde
Wel nygh al other curis let he slyde
And eke he nolde ⁊ that was worst of al
Wedde no wyf for aught that myght befal
Only that poynt his pepyl bare so sore
That flokmele on a day they to hym went
And one of hem that wysest was of lore
Or ellys that the lord wolde best assent
That he shold telle hym what his peple ment
Or ellys coude he shewe wel suche matere
He to the markis sayd as ye shul here
O nobyl markis your humanyte
Assurith vs and yeueth vs hardynes
As ofte as tyme is of necessyte
That we to yow mow telle our heuynes
Accepteth now lord of youre gentilnes
That we with pytous herte vnto you pleyne
And lete your eris not my vois disdaigne
Al haue I not to doon in this matere
More than a nother man hath in thys place
Yet for as muche as ye my lord so dere
Haue alway shewed me fauour and grace
I dar the better axe of you a space
Of audyence to sheWe our request
And ye my lord to doo right as you lest
For certes lord so wel vs liketh you
And al your werke ⁊ euer haue doon that we
Ne coude not our self deuysen how
We myghte lyuyn in more felicite
Saue o thyng lord yf your wyl be
That for to be a weddyd man you lest
Thenne were your pepil in souereyn hertes rest
Bowe ye your hed vnder the blisful yok
Of souereynte and not of seruyse
Whiche that men clepyth spousayle or wedlok
And thynkith lord among your wittis wyse
How that our dayes passen in sondry wyse
For though we slepe or wake renne or ryde
Ay fleyth the tyme it wol noman abyde
And though your grene youth floure as yet
In crepyth age as stylle as ony stoon
And deth manasseth euery age and smyte
In eche astate for there ne escapyth noon
And also certeyn as we knowe echoon
That we shul dye and vucerteyn we alle
Been of the day whan deth shal on vs falle
Acceptith than of vs the trewe entent
That yet neuer refuseden your heste
And we Wol lorde yf ye wol assent
Chese you a wyf in short tyme atte leste
Born of the gentillest and of the meste
Of al Italye so that it oughte seme
Honour to god and you as I can deme
Delyuer vs out of al thys besy drede
And take a wyf for high goddys sake
For yf so be it befalle as god forbede
That thorow your deth your lyne shold slake
And that a straunge successour shold taak
Your heri tage o wo were vs on lyue
Wherfore we pray you hastely to wyue
Her meke prayeer and her pietous chere
Made the markis herte for to haue pyte
Ye wol quod he myn owen peple dere
To that I neuer erst thought constreyne me
I me reioysed in my lyberte
That selde tyme is founde in mariage
There I was fre I muste be in seruage
But netheles I see your trewe entente
And truste vpon your wyt ⁊ haue doon ay
Wherfore of my fre wyl I wyl assente
To wedde me as sone as euer I may
But there as ye haue profrid me to day
To chese me a wyf I yow relece
That chois I pray you of that profir sece
For god it woot that chyldren ofte been
Vnlyke her worthy eldres hem before
Bounte cometh al of god not of the streen
Of whiche they be gendrid and y bore
I truste in goddis bounte and therfore
My mariage and myn astate and reste
I hym betake he may doo as hym leste
Lete me allone in chesyng of my wyf
That charge vpon my bak y wyl endure
But I you pray ⁊ charge vpon your lyf
That what wyf that I take ye massure
To worshyp hir whiles her lyf may dure
In worde ⁊ werk both here and euery where
As she an emperours doughter were
And ferthermore this shal ye swere that ye
Ayenst my chois shal neuer grutche ne stryue
For sith I shal forgo my liberte
At your request as euer mot I thryue
There as my herte is set there wol I wyue
And but ye wyl assente in suche manere
I pray you spekyth nomore of thys matere
With herty wyl they sworyn and assentyn
To al this thyng there sayd not one wygyt nay
Besekyng hym of grace or that they wentyn
That he wold graunte hem a certeyn day
Of his spousayl as sone as euer he may
For yet alwey many of the pepyl dredde
Lest the markys wold no wyf wedde
He graunted hem a day suche as hym lest
On whiche he wold be weddyd sikerly
And sayd he dyd al this at hir request
And they wyth humble entent buxomly
Knelyng vp on her knees ful reuerently
Hym thanked alle ⁊ thus they haue an ende
Of her entent and hoom ayen they wende
And here vp on he toke his offycers
And commaunded for the feste to purueye
And to his pryue knyghtes and squyers
Suche charge yaf as he lyst on hem leye
And they to his commaundement obeye
And eche of hem doth alle his dilygence
To do vnto that feste high reuerence
Prima pars Grisildis
NOught fer fro that paleys honourable
There as this markis shoop his mariage
Ther stode a thorpe of sight ful delictable
In whiche that pour folk of that vyllage
Hadden her bestys and her herbygage
And of her labour toke her sustenaunce
After that the erthe yaf hem habundaunce
Among thyse pour folke ther dwellyd a man
Whiche was I holde pourest of hem alle
But hygh god somtyme sende can
His grace in to a lityl oxys stalle
Ianycola men of that throwpe hym calle
A doughter had he fayr ynough to sight
And Crisildes thys yong mayden hyght
But for to speke of vertuous beaute
Than was she one the fayrest vnder sonne
And ful pouerly y fostred vp was she
No licorous lust was thrugh her herte y ronne
But ofter of the welle than of the wyn tonne
She dranke and for she wold vertu plese
She knewe wel labour but none ydle ese
But though this mayde so tendir were of age
Yet in the brest of her vyrgynyte
There was enclosed ripe and sad corage
And in grete reuerence and charyte
Her olde poure fadre fostryd she
A fewe sheep spynnyng on felde she kepte
She wold not be ydle tyl she slepte
And whan she homward cam she wolde brynge
wortys or other herbys tymes ofte
The which she shredde ⁊ setheth for hir lyuynge
And made her bed harde ⁊ nothyng softe
And ay she kepte her faders lyf on lofte
Wyth eueriche obeysaunce and dilygence
That chylde myght doo to the fadris reuerence
Vp on Grisilde thys pour creature
Ful ofte sithys this markys sette his eye
As he rood on huntyng perauenture
And When it befyl that he myght her aspye
He not wyth wanton lokyng of folye
His eyen cast on her but in sad wyse
Vp on her chere he wold hym ofte auyse
Commendyng in his herte her womanhede
And eke her vertu passyng ony wyght
Of so yong age as wel in chere as dede
For though the peple had no grete insight
In vertu he considered ful right
Her bounte ⁊ disposid hym that he wolde
Wedde her only yf he euer wedde sholde
The day of weddyng cam but no wyght can
Telle what maner Woman hit shold be
For whiche meruayl wondred many a man
And sayd whan they were in priuyte
wol not our lord leue yet his vanyte
Wol he not wedde allas allas the whyle
Why wol he thus hym self and vs begyle
But netheles thys markys had do make
Of gemmys sette in golde and in asure
Brochys and ryngys for grisildes sake
And of her clothyng took the mesure
Of a mayde like vnto hir stature
And eke of her other ornamentis alle
That vnto suche a weddyng shold befalle
The tyme of vndryn on the same day
Approchyd that the weddyng shold be
And al the palays put was in aray
Both halle ⁊ chambrys eche in his degre
Howsis of offyce stuffyd wyth grete plente
There mayst thou see of deynteous vitaylle
That may be founden as fer as lastyth Itayle
This rial markis richely arayed
Lordis and ladyes in his companye
The whiche that to the feste were prayed
And of his retenu the bachelrye
Wyth many a soWn of sondry melodye
Vnto the vylage of whiche I tolde
In thys aray the right wey haue holde
Grisyld of this god woot ful Innocent
That for her shapyn was al thys aray
To fette water atte welle is went
And comyth hoom as sone as euer she may
For wel she herd sayd that ylke day
That the markis shold wedde ⁊ yf she myghte
She Wolde fayn haue seyn somme of that sighte
She thoughte I wyl wyth other maydens stonde
That been my felowes in our dore and se
The markesse and therfore wyl I fonde
To doon at hoom as sone as it may be
The labour Whiche that longeth to me
And than I may at leyser here beholde
Yf she this wey vnto the castel holde
And as she wold ouer the thresshold goon
The markis cam and gan her for to calle
And she set doun her water pot anone
Besides the thresshold in an oxes stalle
And doun vpon her knees she gan to falle
And with sad contenaunce knelid stylle
Tyl she had herd what was the lordys wylle
Thys thoughtful markis spak vnto the mayde
Ful sobirly and sayd in thys manere
Where is your fader o Grisildis he sayde
And she wyth reuerence and humble chere
Answerd lord he is al redy here
And in she goth wyth outen lenger let
And to the markis she her fader fet
He by the hond than took this olde man
And sayd thus whan he had hym a syde
Ianycula I nether may ne can
The plesaunce lenger of my herte hyde
Yf that thou vouchesauf that so betyde
Thy doughter wyl I take or that I wende
As to my wyf vnto her lyuys ende
Thou louest me I woot it Wel certeyn
And art my feythful liege man bore
And al that liketh me I dar wel sayn
It liketh the and specially therfore
Tel me that poynt that I sayd before
And yf thou wolt vnto that purpos drawe
To take me as for thy sone in lawe
This sodeyn caas thys man a stoned soo
That reed he wext abasshyd and al quakyng
He stood vnnethe sayd he wordes mo
But only thus lord quod he my wyllynge
Ys as ye wyl ne agaynst your likynge
I wol no thyng ye be my lord so dere
Right as you list gouernyth thys matere
Yet wol I quod thys markis softely
That in your chambre I ⁊ thou and she
Haue a collacion and Wotist thou why
For I wyl axe yf it here wyl be
To be my wyf and reule her after me
And al thys shal be do in thy presence
I nyl not speke out of thyn audyence
And in the chambyre whyle they were aboute
Her tretees whiche as ye shal after here
The pepyl cam in to the hous al wythoute
And wondred hem in how honest manere
And so tentifly kepte her fader dere
But vtterly grisilde wondre myghte
For neuer erst ne saw she suche a sighte
No wonder is though she were stoned
To se so grete a gest come in that place
She neuer was to no suche gestys y woned
For whiche she lokid wyth ful paal face
But shortly forth this mater for to chase
These ben the wordis that the markis sayde
To thys verry benygne feythful mayde
Grisilde he sayd ye shul wel vnderstonde
It liketh vnto your fader and vnto me
That I you wedde and eke it may so stonde
As I suppose ye wyl that it so be
But thyse demaundis axe I first quod he
That sith it shal be doon in hasty wyse
Wol ye assente or ellis you auyse
I say thus be ye redy wyth good herte
To al my lust and that I frely may
As me best thynkith though ye lawhe or smerte
And neuer ye to grutche nyght ne day
Whan I say ye that ye say not ones nay
Nother by word ne by frounyng countenaunce
SWere thys and here I suere our allyance
Wondryng vpon thise wordes quakyng for drede
She sayd lorde indigne and vnworthy
I am to suche honour as ye me bede
But as ye wyl your self right so wyl I
And here I swere that neuer wyllyngly
In werk ne thought I nyl yow disobeye
For to be ded though me were loth to deye
This is ynough Grisilde myn quod he
And forth he goth with a ful sobyr chere
Out atte dore and after cam she
And to the pepyl he sayd in thys manere
This is my Wyf quod he that stondeth here
Honourith her and loueth her I you praye
Who so me louyth there is no more to saye
And for that no thyng of her olde gere
She shold brynge in to his hous he bad
That women shold despoyle her there
Of whiche thyse ladies were not ful glad
To handel her clothys where in she was clad
But netheles thys mayde bright of hewe
Fro foot to hed they clothyd her al newe
Her heris they kempte that lay vntressyd
Ful rudely ⁊ wyth her fyngrys smale
A crowne on her hed they haue y dressyd
And set hir ful of owches grete and smale
Of her aray what shold I make a tale
Vnnethe the pepyl her knewe for her fayrnes
Whan she translated was in such riches
This markis hath her spousid wyth a ryng
Brought for the same cause ⁊ thenne her set
Vp on an hors snowe white ful wel amblyng
And to his paleys or he lenger let
Wyth ioyful peple that her ladde and met
Conueyed her ⁊ thus the day they spende
In reuel til the sonne gan descende
And shortly forth thys tale for to chace
I say that to this newe Markessesse
God hath such fauour sente of his grace
That it ne semed by no liklynes
That she was born ⁊ fedde in rudenes
As in a cote or in an oxis stalle
But norisshed in an emperours halle
To euery wight she woxen is so dere
And worshypful that folke there she was bore
And from hir birthe knewe her yere by yere
Vnnethe trowed they but durst haue swore
That to Ianycul of whiche I spack before
She doughter was for as by coniecture
Hem thought she was another creature
For though that euer vertuous was she
She was encresid in suche excellence
Of thewys good set in high bounte
And so discrete and feyr of eloquence
So benygne and so digne of reuerence
And coude so the peplis hertis enbrace
That eche her louyd that lokid in her face
Not only of Saluces in the toun
Publisshed was the bounte of her name
But eke beside in many a regyoun
Yf one sayde wel another sayd the same
So spredde of her hygh bounte the fame
That men ⁊ women both yong and olde
Gon to Saluces vpon her to beholde
Thus walter lowly nay but ryally
weddyd hath wyth fortunat honeste
In goddis pees lyuyth ful honestly
At hoom ⁊ outward grace ynough had he
And for he saw that vnder lowe degre
Was honest vertu hyd the peple hym helde
A prudent man and that is seen ful selde
Not only this Grisilde though hir wit
Coude al the feet of wyfly humbylnes
But eke whan that the caas requyred it
The comune prouffyt coude she redresse
There nas discorde rancour ne heuynesse
In al the londe that she it coude a peas
And Wysely brynge hem in rest and eas
Though her husbond were absent or none
Yf gentilmen or other of that contre
Were wroth she wolde brynge hem attone
So wyse and rype wordes had she
And in Iugement so grete equyte
That she from heuyn sent was as men wend
Pepyl to saue and euery wrong to amende
Not long tyme after that this Grisilde
Was weddyd she a doughter had y bore
Al had her leuyr bore a knaue chylde
Glad was the markis and the folke therfore
For though a mayde chylde cam al before
She may vnto a knaue chylde atteyne
By liklihede syn she nys not bareyne
Explicit secunda Pars
Et sequitur Pars tercia
THer fill as it befallyth ofte tyme mo
When that this chylde had sokyd but a throwe
This markis in his herte longeth so
To tempte his wyf her sadnes to knowe
That he ne myght out of his herte throwe
This meruaylous desire his wyf to assaye
Nedeles god wote he thought her taffraye
He had assayed her ynough ofte tyme before
And fond her euer good what nedeth it
Her for to tempte and alway more and more
Though sum man preyse it for a subtil wyt
But as for me I say ful euyl it syt
To assaye a wyf whan that it is no nede
And put her in anguysshe and in drede
For which this markis wrought in this maner

div.l: He cam allone a nyght there as she lay
With sterne face and right ogly chere
And sayd thus Grisilde quod he that day
That I you took fro your poure aray

Her soulys wente to the kyng of grace
This maxymus that sawe this thyng betyde
With pytous teris tolde it anon right
That he her soulys sawe to heuyn glyde
With aungelys ful of clerenes and light
And with his word conuertid many awyght
For whiche almachius dyd hym so to bete
With whippis of led til he his lyf gan lete
Cecily hym took ⁊ buried hym anon
By tiburce and valerian sothly
Within her buryynge place vnder the stoon
And after this almachius hastely
Bad his mynystris fetchyn openly
Cecily so that she myght in his presence
Do sacrefise and Iubiter encence
But they conuerted at her wyse lore
Weptyn ful sore and yaf ful credence
Vnto her worde and cryden more and more
Crist goddis sone whiche withoute difference
Is verry god this is our sentence
That hath a seruaunt so good hym to serue
This with o voys we trowen though we sterue
Almachyus that herde of thys doynge
Bad fetche Cecily that he myght her see
And alderfirst this was his axynge
What maner woman art thou quod he
I am a gentilwoman born quod she
I axe the quod he though it the greue
Of thy relygyon and of thy beleue
Why than began ye your questyon folily
Quod she that wolde two answers conclude
In one demaunde ye axyd lewdly
Almache answerde to that symylitude
Of whens comyth thyn answer so rude
Of whens qd she whan that she was freyned
Of conscience and of good feyth vnfeyned
Almachius sayd ne takest thou no hede
Of my power / ⁊ she answerd hym thys
Your myght quod she is ful litil to drede
For euery mortal mannys power nys
But like a bladder ful of wynde ywys
For with a nedelis poynt when it is blowe
May al the boste of it be leyde ful lowe
Ful wrongfully began thou quod he
And in wrong is yet al thy perseueraunce
Wost thou not how our prynces myghty ⁊ fre
Haue thus cōmmaunded and made ordenaunce
That euery cristen wyght shal haue penaunce
But yf that he his cristendom wyth seye
And gon al quyt yf he wyl it reneye
Your prynces erren as your nobley doth
Quod tho cecile in a wood sentence
Ye make vs gylty and it is not soth
For ye that knowen wel our Innocence
For as muche as we do ay reuerence
To crist ⁊ for we bere a cristen name
Ye put on vs a cryme and eke a blame
But we that knowen that name so
For vertuous we may it not withseye
Almache answerde chese one of thyse two
Do sacrefise or cristendom reneye
That thou mowe ascape by that weye
At whiche worde this holy blisful mayde
Gan for to laughe ⁊ to the Iuge sayde
O Iuge confused in thy nycete
Wolt thou that I reneye Innocence
To make me a wycked wyght quod she
Lo he dissymulith here in audyence
He starith and wodith in his aduertence
To whom almache sayde o sely wretche
Ne wost thou not how fer my might may stretche
Haue not our myghty prynces yeuen
To me both power and auctorite
To make folk bothe dyen ⁊ lyuyn
Why spekyst thou than so proudly to me
I speke not but stedfastly quod she
Not proudly for I say as for my syde
We hatyn dedely that vice of pryde
And yf thou drede not a soth for to here
Than wyl I shewe al openly by right
Thou that hast made a ful grete lesynge here
Thou sayst thy prynces haue yeue the myght
Bothe for to slee and for to quycken a wyght
That thou mayst but only lyf bereue
Thou hast noon other power ne non leue
But thou maist say thy princes haue the makid
Mynystir of deth for yf thou speke of mo
Thou liest for thy poure is ful nakyd
Do wey thy boldnes sayd Almache tho
And do sacrefise to our goddys or thou goo
I reche not what wrong thou me proffre
For I can suffre as can a philosophre
But that wrongis may I not endure
That thou spekist of our goddis here quod he
O cecily answer o nyce creature
Thou saydist no word sith thou spakyst to me
That I ne knewe therwith thy nycete
And that thou were in euery maner wyse
A lewd offycer and a veyn Iustyse
There lackith no thyng of thyn vtter eyen
But thou art blynd for thyng that we see alle
That is a stoon that mowe men wel aspyen
That ylke stoon a god thou wolt it calle
I rede the lete thyn hond vpon it falle
And taste it wel ⁊ stoon thou shalt it fynde
Syn that thou seest not with thyn eyen blynde
It is a shame that the pepyl shal
So skorne the ⁊ lawghe at thy folye
For comynly men woot it wel ouer al
That myghty god is in his heuenys hye
And thyse ymagys wel thou mayst aspye
To the ne to hem self may do not profyte
For in effect they be not worth a myte
This and suche other wordes sayde she
And he wax wroth and bad men shold her lede
Hoom vntil her hous ⁊ in her hous quod he
Brenne her in a bath of flamys rede
And as he bad right so was it do in dede
For in a bath they gonne her fast shyttyn
And nyght ⁊ day fyre they vnder bettyn
The long nyght and eke the day also
For al the fyre and eke the grete hete
She sat al cold and felt no maner woo
It made her not a drope for to swete
But in that bath her lyf she moot lete
For almachius wyth a ful wycked entent
To sle her in the Bath his sonde to her sent
Thre strokis in the necke he smoot her tho
The turmentour but for no maner chaunce
He myght not smyte her necke a two
And for there was that tyme an ordenaunce
That no man shold do to no ꝑpersone suche penaunce
The fourth strook to smyten softe or sore
This turmentour ne durst do no more
But half ded with her neck coruyn there
He left her lye and on his wey is went
The cristen folk whiche that aboute her were
With shetis haue the blood vp hent
Thre dayes lyuyd she in this turment
And neuyr cesid hem the feyth to teche
That she had fostrid hem she gan to preche
And hem she yaf her meuablis ⁊ her thynge
And to pope vrban betoke hem tho
And sayd I askyd this of heuen kynge
To haue respyt thre dayes and no moo
To recomende to you or that I goo
Thyse soulis lo and that I maye do wirche
Here of my hous perpetuelly a chirche
Saynt vrban with his dekenys pryuely
The body fet and buried it by nyght
Among his other sayntis honestly
Her hous the chirche of saynte cecily hight
Saynt Vrban halowed it as he wel myght
In whiche in to this day in nobyl wyse
Men do to crist ⁊ to his sayntes seruyse
Here endeth the seconde nonnys tale

And begynneth the prologue
Of the chanons yeman
WHen tolde was the lyf of saynt Cecile
Or we had ryden fully fyue myle
At boughton vnder ble vs gan a take
A man that clothyd was in clothys blake
And vndernethe he waar a whyte surplice
His hakney whiche was of pomel gryce
So swette he that wonder was to see
Hit semyd that he had pricked mylys thre
Aboute the peytrel stood the fome ful hye
He was of fome as fleckyd as a pye
The hakeney eke that his yeman rood vpon
So swette that vnnethys myght it goon
A male twyfolde vpon his cropyn lay
It semed that he caryed lityl aray
Al light for somer rood this worthy man
And in myn herte to wonder I began
What that he was til that I vnderstood
How that his cloke was sowyd to his hood
For whiche whan I had long auysed me
I demed hym sum chanon for to be
His hat hyng at his bak doun by a lace
For he had ryden more than trot or pace
He rood ay prickyng as he were wood
A clote leef he had leyde vnder his hood
For swoot and for to kepe his hede fro hete
But it was Ioye for to see hym swete
His forhed droppyd as a styllatory
Were ful of planteyn or of peritory
And whan he was come he gan crye
God saue quod he this ioly companye
Fast haue I pricked quod he for your sake
By cause that I wolde you ouer take
To riden in this mery companye
His yeman was eke ful of curtesye
And sayde siris now in the morow tyde
Out of your hostery I saw you ryde
And warned here my lord and souerayn
Whiche that to riden with you is ful feyn
For his disporte he louyth dalyaunce
Frend for thy warnyng god yeue þe good chaūnce
Than sayde our hoost certeyn it wolde seme
Thy lord were wyse ⁊ so y may wel deme
He is ful iocunde also dar I ley
Can he ought telle a mery tale or twey
With whiche he glad may this companye
Who sir my lord / ye sir withouten lye
He can of myrthe and eke of Iolite
Not but ynow also sire trustyth me
And ye hym knewe as wel as do I
Ye wolde wonder how wel and craftely
He coude werke and that in sondry wyse
He hath taken on hym many a grete emprise
Whiche were ful hard for ony that is here
To brynge aboute but they of hym it lere
As homely as he ridyth amongys yow
Yf ye hym knewe it wolde be for your prow
Ye wolde not forgoon his acqueyntaunce
For mykyl good I dar ley in balaunce
Al that I haue in my possessyon
He is a man of hygh discrescion
I warne you he is a passyng wyse man
Wel qd our hoost I pray the telle me than
Is he a clerk or none tel me what he is
A clerk nay nay he is gretter than a clerk ywys
Sayde this yeman and in wordes fewe
Hoost ⁊ of his craft somwhat wyl I s~ewe
Syr my lord can suche a subtilte
But al his craft ye may not wite of me
For al the ground to caunterbury toun
He coude al clene turne vp so doun
And paue it al with siluer and wyth golde
And when this yeman hath thus tolde
Vnto our hoost / he sayde benedicite
This thyng is wonder merueyllous to me
Syn that thy lorde is of so hygh prudence
By cause of whiche shold men hym reuerence
That of his worshyp reckyth he so lyte
His ouerest sloppe is not worth a myte
As in effect to hym so moot y goo
It is al baudy and to tore also
Why is thy lord so sluttysshe I the pray
And of power is better cloth to bey
Yf that his dede accorde wyth his speche
Tel me that and that I the beseche
Why quod this yeman wherto axe ye of me
God helpe me so for he shal neuer the
But I wyl not auowe that I sey
And therfore kepe it secret I you prey
He is to wyse in feyth as I beleue
That is ouer doo it wyl neuer preue
And right as clerkys sayn it is a vice
Wherfore in that I holde hym lewd and nyce
For whan a man hath ouer grete a wytte
Ful ofte it happith hym to mys vse it
So doth my lord and that me greuyth sore
God it amende I can say no more
Therof no force good yeman quod our hoyst
Syn of the connyng of thy lord thou boost
Tel hou he doth tel on now hardelye
Syn that he is so crafty and so slye
Where duelle ye yf it to telle be
In the subbarbys of a toun quod he
Lurkynge in hernys ⁊ in lanys blynde
Where as thise robbers ⁊ thise theuys by kynde
Holden her ferdful pryuy residence
As they that dar not shewe her presence
So fare we yf we shal say the sothe
Now quod our hoost lete me talke tothe
Why art thou so discolouryd in thy face
Peter quod he god yeue it hard grace
I am so vsid the hote fyre to blowe
That it hath chaunged my colour I trowe
I am not wont in no myrour to prye
But swynke sore and lerne multeplye
We bloundryn euer and powryn in the fyre
And for al that we faylen of our desire
For euer we lacke our conclusion
To mykyl folke we do illusion
And borow gold be it a pound or two
Or ten or twelue or many sommys mo
And make hem wene atte leste wey
That of a pounde we coude make twey
It is fals and ay we haue good hope
It for to do and after it we grope
But that science is so fer vs beforn
We mowen not al though we had it sworn
It ouer take it flit awey so faste
It wol vs make beggars atte laste
Whyle this yeman was thus in his talkynge
This chanon drew hym nere and herd al thynge
Whiche this yeman spake / for suspecioy
Of mennys speche euer had this chanon
For caton sayth he that gylty is
Demyth al thyng to be spoke of hym ywys
That was the cause he gan so nygh drawe
To this yeman to herkyn al his sawe
And thus he sayde to his yeman tho
Holde thou thy pees and speke no wordys mo
For yf thou do thou shalt it dere abye
Thou sklaundrist me here in this companye
And eke discuueryst that thou sholdest hyde
Ye quod our hoost tel on what so betyde
Of al his thretynge recke thou not a myte
In feyth quod he nomore I do but a lyte
And when this chanon sawe it wold not be
But that his yeman wolde telle his pryuyte
He fled awey for verry sorowe ⁊ shame
A ha quod the yeman here shal ryse a game
Al that I can anon I wyl you telle
Syn he is goon the foule fende hym quelle
For neuer here after wyl I with hym mete
For peny ne for pound I you byhete
He that me first brought to that game
Or that he dye sorowe haue he and shame
For it is ernest to me by my feyth
That fele y well what that ony man sayth
And yet for al my smert and al my greef
For al my sorowe labour and myschyef
I coude neuer leue it in no wyse
Now wolde to god my wyt myght suffyce
To tellyn al that longyth to that art
But netheles you wyl I telle a part
Syn that my lorde is goon I wol not spare
Suche thyng as I knowe I wyl declare

Here endyth the prologue
of the Chanons yeman

body.fw: The tale of the chanons yeman

div.l: And begynneth the tale
WIth this chanon I duellyd vij yere
And of his science am I neuer the nere
Al that I had I haue lost ther by
And god woot so haue mo than I
There as I was wont to be right fressh ⁊ gay
Of clothynge and of other good aray
Now may I were an hose vp on myn hed
And where my colour was both fressh ⁊ rede
Now it is wan and of a ledyn hewe
Who so it vsith sore shal he rewe
And of my swynk y blent is myn eye
Lo suche auauntage it is to multeplye
That slydyng science hath made me so bare
That I haue no good where that euer I fare
And yet I am endettid so sore therby
Of gold that I borowed trewly
div.fw: The tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: That whyle I lyue I shat it quyte neuer
Let euery man bewaar by me for euer
What maner man that casteth hym therto
Yf he contynue I holde his thrift y do
For helpe me god therby shal he not wynne
But enpeire his purs ⁊ make his witte thynne
And whan he thorou his madnes and folye
Hath lost his owen good thorou Iepardy
Than he excitith other folke therto
To lese her good as he hym self hath doo
For vnto wretchys Ioye it is and ese
To haue her felowis in peyne and disese
For thus was y onys lernyd of a clerke
Of that no charge I wyl speke of our werke
When we be there as we shal excercise
Our eluyssh craft we semyn wonder wyse
Our termys ben so clergyal and so queynte
I blowe the fyre tyl my herte feynte
What shold I telle eche proporcion
Of thynges whiche we werkyn vp on
As on v or vj vncis may wel be
Of syluer or somme other quentite
And besy me to telle yow the namys
Of orpement brent bonys Iren squamys
That in to powder grounde be ful smal
And in an erthen pot how put is al
And salt petir and also papyr
Beforn thyse powdrys that I speke of here
And wel y couerid with a lampe of glas
And of muche other thyng which that ther was
And of the pottis and glassis enlutynge
That of the eyer myght passe out no thyng
And of the fyre esy and smert also
Whiche that was made ⁊ of the care and woo
That we had in our mater sublymynge
And in a malgamynge and calcenynge
Ol quycsyluer y clepyd mercury crude
For al our slightis we cau not conclude
div.fw: The tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: Our orpement and sublymyd mercury
Our grounden litarge eke on the perfury
Of eche of theym of vncis a certeyn
Not helpyth vs our labour is in veyn
And eke our spiritis assencioun
Ne our maters that lyen al fix adoun
Mowe in our werkynge nothyng vs auaylle
For lost is al our labour and traueylle
And al the coste a twenty deuyl wey
Is lost also whiche we on it leye
Ther is also ful many another thyng
That is to our craft apperteynyng
Though I by ordre hem reherce ne can
By cause that I am a lewd man
Yet wil I telle hem as they come to mynde
Though I ne can not sette them in her kynde
As bool Armonyak veerdegrece boras
And sondry vessellys made of erthe and glas
Our vrynalis and our descensories
Violis crossolettis and sublymatorijs
Concurbitees and Alembikis eke
And other suche dere ynow a leek
Not nedith it to reherce hem alle
Watirs rubyfyyng and boles galle
Arsenyk sal armonyak and brymstone
And erbys eke coude I telle many one
As egremoigne valerian and lunarye
And other suche yf that me list to tarye
Our lampes brennyng nyght and day
To brynge aboute our craft yf we may
Our furneys eke of calcinacion
And of watirs albyficacion
Vnsleclyd lyme chalk gleyr of an eye
Powdris dyuerse asshis dong pis and cleye
Seryd pottis salt petir vitriole
And dyuers fyris made of wode and cole
Sal tartir alcoly and sal preparat
And combust maters and coagulat
div.fw: The Tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: Cley maad with hors donge mānnys heer or oyle
Of tartre alym glas berme worte ⁊ argule
Rosealgar ⁊ other maters enbibynge
And eke of our maters encorporynge
And of our siluer cytrynacion
Our sementynge ⁊ also fermentacion
Our Ingottis testes and many mo
I wyl you telle as me was taught also
The iiij spiritis and the bodyes vij
By order as I herde my lord neueyn
The first spirite quycsiluer clepyd is
The second orpement the thridde ywis
Sal armonyak ⁊ the fourth brymstone
The bodyes seuyn loke hem here anon
Sol gold is / ⁊ luna siluer we threpe
Mars Iren Mercury quycsiluer we clepe
Saturnus led and Iubiter is tyn
And venus copyr by my fader kyn
This cursid craft who wol excercise
He shal no good haue that hym may suffyse
For al the good he spendith ther aboute
He lese shal therof haue I no doute
Who so that listeth vtter his folye
Let hym come forth ⁊ lerne to multiplye
And euery man that hath ought in his cofre
Let hym apere ⁊ wexe a philosophyr
Preest or chanon or ony other wight
Though he sitte at his book day and nyght
In lernynge of this eluyssh nyce lore
Alle is in veyn and parde mochil more
Is to lerne a lewd man this subtilte
Fy speke not therof it wol not be
And can he lettrure or can he non
As in effect he shal fynde it allone
For bothe two by my sauacion
Concludyn in multiplicacion
Al liche weel when they haue al y do
This is to sayn they faylen bothe two
div.fw: The Tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: Yet forgat I to make rehersayll
Of watris corosif and of lymayl
And of bodijs mollificacion
And also of her enduracion
Oylis ablacions metall fusibyl
To telle you al it wold passe ony bibyl
That owhere is therfore as for the best
Of thyse namys now wol I me reste
For as I trowe I haue told y nowe
To reyse a fende al loke he neuer so rowe
A nay let be the philosophris stoon
Elixer we clepyn we sekyn fast e hoon
For had we hym than were we sikir y nowe
But vnto god of heuyn I make auowe
For al our craft when we haue al y do
And al our sleyghte he wyl not come vs to
He hath maad vs spende muche good
For sorow therof almost we wexen wood
But that good hope crepyth in our herte
Supposyng euer though we sore smerte
To be releuyd by hym afterwarde
Suche supposynge and hope is sharpe ⁊ harde
I warne you wel it is to seken euyr
That future temps hath made men disseuer
In trust therof al that euer they had
Yet of that art they konne not wexe sad
For vnto hem it is a bitter swete
So semyth it for ne had they but a shete
Whiche that myght wrappyn hem ynne a nyght
And a brate to walkyn ynne by day light
They wolde it selle ⁊ spende it in this craft
They can not stynte tyl nothyng be laft
And euer more where euyr that they goon
Men may hem kenne by smel of brymstoon
For al the world they stynkyn as a goot
Her sauour is so rammyssh ⁊ so hoot
That though a man a myle from hem be
The sauour wol enfect hem trustyth me
div.fw: The Tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: Lo thus by smellyng ⁊ thredbare aray
If that men list thyse folke knowe they may
And yf a man wol axe hem pryuely
Why they be clothyd so vnthriftely
Right anon they wol roune in his ere
And sayen yf that they aspyed were
Men wolde hem sle by cause of her science
Lo thus thyse folke betrayen Innocence
Pas ouer this I goo my tale vnto
Er that the pot be on the fyre y do
And metallys a certeyn quantite
My lord hem temprith ⁊ noman but he
Now is he goon I dar say boldely
For as men say he can do craftely
Algate I woot wel he hath suche a name
And yet ful oft he renneth in the blame
And wyte ye how ful ofte it farith so
The pot to brekyth ⁊ farewel al is do
The metallys ben of so grete violence
Our wallys mowe not make hem resistence
But yf they were wrought of lyme ⁊ stoon
They persyn so ⁊ thorow the wal they goon
And som of hem synke doun in to the grounde
Thus haue we lost by tyme many a pounde
And somme ar skaterid al the floor aboute
Somme lepyn in to the roof withouten doute
Though þt the fend in our sight hym not shewe
I trow that he with vs be that ilke shrewe
In helle where he is lord and sire
Ne is ther more woo ne rancour ne Ire
Whan that our pot is broken as I haue sayd
Euery man chyt ⁊ holdyth hym euyl apayd
Somme sayd it was of the fyre makynge
Some sayde nay it was of the blowynge
Than was I ferd for that was myn offyce
Straw quod the thyrde ye be lewd and nyce
It was not temprid as it ought to be
Nay quod the fourth stynte ⁊ herkenyth me
div.fw: The tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: By cause our fyre was not maad of beche
What is the cause ⁊ other none sitheche
I can not telle where on it was a longe
But wel I woot grete stryf is vs amonge
What qd my lord there is no more to doon
Of these parellys I wyl be waar eftsoon
I am right siker that the pot was crasid
Be as be may be ye not amasid
As vsage is let swepe the floor swithe
Pluk vp your hertes ⁊ be glad and blithe
The mullok on an hepe swepyd was
And on the floor cast a canuas
And al the mullok in a side y throwe
And siftid and pikyd many a throwe
Parde qd one somwhat of our metal
Yet is ther here though we haue not al
And though this thyng myshappid hath as now
Another tyme it may be wel ynow
We must put our good in auenture
A marchaunt parde may not ay endure
Tristith me wel in his prosperite
Somtyme his goodis ben drenchid in the see
And som tyme it comyth sauf vnto londe
Pes qd my lord the nexte tyme I wyl fonde
To brynge our craft al in another plyte
And but I doo sirs let me haue the wyte
Ther was a defaute in somwhat wel I woot
Another sayde the fyre was ouer hoot
But be it hoot or colde I dar say this
That we concluden euer more amys
We faylen alway of that we woldyn haue
And in our madnes euer more we raue
And whan we be to gyder euerichone
Euery man semyth as wyse as salamon
But al thyng whiche that shyneth as gold
It is no gold as I haue herd told
Ne euery appyl that is fayr at eye
Nys not good what so we clappe or crye
div.fw: The Tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: Right so it farith amongis vs
He that semyth wysest by swete Ihesus
Is most fool when it comyth to the preef
And he that semyth trewist is a theef
That shal ye knowe or that I from you wende
Be that my tale be told vnto an ende
There was a chanon of relygyon

div.l: Than why shold the remenaunt haue a blame

Saue only thys yf ye wyl herkyn me
If ony Iudas in your couent be
Remeuyth hym betymes I you rede
Yf shame or los may causyn ony drede
And be no thyng displesid I you pray

IN london was a preest annueler
That therin had duelt many a yeer
Whiche was so plesaunt ⁊ so seruysable
Vnto the wyf where he was at table
That she wolde suffre hym no thyng to pay

div.l: To suche a man I can not sey nay
What qd this chanon shold I be vntrew

Trouth is a thynge that I wol euer kepe
In to that day in whiche I shal crepe
In to my graue or ellys crist forbede
Beleuyth this as sikir as the crede
God I thanke ⁊ in good tyme be it sayd

Ne neuer falshede in my herte I mente
And sir quod he now of my pryuyte
Syn ye so goodliche haue be to me
And kidyth to me so grete gentilnes
Somwhat to quyte with your kyndenes
I wyl you shew yf that ye list here
I wyl you teche plener the matere
How I can werkyn in philosophye
Take good hede ye shul wel seen at eye
That I wyl a mastrye do or I goo
Ye sir quod the preest ⁊ wol ye soo
Mary therof I pray you hertely
At your commaundement sir trewly
Quod the chanon ⁊ ellys crist forbede
Lo how this theef coude his seruyse bede
Ful soth it is that suche profrid seruyse
Stynketh as witnesseth the olde wyse
And that right sone I wol it verifye
In this chanon rote of al trecherye
That euer more delyte hath ⁊ gladnes

O sely preest o sely Innocent

div.fw: The tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: No thyng art thou ware of his disceyt
Whiche that this fox shapen hath to the
His wylys his wrenchis thou mayst not fle
Wherfore to go to the conclusion
That referryth to thy confusion
Vnhappy man anon I wyl me hye
To tellyn thyn vnwyt ⁊ thy folye
And eke the falsnes of that other wretche
As ferforth as my connynge wol stretche
This chanon was my lord ye wolde wene
Syr hoost in feyth ⁊ by heuens quene
It was another chanon and not he

He hath betrayed folk many a tyme
Of his falsnes it dullyth me to ryme
Euer whan I speke of his falshede
For shame of hym my chekis wexen rede
Algatis they begynnen for to glowe
For reednes haue I non right wel I knowe
In my vysage for fumes dyuerce
Of metal whiche ye haue herd me reherce
Consumed ⁊ wastid hath my reednes
Now takith hede of this chanons cursidnes
Sir quod he to the preest lete your man goon
For quycsiluer that we hadde it anon
And lete hym brynge vncis two or thre
And when he comyth as fast ye shul see
A wonder thyng whiche ye sawe nener or this
Syr qd the preest it shal be doo ywys
He bad his seruaunt fet hym this thynge

And went hym forth ⁊ cam anon agayn
With this quycsiluer shortly for to seyn
And took the vncis thre to the chanon

The colys right anon were y fet
div.fw: The Tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: And this chanon took out a crosselet
Of his bosom ⁊ shewde it to the preest
This instrument quod he whiche that thou seest
Take in thy hond ⁊ put thy self therin
Of this quycsiluer an vnce and begyn
In the name of crist to wexe a phylosophyr
Ther be ful fewe whiche I wolde it profre
To shewe hem thus muche of my science
For here shul ye see by experience
That this quycsyluer I wol mortifye
Right in your sight anon withouten lye
And make it as good syluer and as fyn
As there is ony in your purs or myn
Or ellys where and make it mallyable
And ellis hold me fals and vnstable
Amongis folk for euer to apere
I haue a poudre that cost me dere
Shal make alle good for it is cause of alle
My connynge whiche I you shewe shalle
Voydith your man ⁊ lete hym be withoute
And shit the dore whylis we be there aboute
Our pryuyte that no man vs aspye
Whylis that we worke in this phylosophye
Al as he bad fulfilled was in dede
This ylke seruaunt anon out yede
And his maystyr shytte the dore anon
And to her labour spedely they goon
This preest at this cursid chanons byddyng
Vp on the fyre right anon set thys thyng
And blew the fyre and bysied hym ful faste
And this chanon in to the crosselet caste
A powder not I neuer where of it was

To blynde with this preest ⁊ bad hym hye

For in tokenyng that I the loue

div.fw: The tale of the chanons yeman
div.l: Shal werke al thyng that here shal be do
Graunt mercy qd the preest ⁊ was right glad

Til he had ternyd hym he coude not twynne

Of his falshede fayn wolde I me wreke
Yf I wyst how but he is here and there
He is so varyaunt he abydeth nowhere

He took his cole of whiche I spake aboue

And whilis this preest couchyd besily
The colis as I you tolde or this
This chanon sayde frende ye doo amys

Ye be right hoot I see how ye swete

div.l: Now yeue vs drynke quod the chanon thenne

And whan this alkamystre saw his tyme
Ryse vp sir preest he sayd anon ⁊ stond byme
And for I woot wel yngot haue ye non

And brynge eke wyth you a bolle or a panne
Ful of water ⁊ ye shul wel se thanne
How that our besynes shal thryue and preue
And yet for ye shal haue no mysbeleue
Ne wrong conceyt of me in your absence
I wyl not be out of your presence
But go wyth you ⁊ come with you agayn
The chambyr dore shortly for to seyn
They openyd ⁊ shyt ⁊ went her wey

He took the chalk and shoop it in wyse

This disciplyne and this crafty science

div.l: Ne lady lustyer in carolynge

What shal this receyt coste tel me now

I warne you wel that saue I ⁊ a frere

This preest the summe of xl pound anone

div.l:
And begynneth the tale of
the doctour of phisik
THer was as tellyth titus liuyus
A knyght that clepid was virginius
Fulfilled of honour ⁊ of worthynes
And stronge of frendys and of ryches
A doughter had this knyght by his wyf
No children had he mo in al his lyf
Fayr was this mayde of excellent beaute
Abouen euery wyghte that men myght see
For nature hath with souereyn dilygence
Fourmed her in so grete excellence
As though she wolde say lo I nature
Thus can I fourme and peynte a creature
Whan that me list who can me counterfete
