div.fw: The Tale of the doctour of physyk
div.l: Appelles zanzis sholde wirche in veyn
To graue or peynte or forge or bete
If they presumyd me to counterfete
For he that is the fourmour pryncipal
Hath maad me his vicair general
To fourme ⁊ peynte erthly creatures
Right as me list for al thyng in my cure is
Vnder the mone that may wane and wexe
And for my werk no thyng wol I axe
My lorde and I be fully of accorde
I made here to the worshyp of my lorde
So do I al myn other creaturis
Of what colours they be or what figuris
Thus semyth me that nature wold seye
This mayde was of xij yere age and tweye
In whiche that nature had suche delyt
For right as he can peynte a lyly whyt
And rody as a rose with suche peynture
She peyntid hath this nobyl creature
Er she was born vpon her lymys fre
Where as by right suche colouris shold be
And phebus died had her tressis grete
Lyke to the stremys of his burnyd hete
And yf that excellent was her beaute
A thousand fold more vertuous was she
In her ne lackith no condicion
That is to preyse as by discrecion
As wel in body as ghoost chast was she
For Whiche she flourid in virgynyte
With al humylite and abstynence
With al atemperaunce and pacience
With mesure eke and beryng of aray
Discrete she was in answerynge alwey
She was as wyse as pallas dare I seyn
Her facunde eke ful womanly and pleyn
None counterfetid termys had she
To seme wyse but after her degre
She spake ⁊ al her wordes more and les
div.fw: The tale of the doctour of physyk
div.l: Sownynge in vertu and in gentilnes
Shamefast she was in maydens shamefastnes
Constant in herte and euer in besynes
To dryue her out of ydle slogardrye
Bacus had of her mouth right no maistrye
For wyne ⁊ yougthe doth venus encrece
As men in fyre wyl cast oyle or grece
And of her owen vertu vnconstreyned
She hath ful ofte tymes her syke feynyd
For that she wold fle the companye
Where likly was to treten of foly
As is at festis reuellis and daunsis
That been occasions of daliauncis
Suche thyngis make chyldren for to be
To sone rype and bolde as men may see
Whiche is ful parlous and hath be yore
For al to sone may she lerne lore
Of boldnes when she is wexen a wyf
And ye maistressys in your olde lyf
That lordis doughtris hauen in gouernaunce
Ne takith of my wordis no displesaunce
Thynke that ye ben set in gouernyngys
Of lordis doughters only for two thyngis
Eyther for ye haue kept your honeste
Or ellis ye haue fallen in freelte
And knoWe wel ynow the olde daunce
And han forsake fully myschaunce
For euermore / therfore for cristys sake
To teche hem vertu loke that ye not slake
A theef of venyson that hath forlafte
His licorousnesse ⁊ al his olde crafte
Can kepe a forest best of ony man
Now kepe hem wel for and ye wyl ye can
Loketh wel to no vyce that ye assente
Lest ye dampnyd be for your euyl entente
For who so doth a treytour is certeyn
And takith hede of that I shal seyn
Of al treson souereyn pestylence
div.fw: The Tale of the doctour of physyk
div.l: Is when a wyght betrayeth Innocence
Ye fadris ⁊ ye modris eke also
Though ye haue chyldren be it one or moo
Your is the charge of al her surueyaunce
Whiles they ben vnder your gouernaunce
Be waar yf by ensaumplis of your lyuynge
Or by your necligence in chastysynge
That they ne peryssh for I dar wel seye
If that they do ye shul it dere abeye
Vnder a shepherde softe ⁊ neglygent
The wolf hath many a sheep ⁊ lambe to rent
Suffisith ensaumplis y now as here
For I must turne ayen to my matere
This mayde of whiche I telle expres
She kepte her self she nedyd no maystres
For in her lyuynge maydens myght rede
As in a book euery good word in dede
That longyth to a mayde vertuous
She was so prudent ⁊ so bounteous
For whiche the fame out sprong on euery syde
Bothe of her bounte ⁊ of her beaute wyde
That thorow the lond they preysen hir echone
That loued vertu saue enuye alone
That sory is of other mennys weel
And glad is of his sorow and vnhele
This doctour makith this discripsion
This mayde on a day went in to the toun
Toward the tempyl with her moder dere
As is of yonge maydens the manere
Now was ther a Iustyce in the toun
That gouernour was of that regyoun
And so befyl this Iuge his eyen caste
Vp on this mayde auysyng her ful faste
As she cam forth by there the Iuge stood
Anone his herte chaungyd and his mood
So was he caught with beaute of this mayde
And to hym self ful pryuyly he sayde
This mayde shal be myn for ony man
div.fw: The tale of the doctour of physyk
div.l: Anone the fend in to his herte ran
And taughte hym sodenly by what sleighte
The mayden to his purpos wynne he myghte
For certes by no force ne by no mede
Hym thought he was not abyl for to spede
For she was stronge of frendis and eke she
Confermyd was in suche souereyn beaute
That wel he wyst he myght hir not wynne
As for to make her with her body to synne
For whiche with grete delyberacion
He sent after a chorle was in the toun
The whiche he knew ful subtil and ful bolde
This Iuge vnto this chorle this tale hath tolde
In secret wyse and made hym to assure
He shold telle it to no creature
And yf he dede he shold lese his hede
When assentid was this cursid dede
Glad was the Iuge ⁊ made glad chere
And yaf hym yeftes precious and dere
When shapen was al this conspirasye
From poynt to poynt how that his lecherye
Parfourmyd shold be ful subtilly
As ye shullyn here it after openly
Hoom goon this chorle that highte claudyus
This fals Iuge that hyghte appius
So was his name for it is no fabyl
But knowen for an historial thyng notabyl
The sentence of it soth is out of doute
This fals Iuge goth now faste aboute
To hastyn his delyte alle that he may
And so befyl sone after on a day
This fals Iuge as tellyth vs the storye
As he was wont sat in his consistorye
And yaf his domys vpon sondry caas
This fals chorle cam forth a ful grete paas
And sayde lord yf it be your wylle
As doth me right vpon my pytous bylle
In whiche I pleyne vp on virginius
div.fw: The Tale of the doctour of physyk
div.l: And yf he wyl sey it is not thus
I wyl preue it and fynde good wytnes
That soth is that my byll wol expres
The Iuge answeryd of this in his absence
I may not yeue diffinyte sentence
Lete do calle hym ⁊ I wol gladly here
Thou shalt haue right ⁊ no wrong here
Virginius cam to here the Iustyces wyll
Aud right anone was red this cursid bill
The sentence was therof as ye shul here
To you my lord Appius so dere
Shewith your poure seruaunt Claudius
How that a knyght callyd virginius
Ayenst the lawe ⁊ ayenst al equyte
Holdith expres ayenst the wyl of me
My seruaunt which that is my thralle by right
Which from myn hous was stolyn on an nyght
Whilis she was ful yonge I wol it preue
By witnes lord so that ye not greue
She nys not his doughter what so he say
Wherfore my lord Iustyce I you pray
Yelde me my thral yf it be your wylle
Lo this was al the sentence of his bylle
Virginius gan vpon the chorle beholde
But hastely or he his tale tolde
He wolde a defendid it as shold a knyght
And by witnes of many a trewe wight
That al was fals that sayde his aduersary
This cursid Iuge wolde no lenger tary
Ne here a worde more of virginius
But yaf his Iugement ⁊ sayd thus
I deme anone this chorl his seruaunt haue
Thou shalt no lenger in thy hous her saue
Go set her forth ⁊ put her in our warde
This chorle shal haue his thral thus I a warde
And when this worthy knyght virginius
Thorow sentence of the Iuge apius
Must by force his dere doughter yeuyn
div.fw: The tale of the doctour of physyk
div.l: Vnto the Iuge in lechery to lyuyn
He goth hym hoom ⁊ set hym in his halle
And lete anone his dere doughter calle
And with a face ded as asshis colde
Vp on her humbyl face he gan beholde
With faders pite stickyng thorow his herte
Al wol he not from his purpos conuerte
Doughter quod he virginea by thy name
Ther ben two weyys other deth or shame
That thou must suffre allas that I was bore
For neuer thou deseruest wherfore
To dien with a swerde or with a knyf
O dere doughter whiche that al my lyf
I haue fostrid vp with suche plesaunce
That thou ne were out of my remembraunce
O doughter whiche that art my last wo
And in my lif my laste ioye also
O gemme of chastyte in pacience
Take thou thy deth for this is my sentence
For loue ⁊ not for hate thou must be ded
My pytous hond must smyte of thy hed
Allas that euer apius the say
Thus hath he Iuged the to day
And tolde her all the caas as ye before
Haue herd it nedyth to telle no more
O mercy dere fader quod the mayde
And with that worde she both her armys leyde
Aboute his necke as she was wont to do
The teris brast out of her eyen two
And sayd good fader shalle I dye
Is ther no grace is ther no remedye
No certes dere doughter myn quod he
Than yeue me leyser fader myn quod she
My deth to compleyne a litil space
For parde Iepte yaf his doughter grace
For to compleyne or he her slow allas
And god it woot no thyng was her trespas
But that she ran her fader for to see
div.fw: The Tale of the doctour of physyk
div.l: To welcome hym with grete solempnyte
And with that worde she fyl a swoune anoon
And after whan her swouuyng was a goon
She risith vp and to her fader sayde
Blissyd be god that I shal dye a mayde
Yef me my deth or that I haue a shame
Doth with your child your wil a goddis name
And with that worde she prayeth ful ofte
That with his swerde he shold smyte softe
And with that worde a swoune doun she fyl
Her fader with sorouful herte and wyl
Her heed of smote and by the top it hent
And to the Iuge he yaf it in present
As he sat yet in dome in consistory
When that the Iuge it saw as saith the story
He bad take hym ⁊ hange hym al so faste
But right anone al the pepyl in thraste
To saue the knyght for routhe and for pyte
For knowen was the fals iniquyte
The pepyl anone had suspect in this thyng
By maner of this chorlis chalengyng
That it was by assent of appius
They wyst wel that he was lecherous
Forthwyth vnto this appius they goon
And cast hym in prison and that anon
Where as he slow hym self and Claudius
That seruaunt was vnto thys appius
Was demyd for to be hongid vpon a tre
But virginius of his grete pyte
So prayde for hym that he was exylid
And ellis certes had he be begilid
The remenaunt were hongyd both more ⁊ lesse
That consentyd were to this cursidnes
Here may men see how synne hath his merite
Be ware for noman woot how god wol smyte
In no degre ne in no maner wyse
The worm of conscience may ynowgh agryse
Of wicked lyf though it so pryuy be
That no man woot of but god and he
Whethyr that he be lewde man or leryd
He noot how sone he may be a ferid
Therfore I rede yow this counceyl take
Forsake synne or synnne you forsake
Here endyth the Phisicions tale /

And here begynneth the wordes
Of the Hoost
OVr hoost gan swere as he wer wood
Harow qd he by naylis and by blood
This was a fals thef a cursid Iustyse
As shameful deth as herte can deuyse
Come to thise fals Iuges ⁊ her aduocats
Allas this sely mayde is sleyn allas
Allas to dere a boughte she her beaute
Wherfore I say that al men mow see
That yeftes of fortune and of nature
Ben cause of deth of many a creature
Her beaute was her deth I dar wel sayn
Allas so pytously as she was slayn
But here of wol I not procede as now
Men haue ful ofte more harme than prow
But trewly myn owen maister dere
This is a pitous tale for to here
But netheles passe ouer is no force
I pray to god so saue thy gentil corps
And thyn vrynals and thy Iourdens
Thyn ypocras ⁊ thy galiens
And euery boyst ful of letuary
God blisse hem ⁊ our lady saynt mary
So mote I the thou art a propir man
And like a prelat by saynt damyan
Thou hast spoke ynough I can not sey in terme
But wel I wote thou makist my herte to erne
That I almoste haue caught a cardiakyl
By corpus dominus but yf I haue triakyl
Or ellys a draughte of corny moysty ale
Or but I here anon a mery tale
My herte is lost for pyte of this mayde
Thou belamy thou Iohn pardoner he sayde
Tel vs sum myrthys or Iapys right anon
It shal be do he sayde by seynt Runyon
But first quod he here at this ale stake
I wyl bothe drynke and ete of a Cake
But right anone thyse gentils began to crye
Nay let hym telle vs of no rebaudrye
Tel vs sum moral thyng that we mowe lere
Som wyt ⁊ than wol we gladly here
I graunte ywys quod he but I must thynke
Vp on sum honest thynge whilis that I drynke
Here endeth the wordes of the hoost
And begynneth the pardoners prologue
LOrdynges qd he in chirchis when I preche
I peyne me to haue an haunten speche
And rynge it out as rounde as goth a belle
For I can by rote al that I telle
My teme is euer one and alway was
Radix malorum est cupiditas
First I pronounce whens that I come
And than my billis shewe I al ⁊ somme
Our liege lordis seal on my patent
That shewe I first my body to warent
That no man be so bolde ne preest ne clerk
Me to distourbe of cristis holy werk
And after that telle I forth my talis
Bullis of popis and of cardynalis
Of patriarkis ⁊ bisshoppis I shewe
And in latyn I speke wordes a fewe
To saffron with my predycacion
And for to stere men to deuocion
Thenne shewe I forth my longe cristal stonys
I crammyd in cloutis ful of bonys
Relykes they ben as wenen they echon
Than haue I in laton a sholder boon
Whiche that was of an holy iewis shepe
Good men say I take of my wordes keep
If that this boon be wasshe in ony welle
Yf kow or calf sheep or oxe swelle
That ony worm hath ete or hym stonge
Take water of this welle ⁊ wasshe his tunge
And it is hool anon / and ferthermore
Of pockis ⁊ of scabbis and euery sore
Shal euery sheep be hool that of this welle
Drynketh a draughte take kepe of that I telle
Yf that the good man that the bestys oweth
Wol euery weke or that the cok croweth
Fastynge drynke of this welle a draughte
As that holy Iewe our elders taughte
His bestys ⁊ his stoor shal multeplye
And sirys also it heleth ielousie
And though a man be falle in gelous rage
Let make with this water his potage
And neuer shal he more his wyf mystriste
Though he in soth the defaute by her wyste
Al had she take prestys two or thre
Here is a metayn eke that ye may see
He that his hond wol put in that meteyn
He shal haue multiplyyng of his greyn
Whan he hath sowen be it whete or otys
So that he offre pens or ellys grotis
Good men ⁊ women o thyng warne I yow
If ony wyght be in this chirche now
That hath don synne so orryble that he
Dar not for shame shryuen be
Or ony woman be she yonge or olde
That hath y maad her husbond Cokeolde
Suche folke shal haue no power ne grace
To offir to my relikes in this place
And who so fyndeth hym out of suche blame
Comyth vp and offyr in goddis name
And I assoyle hem by the auctoryte
Suche as by bull was grauntid to me
By this gaude haue I wonne many a yeer
An hundred mark syn I was pardoner
I stonde lyke a clerke in my pulpet
And whan lewd pepyl be doun y set
I preche so as ye haue herd before
And telle an hundred fals Iapis more
Than peyne I me to stretche forth myn necke
And est and west vpon the pepyl I becke
As doth a dowue sittynge vpon a berne
Myn hondis and my tunge goon so yerne
That it is ioye to see my besynes
Of auarice and of suche cursidnes
Is al my prechynge to make hem fre
To yeue her pens and namely vnto me
For myn entent is not but for to wynne
And nothyng for correction of synne
I recke not when that they be beryed
Though her soulis goon a blakeberied
For certes ful many a predycacion
Sownyth ofte tyme of euyl entencion
Somme for plesaunce of folk and for flaterye
To ben auaunsid by ypocrisie
And som for veynglorye ⁊ som for hate
For when I dar not other weyes debate
Than wol I stynge hem with my tonge smerte
In prechynge so that they shul not asterte
To ben diffamed falsly yf that he
Hath trespassid othir to my bretheryn or me
For though I telle not his proper name
Men shal wel knowe that it is the same
By sygnes or by other circumstauncis
Thus quyte I folke that doth vs displesancis
Thus spyt I out my venym vnder hewe
Of holynes to seme holy and trewe
But shortly myn entent I wol deuyse
I preche of no thynge but of couetyse
Therfore my teme is yet and euer was
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
Thus gan I preche the same vyce
To suche as be vsyng the synne of auarice
But though my self be gilty in that synne
Yet can I make other folke to twynne
From auarice / ⁊ sore hem to repente
But that is not my pryncipal entente
I preche no thyng but for couetyse
Of this mater it ought y now suffyse
Than telle I hem ensaumplis many oon
Of olde stories longe tyme agoon
For lewd pepyl louyn talis olde
Whiche thyngis can they weel reporte ⁊ holde
What trowe ye whilis that I may preche
And for to wynne gold ⁊ siluer for to teche
That I wyl lyue in pouert wylfully
Nay nay I thought it neuer trewly
For I wol preche ⁊ begge in sondry londis
I wil not doo no labour with my hondis
Ne maken baskettis ⁊ lyue therby
By cause I wol not begge Idelly
I wyl none of the appostlis countirfete
I wyl haue money / wulle chese and whete
Al were it yeuen of the pourest page
Or of the pourest wydow in a village
Al shold her children sterue for famyn
Nay I wol drynke the licour of the vyn
And haue a Ioly wenche in euery toun
But herkenyth lordyngis in conclusioun
Your lykyng is that I shal telle a tale
Now I haue dronke a draughte of corny ale
By god I hope I shal telle you a thyng
That shal by reson be at your lykyng
For though my self be a ful vicious man
A moralle tale yet I you telle can
Whiche I am wont for to preche and also wynne
Now holde your pees my tale I wol begynne

Here endyth the prologue
Of the Pardoner
And begynneth the Tale
IN flaundris sumtyme was a companye
Of yonge folke that hauntedyn folye
As ryot hazard Stewys and tauarnys
Where as wyth harpes lutes and gyternes
They daunce and pleye at the dyce both day ⁊ nyght
And etyn also ⁊ drynkyn aboue her myght
Thorow whiche they doon the deuyl sacrifise
Wyth ynne the deuyls tempyl in cursid wyse
The superfluytees abhomynabyl
Her othys be so grete ⁊ so dampnabyl
That it is grisly for to here hem swere
Our blissyd lordis body they to tere
Hem thought the Iewys rente hym not ynough
And eche of hem at other synne lough
And right anone cam in the tomblesteris
Fetis and smale and yong frutestris
Syngars with harpys Bawdis wafreris
Suche as ben verry the deuyllis offyceris
To kyndyl ⁊ blowe the firis of lecherye
That is annexyd vnto glotonye
The holy writte take I to wytnesse
That lechery is in wyne and in dronkenesse
Lo how that dronkyn loth vnkyndely
Lay by his doughtris two vnwetyngly
So dronke he was he nyste what he wroughte
And therfore sore repente hym oughte
Herodis who so wol the storyes seche
There may ye lerne ⁊ by ensaumpyl teche
Whan he of wyne was repleet at his feste
Right at his owen tabyl yaf his heste
To slee the baptist Iohn ful gyltlees
Senek saith eke good wordis doutles
He sayth he can no difference fynde
Betwyx a man that is oute of his mynde
And a man whiche that is dronkelew
But that woodnes fallyn is in a shrew
Perseuerith lenger than doth dronkenes
Out glotonye ful of cursidnes
O cause first of our confusyon
O origynal synne of our dampnacion
Tyl crist had boughte vs with his blood ageyn
Lo how dere shortly for to seyn
A bought was this cursid vilonye
Corupt was al this world thorou glotonye
Adam our forn fader and his wyf also
Fro paradys to labour and to woo
Were dryuen for that vice it is no drede
For whilis that Adam fastyd as I rede
He was in paradise ⁊ whan that he
Ete of the frut defendyd on the tre
Anon he was out cast to woo and peyne
O glotonye on the oughte vs wel to pleyne
O wyste a man how many maladies
Folowen of excesse and of glotonyes
He shold be the more mesurabil
Of his diete sittyng at his tabyl
Allas the shorte throte the tendyr mouth
Makith that est ⁊ west north and south
In erthe in eyr in watir men to swynke
To gete a gloton deynte mete and drynke
O poule of this mater wel canst thou entrete
Mete vnto wombe ⁊ wombe eke vnto mete
Shal god destroyen bothe as poule sayth
Allas a foul thyng it is by my feyth
To say this worde ⁊ foulir is the dede
When men so drynketh of the whyte ⁊ rede
That of his throte he makyth his pryue
Thorow that cursid superfluyte
The apostyl wepynge sayth ful pytously
Ther walkyn meny of whiche you told haue I
I say it now wepynge wyth pitous vois
That they ben enemyes of cristys crois
Of whiche the ende is deth wombe is her god
O wombe o bely o stynkynge cod
Fulfilled of dung and of corupcion
At eyther ende of the foul is the soun
How grete cost ⁊ labour is the to fynde
Thyse cookis how they stampe streyne ⁊ grynde
And turne substaunce in to accident
To fulfille al thy licorous talent
Out of the harde bonys knockyn they
The mary for they caste naught awey
That may go thorow the golet softe and sote
Of spycery of leuys barke and rote
Shal be his sause y made by delyte
To make hym yet a newer appetyte
But certes he that haunteth suche delicis
Is ded whilis that he liuyth in the vicis
A lecherous thynge is wyne and dronkenesse
Is ful of stryuyng and of wretchydnesse
O dronken man disfiguryd in thy face
Sour is thy breth foul art thou to embrace
And thorow thy drōmkyn nose sownyth thy soun
As though thou saydist ay sampson sampsoun
And yet god wot sampsōm drank neuer no wyn
Thou fallist as it were a styckyd swyn
Thy tonge is lost and al thyn honest cure
For dronkenes is verry sepulture
Of mannys wyt and his discrescion
In whom that drynke hath domynacion
He can no counsel kepe it is no drede
Now kepe you fro the whyte ⁊ fro the rede
Namely fro the whyte wyn of lepe
That is to selle in bridge strete or in chepe
Thys wyn of spayn crepyth subtilly
In other wynys growyng fast by
Of whiche ther risith suche fumosite
That when a man hath dronke draughtis thre
And wenyth that he be at home in chepe
He is in spayne right at the toune of lepe
Not at rochel ne at bordeux toun
And than wol he say sampsoun sampsoun
But herkenyth lordyngys o word I you pray
That al the souereyn actys dar I say
Of victories in the olde testament
Thorou very god that is omnypotent
Were doon in abstynence and in prayer
Lokith the bibyl and there ye mowe it lere
Lokyth attilla the grete conquerour
Deyed in his slepe with shame and dishonour
Bledynge ay at his nose in dronkenes
A capteyn shold lyue in sobyrnes
And ouer al this auyse you right weel
What was commaunded vnto lamuel
Not samuel but lamuel say I
Redith the bybyl and fynde it expresly
Of wyne yeuynge to hem that haue Iustyce
Nomore of this for it may wel suffyse
ANd now that I haue spoke of glotonye
Now wol I defende you hasardrye
Hasardrye is verry moder of lesyngys
And of disceyt and cursid forsweryngis
Blasphemye of crist manslaughtre ⁊ waste also
Of cateyl ⁊ of tyme ⁊ ferthermo
It is repreef ⁊ contrary of honour
For to be holden a Comune hasardour
And euer the hyer that he is in astat
The more he is holden desolate
If that a prynce vse hasardrye
In al gouernaunce ⁊ al polecye
He is as by comune oppynyon
Y holde the lasse in reputacion
Stillebone that was holde a wyse embassedour
Was sent in to Corynthe with grete honour
Fro calidone to make hem aliaunce
And whan he cam hym happid this chaunce
That al the grettest that were of that londe
Pleyynge atte hasarde he hem fonde
For whiche as sone as that it myghte be
He stale hym hoom ayen to his contre
And sayde there wyl I not lese my name
I wol not take on me so grete defame
You for to alye to noon hasardouris
Sendith other wyse ambassiadouris
For by my trouthe me were leuer dye
Than I you to hasardouris sholde alye
For ye that ben so glorious in honouris
Shal not a lye you to no hasardouris
As by my wylle ne as by my trete
This wyse phylosophir thus sayde he

And al was thnrough goddys grace
And thorough his fayr berynge
Ye listenyth lordyngs to my tale
Merier than the nyghtyngale
I wyl wyth you roune
How sir Thopas with sidys smale
Prickyng ouer hylle and dale
Is comyn agayn to toun
His mery men commaundith he
To maken hym bothe game and gle
For nedis must hym fighte
Wyth a geaunt wyth heedys thre
For paramour and Iolite
Of one that shoon so bright
Come doo he sayde my mynstralis
And gestours for to telle talis
Anone in myn armynge
Of romauncis that been ryal
Of popis and of cardynal
And eke of loue longyng
They set hym forth swete wyne
And mede in a masselyne
And ryal spyclory
Of gyngerbrede that was so fyn
And licorice and eke comyn
With sugir that is try
He dyd next his whyt lere
Of clothe a layke fyne and clere
A breche and eke a sherte
And next his sherte an haketon
And ouer that an halergeon
For persynge of his herte
And ouer that a fyn hauberk
Was al I wrought of Iuys werk
Ful stronge it was of plate
And ouer that his cote armure
As whyt as is a lily flour
In whiche he wol debate
His sheld was al of gold so reed
And therin was a boris heed
A charbokyl by his syde
And there he swore on ale and breed
How that the geaunt shal be ded
Betyde what may betyde
His Iambedeux were of quyreboly
His swerdis shethe of Iuory
His helme of latoun bright
His sadil was of rewelbone
His bridyl as the sonne shoon
Or as the mone light
His spere was of fyn Cypresse
That bedith werre ⁊ no thyng pees
The heed ful sharpe y grounde
His stede was al dappyl gray
It goth an ambyl in the way
Ful softely and rounde / In londe
Lo lordys myn here is o fyt
If ye wol ony more of it
To telle yet wyl I fonde
NOw holde your mouth pour charite
Bothe knyght and lady fre
And herkenyth to my spelle
Of batayle of chyualrye
And of ladyes loue drurye
Anon I wyl you telle
Men spekyn of romauncis of price
Of hornchyld and of Ipotise
Of beues and of sir Guy
Of sir libeux and of sir playndemour
But sir Thopas berith the flour
Of ryal chyualrye
His good stede al he bestrode
And forth vpon his wey he rode
As sparcle out of bronde
Vpon his crest he baar a tour
And therin stykyd a lily flour
God shylde his body from shonde
And for he was a knyght aunterous
He nolde slepyn in none hous
But liggen in his hood
His bright helm was his wonger
And by hym bayteth his destrer
Of herbys fyn and good
Hym self drank water of the welle
As dyd the knyght sir percyuelle
So worthyly vnder wede
The hoost Interrupteth his tale /
NO more of this for goddis dygnyte
For thou qd our hoost makist me
So wery of thy verry lewdnesse
That al so wys god my soule bles
Myn eris akyn of thy drafty speche
Now suche a ryme the deuyl I beteche
This may wel be a ryme dogerel qd he
Why so qd I why wolt thou let me
More of my tale than another man
Syn it is the beste ryme that I can
By god qd he ful playnly at o word
Thy drafty rymynge is not worth a tord
Thou dost nought ellis but spendyst tyme
Syr at o word thou shalt no lengyr ryme
Let se where thou canst aught telle in geste
Or tellen in prose somwhat atte leste
In which ther may be som myrthe or doctryne
Gladly qd he by goddys swete pyne
I wol you telle a litil thyng in prose
That oughte to lyke you as I suppose
Or ellis certeyn ye be to daungerous
It is a moral tale vertuous
Al be it tolde somtyme in sondry wyse
Of sondry folk as I shal you deuyse
And thus ye woot that euery euangelist
That telle vs the payne of Ihesu crist
Ne sayth not al thyng as his felow doth
But netheles her sentence is al soth
And al accordynge as in her sentence
Al be ther in her tellyng difference
For som of hem sayth more ⁊ som lesse
When they his pytous passyon expresse
I mene of mark Mathew Luke and Iohn
But doutles her sentence is al on
Therfore lordyngis I you beseche
If that ye thynke I vary in my speche
As thus though that I telle somdeel more
Of prouerbys than ye haue herd before
Comprehendyd in this litil tretys here
To enforce wyth the effect of my matere
And though I not the same wordes say
As ye haue herde yet to you alle I pray
Blameth me not for as in my senteuce
Shull ye nowhere fynde no difference
For the sentence of this trete lite
After the whiche mery tale this I write
And therfore harkenyth what I shal say
And lete me telle my tale I you pray

whyche is a vycyous lyuyng and
ought to be eschewed of euery good man /

For after the worde of
thapostle / Couetyse is the rote of al harmes /

And therfore hit
were better to yow to lese so moche good of your owen than for
to take of her good in thys manere /

For better it is to lese good
wyth worshyp / than it is to wynne good wyth vylonye and
shame /

And euery man ought to doo his dylygence and besynes
to gete hym a good name /

And yet shall he not hooly besye hym
in kepyng of his good name /

But he shal alleway enforcen
to do somme thyng by whiche he may renouele or renewe his good
name /

For it is wryton that the olde good loos of a man or
good name is sone goon and passid whan it is not newed ne
renouelyd /

And as touchyng that ye sayn / ye wol exyle your
aduersaries /

that thynketh me moche agayn reson and out of
mesure /

consyderyng the power that they haue yeue yow vpon
hem self /

And yet it is wryton that he is worthy to lese his pry -
uylege that mysuseth the myght and the power that is yeue hym

And I set caas that ye myght enioyne hem that payne by ryght
and by lawe /
whiche that I trowe ye may not doo /

I say ye
myght not put hit to excution / For parauenture

than were hit
like to retorne to the Warre as hit was before /

And therfore
yf ye wyl that men doo yow obeysaunce ye must demene yow
more curtoysly /

Thys is to saye ye must yeue more esy penaunce
and Iugement /

For it is wryton that he that most curteysly
commaundeth / to hym men moste obeye /

And therfore I praye
yow that in thys necessyte and in thys nede ye cast yow for to
ouercome your herte /

For Senek Sayth / he that ouercometh
hys herte / ouercometh twyes /

And Tullyus sayth / There is
nothyng so comendable in a grete lord

as whan he is debonayr
and meke / And appeesyth hym lightly /

And I praye yow
that ye wyl now forbere to doo vengeance

in suche a manere that
your good name may be kepte and conseruyd /

And that men may haue cause and mater to prayse yow
of pyte and of mercy /

And that ye haue no cause to repente
yow of thyng that is doon /

For Seneke sayth / He
ouercometh an euyll maner that repenteth hym of hys vyc -
torye /
Wherfore I praye yow lete mercy be in your herte /

To
theffect and to the entente that God almyghty haue mercy
The Tale of Chaucer
on yow in his last Iugement /

For saynt Iames sayth in hys
epystlis / Iugement wythout mercy shalle be doo to hym that hath
no mercy on an other wyght /

WHan Mellebee had herd the grete skylles and resons
of dame Prudence and her wyse Informations and te-
chynges

his herte began tenclyne to the wyll of hys
wyf consideryng her grete entente

conformed hym anon
and assented to werke after her counceyl /

And thanked god of
whom procedeth alle goodnes and vertue / that hym had sente a
wyf of so grete dyscrescion /

And whan the day cam that hys
aduersaryes shold appere in his presence /

He spack to hem ful
goodly and sayd in thys wyse /

Al be hit so that of your pryde
and presumption ⁊ hye foly of your neglygence and vnconnyng
ye haue mysborne yow and trespassyd vnto me /

yet for as my -
kil as I see your grete humylite

and that ye be sory ⁊ repentaunte
of your gyltes
hit constrayneth me to doo yow grace and mercy /
Wherfor I receyue yow to my grace

and foryeue you vtterly alle
the offences Iniuryes and wronges that ye haue don ayenst me
to thys effecte and to thys ende that / god of his endeles mercy

wyl at the day of my deyyng forgyue me my gyltes / that I
haue trespaced to hym in thys worlde /

For doubteles yf we be
sory and repentaunte for our synnes and gyltes / the sight of
our lord god
is so fre and so mercyable

that he wyl forgyue vs
our gyltes

and bryng vs to the blysse that neuer shalle haue
ende Amen /

Here endeth chaucers Tale of Mellebe and
Prudence hys wyf and sophye his doughter /

div.l: And begynneth the monkes prologue
WHenne ended was the tale of mellebe
and of prudence and of her benygnyte
Our host sayd as I am faithful man
and by the precious corps Madryan
I had leuer thenne a barel of ale
That good leef my wyf had herde thys tale
For she is nothyng of suche pacience
As was thys Mellebeus wyf Prudence
By goddes bones when I bete my knaues
She bryngeth me the grete clobbed stauys
And cryeth sle the doggys euerychone
And breke both bak and euery boon
And yf that ony neyghbour of myn
Wol not in chyrche to my wyf enclyn
Or be so hardy to her to trespas
Whan she cometh hom she rampeth in my face
And cryeth fals coward wreke thy wyf
By corpus dominus I wyl haue thy knyf
And thou shalt haue my dystaf ⁊ goo spynne
Fro day tyl nyght she wyl thus begynne
Alas she saith that euyr I was shape
To wedde a mylkesop a coward ape
That wol be ouerled wyth euery wyght
Thou darst not stonde by thy wyues ryght
This is my lif / but yf that I wold fyght
And out atte dore anon I moot me dyght
And ellys I am lost but yf that I
Be like a wylde lyon fool hardy
I woote wel she wyl do me slee som day
Som neyghbour and thenne goo my way
For I am parlous wyth knyf in honde
Al be hit that I dare not her wythstonde
For she is byg in armes by my fayth
That shal he fynde that her mysdoth or sayth
But lete vs passe awaye from thys matere The Prologue
My lord sir monke he sayd be mery of chere
For ye shull tellyn a tale truly
Lo rouchester stondeth here fast by
Ryde forth myn owen lorde breke not our game
But by my trouthe I knowe not your name
Whether shal I calle yow my lord dan Iohan
Or dan Thomas dan roberte or dan Albon
Or of what hows be ye by your fader kyn
I vowe to god thou hast a ful fayr chyn
It is a gentil pasture there thou goost
Thou art not like a penaunte or a goost
Vp on my feythe thou art som offycere
Som worthy sexten or som celerer
For by my fader soule as to my dome
Thou art a mayster whan thou arte at home
No pour cloysterer ne no pour nouice
But a gouernour wyly and wyse
And therwyth of brawn and of bonys
A wel faryng persone for the nonys
I praye to god yeue hym confusion
That fyrst the brought in to religyon
Thow woldest haue be a tredefoul a right
Haddist thou as grete leue as thou hast myght
To performe al thy lust in engendrure
Thou haddyst begoten many a creature
Allas why werest thou so wyde a cope
God yeue me sorowe and I were pope
Not only thou but euery myghty man
Though he were shore hyghe vp on his pan
Shold haue a wyf for al this world is lorn
Relygyon hath take vp alle the corne
Of tredyng and borel men be shrympes
Of febyl trees there cometh wretchyd ympes
This maketh that our heyres be so sklendir
And feble that they may not wel engendre
This maketh that our wyues wyl assaye
Religyous folke for they may better paye
Of venus payementis thenne mowe we The Prologue
God woot no lussheburghs paye ye
But be not wroth my lord though I playe
Ful ofte in game a soth haue I herd saye
This worthy monke toke alle in pacience
And sayd I wol doo my dylygence
As fer as sowneth in to honeste
To telle yow a tale or two or thre
And yf yow list to herken hiderwarde
I wol you sayn of the lyf of seynt Edwarde
Or ellys tragedyes fyrst I wyl telle
Of whiche I haue an hondred in my celle
Tragedy is for to telle a certayn storye
As olde bookys maken memorye
Of hem that stonden in grete prosperyte
And is falle out of hye degree
In to mysery and endyth wretchydly
And they been vercifyed comynly
Of / vj / feet whiche men clepen exametron
In prose eke ben endyted many on
And in metre many a sondry wyse
Lo thys ought ynough to suffyse
Now herkenyth yf yow lyst for to here
But fyrst I beseche you in thys matere
Though I by ordre telle not thise thyngis
Be hit of popes emperours or kyngis
And aftir her ages as men wryten fynde
But telle hem som byfore and som behynde
As it cometh to my remembraunce
Haue me excusid of myn ignoraunce
Here endyth the Monkis prologue
Here begynneth the Tale
I Wyl bewayle in maner of tragedye
The harme of hem that stōmden in hye degre
And fyllen so that there nas no remedye
To bryng hem out of her aduersyte
For certayn when that fortune lyst to fle
Ther may no man of her the cours wythholde
Late no man truste on blynde prosperyte
Beth ware by this ensampil yong and olde
At Lucifer though he an aungyl were
And not a man at hym I wyl begynne
For though fortune may not aungel dere
From hye degre yet fyl he for hys synne
Doun in to helle where he is yet ynne
O lucifer bryghtest of aungellys alle
Now art thou sathanas that mayst not twynne
Out of myserye whyche thou art falle
Lo Adam in the felde of damascene
Wyth goddes owen fyngre wrought was
And not bygoten of mannes sperme vnclene
And welte al paradys sauyng one tree
Had neuer worldly man so hyghe degree
As Adam / til he for mysgouernaunce
Was dryuen out of his hye prosperyte
To labour and to helle and to myschaunce
Lo Sampson whyche that was anunciat
By the aungel long or his natiuyte
And was to god almyghty consecrat
And stode in nobles whyle he myght see
Was neuyr suche a nother as was he
To speke of strengthe and therto hardynes
But to his wyues tolde he his secre
Thorough which he slough hym for wretchednes
Sampson thys noble and myghty champyon
Wtthout wepen saue his handes tweye
He slough and al to rente the lyoun
Toward his weddyng walkyng by the weye
His fals wyf coude hym so plese and preye
Til she his counceyl knewe and she vntrewe
Vnto his foos his counceyl gan bewreye
And hym forsoke and toke an other newe
An hondred foxys toke Sampson for yre
And al her tayles he to gyder bonde
And sette the foxys tayles al on fyre
For he in euery tayle hath put a bronde
And they brente al the cornes in that londe
And her olyues and her vynes eek
A thousand men eke he slowe wyth his honde
And had no wepyn but an asse cheek
When they were slayn so thristyd hym that he
Was wel nygh lorn for whiche he gan to preye
That god wold of his peyne haue som pyte
And sende hym drynke or ellis must he dye
And of thys asse cheke that was so drye
Out of a wang toth sprang anon a welle
Of whyche he dranke ynough shortly to seye
Thus halpe hym god / as Iudicum can telle
By verry force as gasa on an nyght
Maugre the philistenys of that Cyte
The gates of the toun he hath vp plyght
And on his back y caryed hem hath he
High on an hille where as men myght hem see
O nobyl and myghty sampson leef and dere
Had thou not tolde to wymmen thy secre
In alle thys world ne hath be thy pere
This sampson neythyr sydre dranke ne wyn
Ne on his hede cam rasour non ne shere
By precept of the messager deuyne
For al his strengthes in hys heeres were
And fully twenty yere by yere
Of ysrael he had the gouernaunce
But after sone shal he wepe many a tere
For wymen shal bryng hym to myschaunce
Vnto his lemman dalida he tolde
That in hys heris al his strengthe lay
And falsly to his foos hym she solde
And slepyng in her barm vpon a day
They made to clyppe or shere his here away
And made his fomen alle his craft aspien
And when that they hym fond in suche aray
They bond hym faste and put out his eyen
But or his heres were clyppid or shaue
There was no bonde that myght hym bynde
But now is he put in pryson in a caue
Where as they made hym at the querne grynde
O noble sampson strengest of mankynde
O whylom Iuge in glory and in ryches
Now mayst thou wepyn wyth thyn eyen blynde
Sith thou art from wele falle in to wretchidnes
The ende of thys caytyf was as I shal say
His fomen maden a feste vpon a day
And made hym as theyr fool before hem playe
And thys was in a tempyl of grete araye
But atte last he made a foul fraye
For he two postis shoke and made hem falle
And doun fyl the temple and al there it laye
And slow hym self and eke his fomen alle
This is to say the prynces euerychon
And eke thre thousand bodyes were there slayn
With fallyng of the grete tempyl of stone
Of sampson wol I nomore sayn
Beth ware of this ensampil olde and playn
That noman telle her counceyl to her wyuys
Of suche thyng as they wolde haue secrete fayn
Yf that hit touche her lymmes or her lyues
OF hercules the souerayn conquerour
Syngyn his werkes laude ⁊ hye renoun
For in his tyme of strengthe he bare the flour
He slough and rafte the skynne of the lyoun
And of Centaurus leyde the bost a doun
He arpies slough the cruel bryddes felle
He the goldyn applys raft fro the dragon
He drowe out Cerberus the hound of helle
He slough the cruel tyraunt busurus
And made his hors to frete hym flessh ⁊ boon
He slough the very serpent venemous
Of Achilles two hornes brake he that one
And he slough Cacus in a caue of stoon
He slough the geaunt Antheus the strong
He slough the grysly boor and that anon
And bare his hede vpon his necke long
Was neuer wyght sythe the world began
That slough so many monstrys as dyd he
Thorow the wyde worlde his name ran
What for his strengthe and his bounte
And euery reme went he for to see
He was so strong that noman myght hym lette
And both worldis endys seyth Trophe
In stede of boundis he of bras a pyler sette
A lemman had thys nobyl champyon
That hyght deyanyra as fressh as may
And as clerkys make mention
She hath hym sent a sherte fressh and gay
Allas thys sherte allas and wel away
Enuenemyd was subtilly wyth alle
That er he had wered hit half a day
It made his flessh al fro his bonys falle
But natheles som clerkys hyr excusen
By one that hight nessus that hit maked
Be as be may I wyl her not accusen
But on his body the shert he wered al nakyd
Tyl the flessh was wyth the venym slakyd
And whan he sawe non other remedye
In hoot colys he hath hym self rakyd
For wyth no venym deyned he to dye
Thus starf thys worthy myghty hercules
Lo who may trust in fortune ony throwe
For hym that folotheth al this world of prees
Or he be ware is ofte leyd ful lowe
Ful wyse is he that hym self can knowe
Be ware for whan that fortune lyst to glose
Thenne wayteth she her man doun to throwe
By suche a waye as he wold lest suppose
THe myghty trone the precious tresour
The glorious septre ⁊ the ryal mageste
That had the kyng Nabugodonosor
Wyth tongue vnnethe may discrivid be
He twyes wan Iherusalem that cyte
The vessyl of the temple he wyth hym lad
At Babilon was his souerayn see
In whiche his glory and his delyte he had
The fayrest chyldren of the blood ryal
Of Iherusalem he dyd doo gelde anon
And made eche of hem to be his thral
Among al other danyel was one
That was the wysest chylde of euerychone
For he the dremes of the kyng expowned
There as in Caldey clerkes were there none
That wyst to what fyn his dreme sowned
This proud kyng let make a statu of golde
Sixti cubytis long and seuyn in brede
To whyche ymage bothe yong and old
Commaunded he to loute and haue in drede
Or in a furneys / ful of flames rede
He shold be dede that wolde not obeye
But neuer wold accorde to that dede
Daniel ne his yong felowes tweye
This kyng of kynges proud and elate
He wende god that sitteth in mageste
Ne myyht not bereue of his astate
But sodenly he lost his dignyte
And like a best hym semed for to be
And eet hey as an oxe and lay there out
In rayn wyth wylde bestes walkyd he
Tyl a certayn tyme was come aboute
And like an eglis fetheris were his heris
And naylis like byrdes clawys were
God releuyd hym at certeyn yeres
And yaf hym witte ⁊ than with many a teer
He thankyd god and euer his lyf in feer
Was he to doo a mys or more trespas
And er that he layde was on his bere
He knewe that god was ful of myght ⁊ grace
HIs sone whiche that hyght Balthasar
That held the regne aftir his fader day
He by his fader coude not bewaar
For proud he was of herte and of araye
And eke an ydolastir was he ay
His high astate assured hym in pryde
But fortune cast hym doun ⁊ there he lay
And sodenly his regne can deuyde
A feste he made vnto his lordis alle
Vp on a tyme he made them blythe be
And than his offycers gan he calle
Goth bryng forth the vessellys quod he
Whiche that my fader in his prosperyte
Out of the tempyl of Iherusalem beraft
And to our goddys thanke we
Of honour that our eldrys wyth vs laft
His wyf his lordis and his concubynys
Ay dronkyn whylis her appetitis last
Out of thys noble vessellys sondry wynys
And on a wal thys kynge his eyen cast
And sawe an hond armeles that wroot fast
For feer of whiche he quok and sighed sore
This hond that balthasar made so sore agast
Wrote mane / techel / phares and nomore
In al that londe magicien was there non
That coude expowne that thys letter ment
But danyel expowned it anon
And sayd kyng / god to thy fadyr sent
Glorye and honour regne tresour and rent
And he was proud and nothyng god he drad
And therfore grete wrath god vpon hym sent
And hym beraft the regne that he had
He was out cast of mannys company
With assys was his habytation
And eet hey as a best in wete and dry
Tyl that he knewe by grace and by reson
That god of heuen hath domynation
Ouer euery regne and euery creature
And than had god of hym compassyon
And hym restoryd his regne and hys fygure
Eke thou that art his sone art proud also
And knowest al thyse thynges pryuely
And art rebel to god and his fo
Thow drank eek of his vessels boldly
Thy wyf eek and thy wenchys synfully
Dronk of the same vesselis sondry wynys
And heryed fals goddis cursydly
Therfore to the shapyn grete peyne is
This hond was sent fro god that on the wall
Wroot mane techel phares trust me
Thy regne is doon thou weyyst not all
Deuyded is thy regne and hit shal be
To medes and to perciens quod he
And that same nyght the kyng was slawe
And daryus ocupyed his degre
Though he therto had neyther right ne lawe
Lordynges here by ensaumple mowe ye take
How that in lordshyp is no sikyrnes
For when that fortune wyl a man forsake
He beryth away his regne and his ryches
And eke his frendis both more and les
And what man hath frendys thorugh fortune
Mys hap wol make hym enemyes I gesse
This prouerbe is ful soth and ful commune
CEnobia of Palymerye quene
As wryteth percyens of her nobles
So worthy was in armys and so kene
That no wyght passyd her in hardynes
Ne in lynage ne in non other gentilnes
Of kynges blood of Perce is she descendyd
I say that she had not most fayrnes
But of her shappe she myght not be amendyd
From her chyldehod I fynde that she fled
Offyce of womman and to wode she went
And many a wylde hertes blood she shed
Wyth arowes brood that she to hem sent
She was so swyft that she anon hem hent
And whan that she was elder she wold kylle
Lyouns liberdis and beris al to rent
And in her armes welde hem at her welle
She durst wylde bestys dennys seke
And renne in the mounteyn al the nyght
And slepe vnder a bussh and she coude eke
Wrastyl by very force and very myght
Wyth ony yong man were he neuer so wyght
There myght nothyng in her armes stonde
She kepte her maydenhede from euery wyght
To no man deyned she to be bonde
But atte last her frendes hath her maryed
To Onedac a prynce of that contree
Al were it so / that she hem long taryed
And ye shul vnderstonde how that he
Hadde suche fantesyes as had she
But netheles when they were knyt in fere
They lyuyd in Ioye and in felicite
For eche of them had other leef and dere
Saue o thyng that she nolde neuer assent
By no wey that he shold by her lye
But onys for it was her pleyn entent
To haue a chyld the world to multiplye
And also sone as she myght aspye
That she was not wyth chylde wyth that dede
Than wold she suffir hym do his fantesie
Eft sonys and nat but onys out of drede
And yf she were wyth chylde at that cast
Nomore shold he pleye that game
Tyl fully / xl dayes were y past
Thenne wolde she onys suffir hym the same
Al Were thys Onedak wylde or tame
He gat no more of her for thus she sayde
It was to wyuys lecherye and shame
In other caas yf men wyth hem playde
Two sonys by thys Onedak had she
The whiche she kept in vertue and lettrure
But now vnto our tale turne we
I say that so worshypful a creature
And wyse therwyth and large With mesure
So penybil in warre and curteys eke
Ne more labour myght in werre endure
Was none though al this world men wolde seke
Her riche aray ne myght not be tolde
As wel in vessyl as in her clothyng
She was al clad in perry and in golde
And eke she left not for none huntynge
To haue of sondry tongis folk knowynge
When that she leyser had and for to entende
To lerne bokis was al her lykyng
How she in vertu her lyf myght dyspende
And shortly of thys story for to trete
So doughty was her husbond as she
That they conqueryd many regnes grete
In the oryent wyth many a fayr cyte
Appertenaunt vnto the maieste
Of rome and wyth strenghte held hem fast
Ne neuer myght her fomen doo her fle
Al the whyles that Onedakys dayes last
Her batellis who so lyst hem for to rede
Agayn Sapor the kyng and other moo
And how al thys proces fyl in dede
Why she conqueryd ⁊ what title she had therto
And aftir of her myschyef and of her woo
How that she was besegyd and y take
Lat hym to my maystyr Petrark goo
That wryteth ynow of thys I vndertake
Whenne Onedack Was ded she myghtyly
The remys held and wyth her owen hond
Agaynst her foos she fought trewly
That there nas prynce ne kyng in al that londe
But were glad yf they that grace fonde
That she ne shold vp on his lond werreye
With her they made aliaunce by bonde
To be in pees and lete hem ryde and pleye
The emperour of rome claudyus
Ne hym beforn the Romayn Galyene
Ne durst neuer be so corageous
Ne non ermyn ne none egipcien
Ne surryen ne none arabien
Within the felde that durst with her fyght
Lest that she wold hem With her handes sleen
Or wyth her meyne put hem to flyght
In kynges habyt wente her sones tWo
As heyres of her remes alle
And hermanno and titamallo
Her namys were as perciens hem calle
But ay fortune hath in her hony galle
This myghty quene may no whyle endure
Fortune out of regne made her to falle
To wretchydnes and to mysauenture
Aurilian whenne that the gouernaunce
Of Rome cam in his houndis tweye
He shope vp on thys quene to doo vengeance
And wyth his legyons he toke his waye
Toward Cenobie and shortly for to seye
He made her flee and atte laste her hent
And feteryd her and eke her chyldren tweye
And wan the londe and home to rome he Went
Among othyr thyngis that he wan
Her chare that of gold was wrought ⁊ perre
This grete romayn thys aurilyan
Hath with hym lad that for men shold see
Beforn his tryumphe Walkyd she
wyth goldyn cheynes on her necke hangynge
Crouned she was as aftir her degre
And ful of perre charged her clothynge
Allas fortune she that whylom was
Dredeful to kyngys and to Emperouris
Now gawrith al the peple on her allas
And she that helmyd Was in stark stouris
And wan by force toWnes strong and touris
Shal on her hed now were autremyte
And she that bare the septer ful of flouris
Shal bere a dystaf her cost for to quyte
OF mylane grete barnabo viscount
God of delyte and scorge of lumbardye
Why shold nat I thy fortune acounte
Sythen in estate thou clomben were so hye
Thy brothyr sone that was thy doubyl alye
For he thy nevewe was and sone In lawe
Wythin his pryson made the to dye
But why ne how not I that thou were slawe
OF the erle huglyn of pyse the langour
There may no tongue telle for pite
But litil out of pise stondyth a tour
In whiche tour in pryson put was he
And wyth hym his litil chyldren thre
The eldest skarsly fyue yere was of age
Allas fortune it was grete cruelte
Suche byrdes for to put in suche a cage
Dampned he was to dyen in that pryson
For Roger whiche bysshop was of pyse
Had on hym made a fals subgestyon
Thorow whiche the peple gan on hym aryse
And put hym in pryson in suche a wyse
As ye haue herd and mete and drynke he hadde
So smal that wel vnnethe it may suffyse
And therwyth al it was ful poure and badde
And on a day it be fyl that in that hour
when that his mete was wont to be brought
The gayler shytte the doris of the tour
He herde it wel but he spack right nought
And in his herte anon there fyl a thought
That they for hungre wolde do hym to dyen
Allas quod he allas that I was wrought
Therewyth the teris fyl from his eyen
His yong sone that thre yere was of age
Vnto his fader he sayde why doo ye Wepe
Whenne wol our Gayler bryng our potage
Is there no morsel breed that ye do kepe
I am so hungry that I may not slepe
Now wolde god that I myght slepe euyr
Than shold no hungre in my wombe crepe
There is no thyng than bred that me wer leuyr
Thus day by day thys chylde gan to crye
Tyl in his faders barm a doun it lay
And sayd fare wel fader I mot dye
And kyssed his fader and deyde the same day
And when the woful fader dede hym say
For wo his armys he gan to byte
And sayd allas fortune and welaway
Thy fals Whele my wo all may wyte
His other chyld wende that for hungre it was
That he his armes gnewe and not for woo
And sayd fader doo not so allas
But rather ete the flessh vpon vs two
Our flesshe thou yaf vs take our flessh vs fro
And ete ynough ryght thus the chylde sayde
And after that wyth ynne a day or two
They leyde hem doun in his lappe and deyde
Hym self dyspeyryd eke for hungre starf
Thus ended the myghty erle of pyse
From high estate fortune awaye hym carf
Of thys tragedye it ought I nough suffyse
Who so wyl here it in a lenger wyse
Redyth the grete poet of ytayle
That hight daunte for he can hit deuyse
Fro poynt to poynt nat on word wyl he fayle
AL though that nero were as vycious
As eny fende that lieth ful lowe adoun
Yet he as tellyth vs suetonius
Al thys World had in subiection
Bothe est and West and septemtrion
Of Rnbies / saphires and of perlis White
Were al his clothys browdyd vp and doun
For he in gemmys gretly gan delyte
More delycat more pompons of aray
More proud was neuer emperour than he
That ylke cloth that he had weryd o day
After that tyme he nolde it neuer see
Nettis of golde threde had he grete plente
To fyssh in Tyber whan hym lyst to pleye
His lustis were as lawe in his degre
For fortune as his frende wold hym obeye
He Rome brent for his dilycacye
The senatours he slough vpon a day
To here hoW that thomen wolde wepe and crye
And slough his brothyr and by his suster lay
His moder made he in a pytous aray
For he her wombe lete slytte to be holde
Where he conceyued was so welaway
That he so lytyl of hys moder tolde
No teris out of his eyen for that sight
Ne cam but sayd a fayr woman was she
Grete wonder is that he coude or myght
Be domesman of her ded beaute
The wyn to bryng hym commannded he
And drank anon none other wo he made
Whenne myght is ioyned vnto cruelte
Allas to depe Wol the venym wade
In youth a mayster had thys emperour
To teche tym lettrure and curtesye
For of moralyte he was the flour
As in his tyme but yf his bokes lye
And whiles his maister had of hym maistrye
He made hym so connyng and so souple
That long tyme it was or tyrannye
Or ony vyce durste in hym vncouple
Seneca his mayster was of whiche I deuyse
By cause Nero had of hym suche drede
For he for his vyces wold hym chastyse
Dyscretly as by worde and not by dede
Syre he wold say an emperour moot nede
Be vertuous and hate Tyrannye
For Whiche he made hym in a bath to blede
On bothe his armys til he must dye
This nero had eke of a custumaunce
In yongthe ayenst his mayster to ryse
Which afterward hym thought a grete greuaūnce
Ay cause he ofte wolde hym chastyse
Therfore he made hym dye in thys wyse
To chese in a bath to dye in thys manere
Rathyr than to haue another turmentise
And thus hath nero slayn his mayster dere
Now fyl it so that fortune lyst no lenger
The hygh pryde of Nero to cherysshe
For though he were strong yet was she strenger
She thought thus by god I am to nyce
To sette a man that is fulfylled of vice
In hye degre and an Emperour hym calle
By god out of his sete I wyl hym tryce
Whan he leste weneth sonest shal he falle
The pepyl roos vp on hym on an nyght
For his defaute and whan he it aspyed
Out of his doris anon he hath hym dyght
Alone and there he wende haue be alyed
He cnockyd fast and ay the more he cryed
The fastyr shyt they the dorys alle
Tho wyst he wel he had hym self begylid
And wente his way no lengir durst he calle
The peple cryde and romblyd vp and doun
That with his eris he herde how that they sayde
Where is thys fals tyraunt thys neron
For feer ful neer out of his wytte he breyde
And to his goddis pitously he preyde
For socour but it myght not be tyde
For drede of thys hym thought that he deyde
And ran in to a gardyn hym to hyde
And in thys gardyn fond he chorlis tweye
And syttyng by a fyre grete and reed
And to the chorlis two he gan to preye
To sle hym and to girde of his heed
That to his body Whan he were deed
Weere no despyte don for his defame
Hym self he slough he coude no better rede
Of whiche fortune lowhe and had game
WAs neuyr Capteyn vnder a kyng
That regnes mo put in subiection
Ne strenger was in felde of al thyng
As in his tyme ne gretter of renonn
Ne more Pompous in high presumpcion
Than Olophern whiche fortune ay kyste
So licorously ladde hym vp and doun
Tyl that he ded was or that he wyst
Not only that thys world had of hym awe
For lesyng of ryches and lyberte
But he made euery man reneye his lawe
Nabugodonosor was lord sayde he
None other god shold honoured be
Ayenst his heste there dar no wyght trespas
Saue in bethulya a strong cite
Where Elyachym was prest of that place
But take kepe of the deth of Olophern
Amyd his hoost he dronke lay al nyght
Wyth in his tente large as is a bern
And yet for al his pompe and al his myght
Iudyth a womman as he lay vpright
Slepyng his hede of smote and fro hys tente
Ful pryuely she stale from euery wyght
And wyth his hede vnto her toun she Wente
WHat nedith it of kyng Antiochus
To telle his hygh and ryal maieste
His high pryde his werk venemus
For suche another man nas neuer as he
Redyth what that he was in Machabe
And redyth the proude werkys that he sayde
And why he fyl from his prosperyte
And in an hyll how wretchidly he deyde
Fortune hym hadde enhaunsid so in pryde
That veryly he wende he myght atteyne
Vnto the sterrys vp on euery syde
And in a balaunce to weye eche mounteyn
And al the flodys of the see restreyn
And goddis peple had he most in hate
Hem wolde he sle in tourment and in peyn
Wenyng that god ne myght his pryde abate
And for that Nychamore and Tymothe
Whiche Iewes were vencusid myghtyly
Vnto the Iewes suche an hate had he
That he had greythyd his chare ful hastely
And swoor and sayd ful despitously
Vnto Ierusalem he wolde eftsone
To wreke his yre on hit ful cruelly
But of his purpoos was he let ful sone
God for his manace hym sore smoot
With inuisible wounde ay incurable
That in his guttes carf so and boot
That hys peynes were Importaale
And certenly the wreche was resonable
For many a mannys guttis dyd he peyne
But from his purpoos cursid and dampnable
For al his smert / he nolde hym restreyne
But bad anon pareylen his hoost
And sodenly or he than was waar
God dauntid al his pryde and al his boost
For he so sore fyl out of his chare
That al his lymmys and his skyn to tare
So that he ne myght goo ne ryde
But in a chayer men about hym bare
Al for brosyd bothe bak and syde
The wreche of god hym smote so cruelly
That in his body wyckyd wormes crept
And therwyth al he stank so horrybly
That none of al his meyne that hym kept
Whether that he woke or ellys slepte
Ne myght not of hym the stynke endure
And in this myschief he wayled and eke wepte
And knewe god lord of euery creature
To al his hoost and to hym silf also
Ful waltsom Was the stynke of his careyn
No man myght hym bere to ne fro
And in his stynke and in his horryble peyn
He starf ful wretchydly on a mounteyn
Thus hath this robber and thys homycide
That many a man made to wepe and pleyn
Suche guerdon as belongyth vnto pryde
THe story of alisaunder is so comune
That euery wight that hath discrescyon
Hath herd somwhat or al of his fortune
This wyde worlde as in conclusion
He wan by strengthe and his renoun
They were glad for pees vnto hym sende
The pryde of man and boste he leyd a doun
Where so he cam in to the worldys ende
Comparyson myght yet neuer be makyd
Betwyx hym and another conquerour
For al this worlde for drede of hym hath quakid
He was of knyghthod ⁊ of fredom floure
Fortune hym made the heir of hygh honour
Saue wyn ⁊ wommen no thyng myght aswage
His hygh entent in armes and labour
So was he ful of louyng corage
What pryde were it to hym though I you tolde
Of daryus and of a hundrid thousand mo
Of pryncis / erlis / and kyngys bolde
Whiche he conqueryd and brought to wo
I say as fer as a man may ryde or go
The world Was his what shold I more deuyse
For though I wrote and tolde you euyr mo
Of his knyghthod it myght not suffyse
Xij yere he regned as I rede in machabe
Philippis sone of Macedone he was
That first was kyng of grece that countre
O worthy gentyl Alisaunder allas
That euyr shold the falle suche a cas
Empoysond of thy folk thou were
Thy syce fortune hath tournyd in to an aas
And yet for the ne wepte she neuer a teer
Who shal yeue men terys to compleyne
The deth of gentilnes and of franchyse
That al the world weldyd in his demeyne
And yet hym thought it myght not suffyse
So ful was his corage of high emprise
Allas who shal me helpe to endyte
Fals fortune and poison to dispise
The whiche of al thys woo I wyte
BY wysedom manhod and high labour
From humbyl bedde to rial maieste
Vp roos he Iulyus the conquerour
That al the occident by londe and see
By strengthe of hond or ellys by trete
And vnto rome made hem trybutary
And sith of Rome Emperour was he
Tyl that fortune wex his aduersary
O myghty Cesar that in Thessaly
Ayenst Pompeius fader thyn in lawe
That of the oryent had the chyualry
As fer as that the day begynneth to dawe
Them thorugh knyghthod hast take ⁊ slawe
Saue fewe folk that wyth Pompeius fledde
Thorou which thou puttist al the orient in awe
Thanke fortune that so Wel the spedde
But now a litil Whyle I wyl bewayl
This pompeius this noble gouernour
Of rome whiche that fledde at thys batayl
I say one of his men a fals traytour
His hede of smoot to Wynne hym fauour
Of Iulius and to hym the heed broughte
Allas Pompeye of the oryent conquereur
That fortune vnto suche a fyn the broughte
To rome agayn repeyrith Iulyus
Wyth his tryumphe laureat ful hye
But on a tyme brutus cassius
That euer had of his hye estat enuye
Ful pryuely had made conspyresye
Ayenst thys Iulyus in subtil wyse
And cast the place in whiche he shold dye
With boydekyns as I shal you deuyse
This Iulius vnto the Capytoly went
Vp on a day as he was wont to gon
And in the capitoly anon hym hent
This fals brutus and his other foon
And stikyd hym wyth boydekyns anon
Wyth many a wounde ⁊ thus they let hym lye
But neuer grunted he at no strook but oon
Or ellys at tWo but yf his story lye
So manly was thys Iulyus of herte
And so wel louyd estatly honeste
That though his dedly woundis so sore smert
His mantel ouer his hippis cast he
For no man shold see his pryuyte
And as he lay in dyyng on a traunce
And wyst veryly that dye shold he
Of honeste yet had he remembraunce
Lucan to the thys story I recommende
And to Sueton and to valery also
That of thys story wryten word and ende
How that thyse conquerours two
Fortune was first a frende ⁊ sythen a foo
Noman truste vp on her fauour longe
But haue here in a wayte for euermoo
Witnes on al the conquerours stronge
O Noble o worthy petro glorye of spayne
Whom fortune held so hye in mageste
Wel oughten men thy pyetous deth compleyne
Out of thy londe thy brother made the fle
And after at a siege by subtilte
Thou were betrayed ⁊ lad vp to his tente
Where as he wyth his own hond slowe the
Succedyng in thy regne and in thy rente
The felde of snowe wyth thegle of black therin
Caught wyth the lymerodde colourd as a glede
He brewe thys cursydnes and al thys synne
The wycked nest was werker of thys nede
Not charles Olyuer that toke ay hede
Of trouth and honour / but of armoryke
Genelon Olyuer corrupte for mede
Brought thys worthy kynge in suche a bryke
O worthy petro kyng of Cypre also
That alysaunder wan by hye maystrye
Ful many an hethen wroughtest thou ful wo
Of whiche thyn owen lieges had enuye
And for no thyng but for thy chyualrye
They in thy bedde han slayn the by the morowe
Thus can fortune wel gouerne and gye
And out of Ioye bryng men to sorowe
THe riche cresus whylom kyng of lyde
Of whiche cresus / cirus sore hym dradde
Yet was he caught amyd al his pryde
And to brenne men to the fyre hym ladde
But suche a rayn doun fro the fyrmament shad
That queynte the fire and made hym to scape
But to be waar yet no grace he had
Tyl fortune on the galowis made hym gape
When he ascaped was he coude nat stynte
For to begyn a newe aray agayn
He wend wel for that fortune hym sent
Suche hap that he ascapyd thorough the rayn
That of his foos he myght not be slayn
And eke a sweuyn vpon a nyght he mette
Of whiche he was so proude ⁊ eke so feyn
That in vengeaunce he al his herte sette
Vpon a tre he was as hym thought
There Iubyter hym wessh both back and syde
And phebus eke a fayr towayl hym brought
To drye hym with ⁊ therwith Wext his pryde
And to his doughter that stode hym besyde
Which that he knewe in high sentence habounde
He bad her telle what it signyfyed
And she his dremys right thus expowned
The tre quod she the galowis is to mene
And Iupyter betokenyth snow and rayn
And phebus with his toWel so clene
Betokenyth the sonne bemys soth to sayn
Thou shalt an hanged be fader certeyn
Rayn shal the wasshe ⁊ sonne shal the drye
Thus she warnyd hym ful plat ⁊ ful pleyn
His doughter that callyd was Phanye
An hangyd was cresus the proud kyng
His ryal trone myght hym not auaylle
Tragedy is none other maner thyng
Ne can in syngyng cryen ne bewayle
But for that fortune alday wyl assaylle
Wyth vnwaar stroke the regnes that be proude
For when men trust in her than wol she faylle
And couer her bryght face vnder a cloude
Here endeth the Monkes tale

Here foloweth the prologue
Of the nonnys preest
HO quod the knyght good sir nomore of this
That ye haue sayd is right ynough ywis
And mykyl more for litil heuynes
Is ryght ynough to mykyl folke I ges
I seye for me it is a grete disease
Where as men haue be in welthe and ease
To here of her sodeyn fal allas
And the contrarye is Ioye and solas
As whan a man hath ben in pour estate
And clymbeth vp and wexyth fortunate
And there abydeth in prosperite
Suche thynge is gladsom as thynketh me
And of suche thyng were good for to telle
Ye quod our hoost by seynt poulis belle
Ye say right soth / this monke clappeth loude
He spack how fortune couerd wyth a cloude
I wote neuer what / ⁊ als of a tragedye
Right now ye herde / ⁊ perde no remedye
It is for to bewaylen ne compleyne
That / that is don / and als it is a peyne
As ye have seyd to here of heuynesse
Syr monke no more of thys so god you blesse
Your tale anoyeth al thys companye
Suche talkyng is not worth a butterflye
For there in is there no dysport ne game
Wherfore sir monk or dan Piers by our name
I pray you hertely tel vs sumwhat ellys
For sikerly nere clynkyng of your bellys
That on your brydyl hongyn on euery syde
By heuyn kyng that for vs al dyde
I shold or thys haue fallen doun for slepe
Al though the slough had neuer be so depe
Than had your tale al be tolde in veyn
For certenly as that thyse clerkys seyn
Where as a man may haue non audyence
Not helpyth it to telle his sentence
And wel I woot the substaunce is in me
Yf ony thyng shal wel reported be
Syr say somwhat of huntyng I you praye
Nay quod thys monke I haue no lust to playe
NoW lette another telle as I haue tolde
Than spake our hoost with rude speche ⁊ bolde
And sayde to the nonnys preest anon
Com ner thou preest come hidyr thou syr Iohn
Tel vs suche thyng as may our hertis glade
Be blythe though thou ryde vpon a Iade
What though thy hors be foul and lene
Yf he wol serue the / recke the not a bene
Look that thy herte be mery euer moo
Yes syr quod he yes hoost so moot y goo
But I be mery I Wys I wyl be blamyd
And right anon his tale he hath attamyd
And thus he sayd to vs euerychone
Thys sWete preest this goodly man sir Iohn
Here endeth the prologue of the nonnys preest

body.fw: The Tale of The Nonnys preest

div.l: And here begynnyth his tale
A Poure wydow som dele y stept in age
Was somtyme dwellyng in a cotage
Beside a groue stondyng in a dale
This wydow of whiche I telle you my tale
Syn that day that she was last a wyf
In pacience ledde a ful sympyl lyf
For lytil was her catel and her rent
By husbondry of suche as god her sent
She fonde her self and eke her doughtryn two
Thre large sowys had she and nomo
Thre kyne ⁊ eek a sheep that hight malle
Wel soty was her bour and eek her halle
In whyche she eet many a slender meel
Of poynaunt sawce ne knewe she neuer adeel
Ne deynte morcel passyd thorough her throte
div.fw: The Tale of The Nonnys preest
div.l: Her dyet was accordaunt to her cote
Repleccion ne made her neuer syke
A temperat dyet was her physyke
And excercyse and hertis suffysaunce
The gowte let her no thyng for to daunce
Ne Apoplexie shent not her heed
No wyn ne drank she neyther whyte ne reed
Her bord was most seruyd with whit ⁊ blak
Mylk ⁊ broun bred in whiche she fond no lak
Seynd bacon and somtyme an ey or tweye
For she Was as it were a maner deye
A yerd she had enclosyd al aboute
Wyth styckis and drye dyched wythoute
In whiche she had a cok highte chauntecleer
In al the lond of crowyng nas his peer
His voys was merier than the mery orgon
On masse dayes that in the chyrches goon
Wel sikerer was his crowyng in his loge
Than is a clocke or in ony abbey an orloge
By nature he crewe eche assencion
Of the equynoccion in the toun
For when degrees / xv / Were ascendyd
Than crew he that it myght not be amendyd
Hys comb was redder than the fyn coral
And batellyd as it had be a castel wal
His byl was blak as ony geet it shoon
Lyke asure were his leggys and his toon
His naylis whytter than the lily flour
And like the burned gold was his colour
This gentil cok hadde in his gouernaunce
Seuen hennys to doo al his plesaunce
Whiche were his sistris ⁊ his paramouris
And wonder like to hym as of colouris
Of whiche the fayrist hewyd in the throte
Was clepyd fair damysel Pertelote
He fethered her an hundred tyme a day
And she hym plesith al that euer she may
Curteys she was discrete and debonayr
div.fw: The Tale of The Nonnys preest
div.l: And compenabyl ⁊ baar her self so fayre
Syn the tyme that she was seuenyght olde
That trewlych she hath the herte in holde
Of chaunteclerys lokyng in euery lith
He louyth her so that wel was hym therwyth
But suche a Ioye it was to here them synge
Whan the bryght sonne gan to sprynge
In swete accorde my leef is fer in londe
For that tyme as I haue vnderstonde
Bestys ⁊ byrdys coude speke and synge
And it so fyl that in the dawenynge
As Chauntecleer among his wyuys alle
Sat on his perche that was in the halle
And next hym sat his fayre Pertelote
This chauntecleer gan to grone in his throte
As a man in his dreme is dretchyd sore
And whan that Pertelot thus herde hym rore
She was a gast and sayde herte dere
Whet eyleth yoW to grone in thys manere
Ye be a verry slepar fy for shame
And he answerd thus and sayd madame
I pray yow that ye take it not in greef
By god I mette I Was in suche myschyef
Right noW that yet myn herte is sore a fright
Now god quod he my sweuen retche a right
And kepe my body out of foul prysoun
Me mette that I romed vp and doun
Wyth ynne our yerde where I sawe a beste
Was like an hounde ⁊ Wolde haue made a reste
Vp on my body ⁊ wolde haue had me deed
His colour was betwyxte yeloW and reed
And tippid was his tayle ⁊ bothe his erys
With black vnlike the remenaunt of his herys
His snoWte smal with glowyng eyen tweye
Yet for his loke almost for feer I dye
This causith me my gronyng doutles
Avoy quod she fy for shame hertles
Allas quod she for by god aboue
div.fw: The Tale of The Nonnys preest
div.l: Now haue ye lost myn herte ⁊ al my loue
I can not loue a coward by my feyth
For certes what so ony womman sayth
We al desiren yf it myght be
To haue husbondis hardy wyse and fre
And secret and non nygard ne no fool
Ne hym that is agast of euery tool
Ne none auauntour by that god aboue
HoW durst ye say for shame vnto your loue
That ony thyng myght make you a ferde
Haue ye no mannys herte ⁊ haue a berde
Allas and conne ye be a ferd of sWeuenys
No thyng but vanyte god woot in sweuene is
Sweueuys ben engendryd of replexions
And of fume and of complexions
When humours ben to habundaunt in a wight
Certis thys dreme whiche ye haue met to nyght
I telle you trouth ye may trust me
Cometh of superfluyte ⁊ rede coler parde
Whiche cause folke to drede in her dremys
Of arowes and of fyre wyth rede lemys
Of rede bestes that wol hem byte
Of contek and of waspes grete and lyte
Ryght as the humour of Melancolye
Causeth many a man in slepe to crye
For feer of grete bolis and beris blake
Or ellys blake deuylles wol hem take
Of other humours coude I telle also
That worken a man in slepe mykyl wo
But I wyl passe as lyghtly as I can
Lo caton whiche that was so wyse a man
Sayde he not thus / do no force of dremys
Now syr quod she whan we fle fro the bemys
For goddys loue as takyth som laxatyf
Vp peryl of my soule and of my lyf
I counceyl you the best / I wyl not lye
That bothe of coler and of malencolye
Ye purge you and for ye shul not tary
div.fw: The Tale Of The Nonnys preest
div.l: Though in thys toun be non apotecary
I shal my self two herbys teche yow
That shal be for your hele and for your prow
And in oure yerde tho herbys shal I fynde
The whiche haue of her properte by kynde
To purge you benethe and eke aboue
Foryet not thys for goddis owen loue
Ye be ryght coleryk of complexyon
Where the sonne is in his ascension
Ne fynde you not replete of humours hote
For yf ye doo I dar wel ley a grote
Than ye shal haue a feuyr terciane
Or ellys an agew that may be your bane
A day or two ye shal haue digestyuys
Of wormys or ye take your laxatyuys
Of laureal centory and of fumetere
Or ellys of the elderberyes that growyn there
Of Catapuce or of gaytrys beryes
Of herbe yue growyng in our yerde that mery is
Pluk hem vp as they growe and ete hem yn
Be mery husbond for your fader kyn
Dredyth no dreme I can say you nomore
Madame quod he gramerry of your lore
But netheles as touchyng dan catoun
That of wysedom hath suche a grete renoun
Though he bad no dremys for to drede
By god men may in olde bokys rede
Of many a man more of auctoryte
Than euer caton was so moot y the
That al the reuers sayth of his sentence
And haue wel founde by experyence
That dremys be signyficacions
As wel of Ioye as of trybulacions
That folke enduren in thys lyf present
There nedyth to make of thys none argument
The verry preef shewyth it in dede
One of the grettest auctor that men rede
Saith thus that somtyme two felowes went
div.fw: The Tale of the Nonnys preest
div.l: On pylgremage in ful good entent
And happid so they comyn in a toun
Where as there was suche congregacion
Of pepyl and eke of strayt herbygage
That they ne fond as mykyl as a cotage
In whiche they bothe myght I lodgyd be
Wherfore they must of necessyte
As for that nyght departe companye
And eche of them goth to his hosterye
And took his lodgyng as it wold falle
That one of hem was lodgyd in a stalle
Ferre in the yerde wyth oxen of the plow
That othyr man was lodgyd wel I now
As Was his auenture or his fortune
That vs gouernyth al as in comune
And so it befyl long or it Were day
This man mette in his bed there as he lay
How that his felow gan vpon hym calle
And sayde allas for in an oxes stalle
Thys nyght shal I be murdryd there I lye
Now helpe me dere brother or I dye
In al haste come to me he sayde
This man out of his slepe for feer abreyde
And whan he was wakyd of his slepe
He turned hym and toke of thys no kepe
Hym thought his dreme was but a vanyte
Thus twyse in his slepe dremyd he
And atte thrydde tyme yet his felaw
Cam as hym thought ⁊ sayde I am now slawe
Beholde my blody woundys depe ⁊ wyde
Aryse vp erly in the morow tyde
And atte west gate of the toun quod he
A cart ful of dung there shalt thou see
In whiche my body is hyd ful pryuely
Do that carte areste boldely
My gold causyd my deth soth to sayn
And tolde hym euery poynt how he was slayn
With a ful pytous face pale of hewe
div.fw: The Tale Of the Nonnys preest
div.l: And trust wel his dreme he fond right trewe
For on the morowe as sone as it was day
To his feloWys Inne he took the way
And when that he cam to the oxys stalle
Aftir his felow he began to calle
The osteler ansWerd hym anon
And sayde syr your felowe is goon
As sone as day he went out of the toun
This man gan fallyn in suspessyon
Remembryng of his dremys that he mette
And forth he goth no lenger wolde he lette
Vnto the westgate of the toun and fond
A dong carte as it were to donge londe
That was arayed in the same wyse
As ye haue herde the dede man deuyse
And wyth hardy herte he gan to crye
Veniaunce and Iustyce of thys felonye
My felow murdryd is this same nyght
And in thys carte he lyeth gapyng vp ryght
I crye out on the mynystris quod he
That shold kepe and reule thys cite
Harow allas here lyeth my feloW slayn
What shold I more of thys tale sayn
The pepyl out stert ⁊ cast the carte to grounde
And in the myddel of the dong they founde
The ded man that murdryd was al newe
O blesful god that art so good and trewe
Lo how that thou bewreyest murdyr alWey
Murdyr wyl out that se we day by day
Murdyr is so waltsom and abhomynabyl
To god that so Iust is and resonable
That he ne wol it suffre helyd to be
Though it abyde a yere or two or thre
Murdyr wyl out this is my conclusion
And right anon the mynystris of the toun
Haue hent the carter and so sore hym pyned
And eke the hosteler so sore engyned
That they beknewe her wyckednesse anon
div.fw: The Tale of the Nonnys preest
div.l: And weren an hangyd by the necke boon
Here may ye see that dremys ben to drede
And certis in the same lyf I rede
Ryght in the nexte chappytre after thys
I gab not so haue I Ioye and blys
Two men that wold haue passid ouer the se
For certeyn causes in to a fer contre
Yf the wynde ne had be contrarye
That made hem in a cyte to tarye
That stood ful mery vp on an hauen syde
But on a day ayenst an euyn tyde
The wynde gan chaunge ⁊ blew as hem lest
Ioly and glad they wentyn to rest
And cast hem ful erly for to saylle
But herkyn to one mān fil a grete merueille
The one of hem in slepyng as he lay
He mette a wonder dreme agayn the day
Hym thought a man stode by his beddys syde
And hym commaundyd that he sholde abyde
And sayd hym thus yf thou to morow wende
Thou shalt be dreynt my tale is at an ende
He wook ⁊ tolde his felow what he mette
And prayed hym his viage for to lette
As for that day he prayd hym forto abyde
His felow that lay by his beddis syde
Gan for to lawhe ⁊ scornyd hym ful faste
No dreme quod he may so my herte agast
That I wol lette for to do my thyngis
I set nat a strawe for thy dremynges
For sweuenes be but vanytees and Iapes
Men metyn alday of owlis and of apes
And eke of many a mase therwyth al
And dremyn of thyng that neuer was ne shal
But sith I see that thou wolt here abyde
And thus slouthen wylfully thy tyde
God woot it rewith me ⁊ haue good day
And thus he toke his leue ⁊ went his way
div.fw: The Tale Of the Nonnys preest
div.l: But er he hadde half his cours y saylyd
I not why ne what myschaunce it aylyd
But casuelly the shyppys botom to rent
And shyp ⁊ man vndir the watir went
In sight of othyr shippis besyde
That wyth hym sayled atte same tyde
And therfore fayr pertelot so dere
By suche ensamplys olde mayst thou here
That no man sholde be to recheles
Of dremys for I say the doutles
That many a dreme ful sore is for to drede
Lo in the lyf of seynt Kenelme I rede
That was kenulphus sone the nobyl kyng
Of mereturik how kenelme mette a thyng
A litil or he were murdryd on a day
His murdyr in his vysion he say
His norice hym expouned it euery del
His sweuyn ⁊ bad hym kepe hym wel
Fro treson but he was but vij yere olde
And therfor lityl tale he hath therof tolde
Of ony dreme so holy was his herte
By god I had leuer than my sherte
That ye had herde his legend as haue I
Dame pertelot I say to yow truly
Macrobyus that writeth the a visioun
In affryke of the worthy scypyoun
Affermyth dremys ⁊ sayth that they been
Warnyng of thynges that we after seen
And ferthermore I praye yow lokyth wel
In the olde testament of danyel
Yf he helde dremys ony vanyte
Rede eke of Ioseph and there shul ye se
Wondrys ben som tyme I say not al
Warnyng of thynges that shul aftir fal
Lo of egypt the kyng that hight Pharao
His baker and his boteler also
Whethir they felt none effect in dremys
Who so wol seke actis of sondry remys
div.fw: The Tale of The Nonnys preest
div.l: May rede of dremys a wonder thyng
Lo Cresus whiche was of lide kyng
