Mette he not that he sat vpon a tree
Whiche signyfyed he shold hangyd be
Lo Andrometa Hectors wyf
That day that Hector shold lese his lyf
She dremyd in the same nyght beforn
How that the lyf of Hector shold be lorn
Yf that day he went vn to bataylle
She warnyd hym but it myght not auayle
He went for to fyght netheles
But he was slayn anon of achylles
But that tale is to long to telle
And eke it is nygh day I may not dwell
Shortly I say as for conclusion
That I shalle haue of thys auysion
Aduersite and I say furthermore
That I ne telle of laxatiuys no store
For they be venemous I woot it weel
I hem deffye I loue hem neuer a deel
But now let vs speke of myrthe ⁊ stynt al this
Madame Pertelot so haue I blys
Of o thyng god hath me sent large grace
For when I see the beaute of your face
Ye be so skarlet reed about your eyen
It maketh al my drede for to dyen
For also sikir as in principio
Mulier est hominis confusio
Madame the sentence of this latyn is
Womman is mannys Ioye and his blys
For when I fele on nyght your soft syde
Al be it that I may not on yow ryde
For that our perche is made so narow allas
I am so ful of Ioye and of solas
That y diffye bothe sweuene and dreme
And with that word he fleye doun fro the beme
For it was day and eke his hennys alle
And wyth a chuk he gan hem for to calle
div.fw: The Tale Of the Nonnys preest
div.l: For he had found a corn lay in the yerde
Ryal he was ⁊ nomore a ferde
He federyd pertelot twenty tyme
And trade her eke as ofte or it was pryme
He lokyth as he were a grym lioun
And on his toos he romed vp and doun
Hym deyned not to sette his feet to grounde
And chuckyd whan he had a corn y founde
And to hym than ran his wyuys alle
As ryal as a prynce in his halle
Leue I thys chauntecleer in his pasture
And after wol I telle of his auenture
Whan the moneth in the which the world began
That hight marche that god first made man
Was complet and passyd were also
Sith marche began twenty dayes and two
Befyl that chauntecleer in al his pryde
Hys seuyn wyuys walkyng hym besyde
Cast vp his eyen to the bright sonne
That in the signe of taurus was y ronne
Fourty degrees ⁊ one ⁊ somwhat more
He knewe by kynde ⁊ by non other lore
That it was pryme ⁊ crew with a blisful steuēm
The sonne he sayde is clombe vp to heuyn
Fourty degrees ⁊ one ⁊ somwhat more I wys
Madame pertelot my worldis blys
Herkyn how this blisful briddis synge
And see the fressh flouris how they sprynge
Ful is myn herte of reuel and solas
But sodenly hym fyl a sorouful caas
For euer the latter ende of ioye is woo
God wote that worldly ioye is sone a goo
And yf a rethour coude fayr endyte
He in a cronycle myght sauely wryte
As for a souerayn notabylyte
Now euery wyseman herkyn to me
This story is also trewe I vndertake
As is the book of launcelot delake
div.fw: The Tale of the Nonnys preest
div.l: That wommen holden in ful grete reuerence
Now wol I turne ayen to my sentence
A col fox ful of sleyght and iniquyte
That in the groue had woned yeres thre
Be hygh ymagynacion aforn cast
The same nyght thorough the hedge brast
In to the yerde there chauntecleer the fayre
Was wont ⁊ eke his wyuys to repayre
And in a bed of wortis stylle he lay
Tyl it was passyd vndryn of the day
Waytyng his tyme on chauntecleer to falle
As gladly doon thyse homycides alle
That in a wayte ligge to murdre men
A fals murderour ruckyng in thy den
O newe Scariot and newe Genylion
Fals dissimylour o greek Synon
That broughtist troye vtterly to sorow
O chauntecleer acursid be the morow
That thou in thy yerde fley fro the bemys
Thou Were ful wel warnyd by thy dremys
That ylke day was perilous to the
But what that god afore wote muste nedis be
Aftir the oppynyon of certeyn clerkys
Witnes of hym that ony clerk is
That in scole is grete altercacion
In this mater ⁊ grete disputacion
And hath ben of an hondred thousand men
But I ne can not bulte it to the brenne
As can the holy doctour austyn
Or boece or the bysshop bradwardyn
Whethyr that goddis worthy fore wetyng
Streyneth me nedely to doo a thyng
Nedly clepe I symple necessyte
Or yf the fre choys be grauntid me
To doo that same thyng or do it nought
Though god forwoot it or it was wrought
Or yf his wytyng streyneth neuyr adeel
But by necessyte condycionel
div.fw: The Tale Of the Nonnys preest
div.l: I wol not haue to doon of suche matere
My tale is of a cok as ye shal here
That toke his counceyl of his wyf wsth sorow
To walke in the yerde vpon the morow
That he had met the dreme as I yow tolde
Wymens counceyllis ben ful ofte colde
Wymens counceyl broughte vs first to woo
And made Adam fro paradis to go
There as he was ful mery and Wel at ese
But for I not whom I myght displese
Yf I counceyl of wymmen wold blame
Passe ouer for I sayd it in my game
Redith auctours where they trete of such matere
And what they say of wymmen ye mowe here
These ben the cokkys wordis ⁊ not myn
I can no harme of no woman deuyne
Fayr in the sonde to bathe her merily
Lyeth pertelot ⁊ al her susteris by
Ayenst the sonne ⁊ chauntecleer so free
Sang merier than the mermayde in the see
For physologus sayth vtterly
How that they syngen wel ⁊ merily
And so befyl as he cast his eye
Among the Wortis on a butterflye
He was waar of this foxe that lay ful lowe
No thyng than lust hym for to crowe
But cryde anon cok cok and up he stert
As man that was afrayd in his hert
For naturelly a best desireth to fle
Fro his contrary yf he may it see
Though he neuer had seen it erst wyth his eye
This chauntecleer whan he gan hym aspye
He wold haue fled but that the fox anon
Sayd gentil sir alas what wyl ye don
Be ye affrayd of me that am your frende
Now certes I were worse than a fende
If I to you wold harme or vilonye
I am not comen your counceyl to aspye
div.fw: The Tale of The Nonnys preest
div.l: But trewly the cause of my comyng
Was only to here how ye syng
For trewly ye haue as mery a steuyn
As ony aungel hath that is in heuyn
Therwyth ye haue of musik more felyng
Than had boece or ony that can syng
My lord your fadir god his soule blys
And eke your moder of her gentilnys
Haue in my hows be to my grete ese
And certes sir ful fayne wolde I you plese
But for men speke of syngyng I wolde sey
So moot I browkyn wel myn eyen twey
Saue you ne herde I neuer man so synge
As dyd your fader in the mornyng
Certis it was of herte al that he song
And for to make his voys the more strong
He wold so peyn hym that wyth bothe his eyen
He must wynke so loude he must cryen
And stondyn on his tiptoos therwyth alle
Any stretche forth his necke long and smalle
And eke he was of suche discressyon
That there was no man in no regyon
That hym in song or wysdom myght passe
I haue wel red dan burnel the asse
Among his vers how that there was a cok
For that a preestes sone yaf hym a knok
Vp on his leggys while he was yong and nyce
He made hym for to lese his benefyce
But certeyn there is no comparison
Betwyx the wysdom and discrecion
Of yonr fader ⁊ of his subtilite
Now syngeth sir for saynt charite
Lete see can ye your fader counterfete
This chauntecleer his wynges gan to bete
As man that coude not his reson aspye
So was he rauesshyd with his flatery
Alas ye lordis many a fals flaterour
As in your court ⁊ many a fals losyngour
div.fw: The Tale Of the Nonnys preest
div.l: That plese you wel more by my feyth
Than he that sothfastens vnto you sayth
Redyth ecclesiast of flatery
Be waar ye lordis of her trecherye
This chauntecleer stood hye vpon his toos
Stretchyng hys necke and helde his eyen cloos
And gan to crowe lowde for the nonys
And dan russel the fox start vp at onys
And by the gorget hent chauntecleer
And on his bak toward the wode hym beer
For yet was there no man that hym sued
O destene that mayst not be escheued
Alas that chauntecleer flewe fro the bemys
Alas his Wyf raught not of dremys
And on a friday fyl al this myschaunce
O venus that art goddesse of plesaunce
Sithnes that thy seruaūnt was this chauntecleer
And in thy seruyse dyd al his power
More for delyte than the world to multeplye
Why woldest thou suffre hym on thy day to dye
O Gaufryde dere mayster souereyn
That whan the worthy kyng richard was sleyn
Wyth shot compleynedyst his deth so sore
Why ne had I now thy science ⁊ thy lore
The friday for to chyden as dyd ye
For on a friday shortly slayn was he
Than wold I shewe yow how that I coude pleyn
For chauntecleer drede and for his peyn
Certis suche crye ne lamentacion
Nas neuer of ladyes made when that Ilion
Was wōmne ⁊ pirrus with his bryght swerd
When he hent kyng Pryam by the berde
And slow hym as sayth eneydos
As maden al the hennys in the cloos
When that they had of chauntecleer the sight
But souerenly dame pertelot shright
Ful lowder than dyd hasdrubalis wyf
When that her husbond had lost his lyf
div.fw: The Tale of The Nonnys preest
div.l: And that the romayns had brent Cartage
She was so ful of turment and of rage
That wylfully in to the fyre she stert
And brend her self with a stedfast hert
O woful hennys ryght so cryden ye
As when that nero brent the cyte
Of rome criden the senatouris wyuys
For that her husbondys shold lese her lyuys
Wythouton gylt nero hath hem sleyn
Now wyl I turne to my tale agayn
This sely wydow and hir doughtris two
Herden the hennys cryen and make woo
And out at the dore stert they anoon
And saw the fox toward the wode goon
And bare vpon his bak the cok awey
And criden out ⁊ harow and welawey
A ha the fox and after hym they ran
And eke with stauys many an othyr man
Ran colle our dogge talbot and garlonde
And malkyn with her dystaf in her honde
Ran cow ⁊ calf and eke the very hoggys
For they so sore a ferde were of the doggys
And showtyng of men ⁊ of wommen eke
They ranne so her herte thought to breke
They yellyn as fendys don in helle
The dokys cryden as men wold hem quelle
The gees for feer flewe ouer the trees
Out of the hyuys cam the swarme of bees
So hidous was the noyse a benedicite
Certis Iacke strawe ne his meyne
Ne made neuyr showtes half so shrille
When that they wolde ony flemyng kylle
As that day was made vp on the fox
Of bras they blewe the trompes ⁊ of box
Of horn ⁊ boon in whiche they blew ⁊ powpyd
And therwith they shrikyd and shoutyd
It semed as though heuyn shold falle
Now good men I pray yow harkyn alle
div.fw: The Tale Of the Nonnys preest
div.l: Lo how fortune turnyth sodenly
The hope and the pryde of her enemye
This cok that laye vpon the foxys bak
In al his drede vnto the fox he spak
And sayde sir yf I were as ye
Yet shold I say as wys god helpe me
Turnyth ayen ye proude chorlis alle
A verry pestelence vpon you falle
Now am I come vnto this wodis syde
Magre your hede the cok shal here abyde
I wyl hym ete in feyth and that anon
The fox answerde in feyth it shal be don
And as he spak the worde al sodenly
This cok brake from his mouth delyuerly
And hygh vpon a tree he flewe anon
And when the fox saw that he was goon
Alas quod he o chauntecleer alas
I haue quod he do to you grete trespas
In as muche as I made you aferde
When I you hente and brought out of your yerde
But sir I dyd hit not in no wickyd entent
Come doun ⁊ I shal telle you what I ment
I shal you say soth so god helpe me so
Nay than quod he I shrewe vs both two
And first I shrewe my self both blood ⁊ bonys
Yf thou begyle me ofter than onys
Thou shalt nomore wyth thy flaterye
Do me syng wyth a wynkyng eye
For he that wynketh when he shold see
Al wylfully god lete hym neuer thee
Nay quod the fox but god yeue hym myschaūnce
That is so indiscrete of gouernaunce
That iangelith when that he shold haue pees
Lo suche it is for to be recheles
And neclygent and truste on flaterye
But ye that holden this tale a folye
As of a fox and a cok and an hen
Takyth the moralyte good men
For saynt poul sayth al that writyn is
To our doctryne it is writen y wis
Takyth the fruyt and leet the chaf be stylle
Now good god yf that it be thy wylle
As seith my lord so make vs al good men
And bryng vs to thy hygh blisse amen
Here begynneth the mauncyplis prologue
SYr nonnys preest our hoost sayd anon
Y blessyd be thy breche and euery stoon
This was a mery tale of chauntecleer
But by my trouth yf thou were seculer
Thou woldest ben a tredefoul a right
For yf thou haue corage / as thou hast myght
The were nede of hennys as I wene
Ye more than seuen tymes seuentene
See whiche brawnes hath this gentil preest
So grete a necke and suche a large breest
He lokyth as a sperhauke wyth his eyen
Hym nedeth not his colours for to dyen
Wyth brasil ne with grayn of portyngale
But sir fayr falle you for your tale
And after that he with ful mery chere
Sayd to an other man / as ye shal here
Woot ye not where there stondyth a litil toun
Whiche that is clepyd bob vp and doun
Vnder the blee in caunterbery way
There gan our hoost to iape and to pley
And sayd sires what dun is in the myre
Is there no man for preyer ne for hyre
That wol awake our felaw behynde
A theef myght hym ful lightly robbe ⁊ bynde
Se how he nappith see for cokkis bonys
How he wol falle from his hors attonys
As that a cook of london wyth myschaunce
Do hym comfort he knowyth his penaunce
For he shal telle a tale by my fey
Al though it be not worth a botel hey
Awake thou cook qd he god yeue the sorow
What eylith the to slepe by the morow
Hast thou had fleen al nyght or art thou dronk
Or hast thou al nyght with som quene y swonk
So that thou mayst not holde vp thy heed
This cook that was ful paal ⁊ no thyng reed
Sayd our hoost so god my soule blesse
There is falle on me grete heuynesse
Not I nat why me were leue to slepe
Then the best galon of wyne in chepe
Wel quod the maunapyl yf it may do ese
To the sir cook ⁊ to no wyght displese
Whiche that here ryden in thys companye
And that our hoost wyl of his curtesye
I wyl as now excuse the of thy tale
For in good feyth thy visage is ful pale
Thyn eyen dasowen sothly as me thynkith
And wel I woot thy breth ful soure stynketh
That shewyth wel thou art not wel disposid
Of me certeyn thou shalt not be glosyd
Se how he galpyth lo thys dronkyn wight
As though he wold vs swolowe anon right
Hold cloos thy mouth by thy fader kyn
The deuyl of helle sette his foot ther in
Thy cursyd breth wyl enfecte vs alle
Fy stynkyng swyn / fy foule moot the befalle
Takyth hede sires of thys lusty man
Now swete syr wyl ye Iuste atte van
Therto me thynketh ye be wel shape
I trow that ye haue dronkyn wyn ape
And that is when men pleyen atte straw
And with his speche the cook wexyd al wraw
And on the mauncipyl he gan to nodde faste
For lacke of speche adoun the hors hym caste
Where as he lay til that men hym vp took
This was a feyr cheuesaunce of a cook
Alas that he ne had holde hym by his ladyl
And er that he ayen were in his sadyl
There was a grete shouyng both to and fro
To lift hym vp and mykyl care and woo
So vnweldy was thys sely pallyd goost
And to the mauncipyl than spack our hoost
By cause that drynke hath domynacion
Vp on thys man / by my sauacion
I trowe lewdly wyl he telle his tale
For were it wyne or olde moysty ale
That he hath dronkyn he spekyth so in his nose
And fnesyth fast and eke he hath the pose
He hath also to doo more than ynough
To kepe hym on his capyl out of the slough
And yf he falle from his capyl eft sone
Than shul we al haue ynough to done
In lyftyng vp his dronkyn corps
Tel on thy tale of hym make I no fors
But yet mauncipyl in feyth thou art to nyce
Thus openly to reproue hym of his vyce
Another day he wyl perauenture
Recleyme the and bryng the to lure
I mene he speke wyl of smale thynges
And for to pynche at thy rekenyngys
That were not honest yf it cam to the preef
No qd the maūncypil that were a grete myschief
So myght he bryng me in to the snare
Yet had I leuer paye for the mare
Which he rideth on than he shold wyth me stryue
I wol not wrath hym so mote I thryue
That I spack I sayd it but in bourde
And wote ye what I haue here in my gourde
A draught of wyne ye of a rype grape
And right anon ye shul see a good Iape
This cook shal drynke therof yf I may
Vp peyne of my lyf he wyl not say nay
And certenly to tellyn as it was
Of this vessel the cook dranke fast alas
What nedyth it he drank ynough beforn
And when he had poupyd in his horn
To the mauncipyl he took the gourde agayn
And of the drynke the cook was ful fayn
And thankyd hym in suche wyse as he coude
Than gan our hoost to lawghe wonder loude
And sayde I se wel it is necessary
Where that we gon good drynke with vs to cary
For that wol turne rancour and dysese
To accorde ⁊ loue and many a word to pese
O bacus y blissyd be thy holy name
That so canst torne ernest in to game
Worshyp and thanke be to thy deyte
Of that mater ye gete nomore of me
Tel on thy tale thou mauncypyl I the preye
wel syr quod he herkenyth What I seye
Here endyth the mauncyplys prologue
And begynnyth his tale
WHen phebus dwellyd her in erthe adoun
As olde bokis maken mencion
He was the most lusty bacheler
Of al the world and eke the best archer
He slough pheton the serpent as he lay
Slepyng ayenst the sonne vpon a day
And many anothyr nobyl worthy dede
He with his bowe wrought as men mowe rede
Pleye he coude on euery mynstralcye
And syngen that it was a melodye
To here of his cleer voys the soun
Certes the kyng of Thebes amphyon
That wyth his song wallyd the cite
Coude neuer synge half so wel as he
Therto he was the semelyst man
That is or was sith the world began
What nedyth it his feture to discryue
For in thys world was there non so fayr alyue
He was therwith fulfilled of gentilnesse
Of honour and of parfight worthynesse
This phebus that was flour of bachelerye
As wel in fredom as in chyualrye
For his disporte in signe eke of vyctorye
Of pheton so as tellyth vs the story
Was wont to bere in his hond a bowe
Now had this phebus in his hous a crowe
With ynne a cage y fostryd many a day
And taught it speke as men teche a Iay
Whyt was this crowe as is a snow whit swan
And countirfetid the speche of euery man
He coude when he shold telle a tale
There was in al this world non nyghtyngale
Ne coude be an hondred thousand deel
Synge so wonderly merily and weel
Now had this phebus in his hous a wyf
Whiche that he loued more than his lyf
And nyght ⁊ day did euer his dylygence
Her for to plese and do her reuerence
Saue only yf the soth yf I shal sayn
Ielous he was ⁊ wolde haue kept her fayn
For hym were loth iapyd for to be
And so is euery wyght in suche degre
But al for nought for it auaylid nought
A good wyf that is clene of werk and thought
Shold not be kept in non awayte certeyn
And trewly the labour is in veyn
To kepe a shrewe for it wyl not be
This holde I for a very nycete
To spylle labour for to kepe wyuys
Thus wryten olde clerkys in her lyuys
But now to purpos as I first began
This worthy phebus doth al that he can
To plesen her Wenyng thorow suche plesaunce
And for his manhod ⁊ for his gouernaunce
That noman shold put hym from her grace
But god it woot there may no man enbrace
As to distreyne a thyng whiche that nature
Hath naturelly set in a creature
Take ony bryd and put hym in a cage
And do al thyn entent and thy corage
To fostre it tenderly wyth mete and drynke
Of al deyntees that thou canst bethynke
And kepe it also clenly as thou may
Al though his cage of golde be neuer so gay
Yet hath this brid by twenty thousand fold
Leuer in a forest that is wylde and cold
Go ete wormys and suche wretchydnes
For euyr thys brid wyl do his besynes
To ascape out of his cage when he may
His lyberte the bryd desyryth ay
Leet take a cat and fostre hyr wyth mylk
And tender flessh ⁊ make her couche of sylk
And leet hir see a mous go by the wal
Anon she weyuyth flessh ⁊ couche and al
And euery deynte that is in that hous
Suche appetyt hath she to ete the mous
Lo here hath lust his domynacion
And appetit flemyth discrcion
A she wolf hath also a vylens kynde
The lewdyst wolf that she may fynde
Or leest of reputacion that wyl she take
In tyme when her lust to haue a make
Al thyse ensaumplys speke I by thyse men
That ben vntrewe ⁊ nothyng by women
For men haue euer a licorous appetyt
On lower thyng to perfourme her delyt
Than on her wyuys be they neuer so feyr
Ne neuer so trewe ne so deboneyr
Flessh is so newfangyl wyth myschaunce
That we ne konne in no thyng haue plesaunce
That sownyth vnto vertu ony Whyle
Thus phebus whiche thought no gyle
Disceyued was for al his iolyte
For vnder hym another had she
A man of litil reputacion
Not worth to phebus in comparison
The more harme is it happith oft so
Of whiche there comyth muche harm and woo
And so befyl when phebus was absent
His wyf anon hath for her lemman sent
Her lemman certis this is a knauyssh speche
Foryeue it me and that I you beseche
The wyse plato sayth as ye mow rede
The worde must nede accorde wyth the dede
Yf men shul telle properly a thyng
The worde must cosyn be to the workyng
I am a boystous man ryght thus say I
There is but litil difference trewly
Betwyx a wyf that is of hygh degre
Yf of her body dyshonest she be
And a pore wenche other than thys
Yf it so be they werke both amys
But that the gentil is in staat aboue
She shal be clepyd his lady and his loue
And for that other is a poWer woman
She shal be clepyd hys wenche or his lemmnn
And god it woot myn owen dere brother
Men leye as lowe that one as that othyr
Right so betwyx a titelees tyraunt
And an out lawe or a theef erraunt
The same I say there is no dyfference
To Alisaunder was tolde thys sentence
That for the tyraunt is of gretter myght
By force of meyne to slee doun right
And brenne hous ⁊ hoom ⁊ make al pleyn
Lo therfore is he clepyd a capteyn
And for the outlawe hath but smal meyne
And may not doo so grete an harme as he
Ne bryng a contre to so grete myschief
Men clepe hym an outlawe or a theef
But for I am a man not textuel
I wol not telle of textes neuer a deel
I wyl goo to my tale as I began
Whan phebus wyf had sent for her lemman
Anon they wroughten al theyr lust volage
This white crowe that hyng ay in the cage
Beheld her werk ⁊ sayde neuer a worde
And when hoom was come phebus the lord
This crowe song cuckow cuckow cuckoW
What brid qd phebus what syngest thow
Ne were thou not wont so merily to synge
That to my herte it was a reioysyng
To here this voys alas what song is this
By god quod he I syng not amys
Phebus quod he for al thy worthynes
For al thy beaute and thy gentilnes
For al thy song and al thy mynstralcye
For al thy waytyng bleryd is thyn eye
With one of lityl reputacion
Not worth to the in comparyson
The mountaunce of a gnat so moot I thryue
For on thy bed thy wyf I sawe hym swyue
What wol ye more the crowe anon hym tolde
By sad tokenys and by wordis bolde
How that his wyf had don her lecherye
Hym to grete shame and to grete vylonye
And tolde hym efte he sawe it wyth his eyen
This phebns gan aweyward for to prien
Hym thought his woful herte brast a two
His bowe he bent ⁊ set ther ynne a flo
And in his yre he hath his wyf slayn
This is the effect there is nomore to sayn
For sorowe wherof he brak his mynstralsie
Bothe harpe and lute / geterne and sawtrye
And eke he brak his arowys and his bowe
And after that thus spak he to the crowe
Traytour quod he with tongue of scorpion
Thou hast me brought to my confusion
Alas that I was wrought why nere I deed
O dere wyf O gemme o lustyheed
That were to me so sad ⁊ eke so trewe
Now liest thou ded with face pale of hewe
Ful gyltlees that durst I swere y wys
O rakyl hond to do so foule a mys
O troubyl wyt O Ire recheles
That vnauysed synnest gyltles
O wantrust ful of fals suspecion
Where was thy wyt and thy discrecion
O euery man bewaar of rekylnes
Ne trowe no thyng wythout strong wytnes
Smyte not to sone or thou wyt why
And be auysid wel and sikerly
Or ye do ony execucion
Vp on your yre for suspecion
Alas a thousand folk haue rekyl Ire
Fully fordoon ⁊ brought hem in the myre
Allas for sorow I wyl my self slee
And to the crowe o fals thef sayde he
I wol quyte anon thy fals tale
Thou song whilom like an nyghtyngale
Now shalt thou fals theef thy song forgoon
Eke thy whyte fetherys euerychone
Ne neuer in al thy lyf shalt thou speke
Thus shul men on a treytour be a wreke
Thou ⁊ thyn ofspryng euer shal be blake
Ne neuer swete noyse shul ye make
But euer crye ayenst tempest and rayn
In tokyn that thorou the my wyf is slayn
And to the crowe he stert ⁊ that anon
And pullyd of his whyt fetheris euerichon
And made hym blak ⁊ reft hym al his song
And eke his speche ⁊ out atte dore hym slong
Vnto the deuyl whiche I hym betake
And for this caas be al crowys blake
Lordynges by this ensaumpyl I wyl you pray
Bewar and take kepe what I say
Ne tellyth neuer noman in your lyf
How that another man hath dyght his wyf
He wyl you haten mortally certeyn
Dan salamon as wyse clerkys seyn
Techyth a man to kepe his tongue wel
But as I sayd I am not textuel
But netheles thus taught me my dame
My sonne thynke on the crowe a goydis name
My sone kepe wel thy tongue ⁊ kepe thy frend
A wickyd tongue is worse than a fend
My sone from a fende men may hem blysse
My sone god of his endles goodnesse
Wallyd a tougue wyth teth ⁊ lippys eke
For man shold hym auyse what he speke
My sone ful oft for to mykyl speche
Hath many a man be spylt as clerkys teche
But for lityl speche spoken auysedly
Is no man shent to speke generally
My sone thy tongue sholdest thou restreyne
At al tyme but whan thou doost thy peyne
To speke of god in houour and prayere
The first vertu sone yf thou wylt lere
Is to restreyne ⁊ kepe wel thy tunge
Thus lerne chyldren whan they be yong
My sone of mykyl spekyng vn auysid
There lasse spekyng had I nough suffysyd
Comyth mykyl harme thus was me taught
In mykyl speche synne wantith naught
Wost thou wherfor a rakyl tunge seruyth
Right as a swerde for cuttith ⁊ forkeruyth
An arme a two my dere sone right so
A tunge cuttith frendshyp al a two
A Iangeler is to god obhomynabyl
Rede salamon so wyse ⁊ honourabyl
Rede dauyd ⁊ his psalmys rede seneke
My sone speke not ne wyth thy hede thou beke
Dissymyl as thou were deef yf that thou here
The Iangelour speketh of perlous matere
The flemyng sayth lerne yf that thou lest
That litil Iangelyng causith muche rest
My sone yf thou no wicked word hast sayd
The dar not drede for to be bewrayd
But he that hath myssayde I dar wel sayn
He may by no way clepe his worde agayn
Thyng that is sayd / is sayd ⁊ forth it goth
Though hym repente or hym be neuer so loth
He is thral to hym to whom he hath sayd
A tale for whiche he is now euyl apayd
My sone bewaar and be non auctor newe
Of tidynges whether they be fals or trewe
Where so thou come among hye or lowe
Kepe wel thy tuuge and thynk on the crowe
Here endeth the maunciplis tale
Here begynneth the parsonnys prologue
BY that the mauncipil had his tale ended
The sonne fro the south syde is descended
So lowe that it was not to my sight
Degrees of fyue and twenty of hyght
Ten atte clocke it was so as I gesse
For enleuyn foot a litil more or lesse
My shadow was at that tyme as there
Of suche feet as my lengthe partid were
In vj feet equally of proporcion
Ther wyth the monys exaltacion
I mene libra alway gan ascende
As we were entryng at the thorpys ende
For whiche our hoost as he was wont to gye
Ay in thys caas this Ioly companye
Sayde in thys wyse lordyngys euerychoon
Nou lakkyth vs no tale more than oon
Fulfilled is my sentente and my decre
Who wyl now telle a tale let see
Almost fulfylled is myn ordenaunce
I pray to god so yeue hym right good chaunce
That tellith this tale to vs lustely
Syr preest quod he art thou a vicary
Or art thou a parson say soth by the fey
Be what thou be breke thou not our pley
For euery man saue thou hath tolde his tale
Vnbokyl ⁊ shewe vs what is in thy male
For trewly me thynketh by thy chere
Thou sholdest knyt vp wel a grete matere
Tel vs a fabyl anon for cokkys bonys
This parson hym answerde al attonys
Thou getist fabyl non tolde for me
For Poule that writeth to Tymothe
Repreueth hem that wayuen sothfastnesse
And techen fablis and suche wretchydnesse
Why sholde I sowe draf out of my fist
When I may sowe whete yf that me list
For whiche I say yf that ye list to here
Moralite and of vertuous matere
And than yf ye wyl yeue me audyence
I wolde ful fayn at cristys reuerence
Done you plesaunce leefful as I can
But trustyth wel I am a sotheryn man
I can not geste rum ram ruf by lettir
And god wote ryme holde I but lytil bettir
And therfore yf ye lust I wyl not glose
I wyl you telle a litil tale in prose
To knet vp al this fest ⁊ make an ende
And Ihesu for his grace wyt me sende
To shewe you the wey in thys vyage
Of thylke parfight glorious pylgremage
That hight Iherusalem celestyal
And yf ye vouchesauf anon I shal
Begynne vpon my tale for whiche I preye
Tel your auys I can no better seye
But netheles this meditacion
I put it ay vnder correction
Of clerkys for I am not textuel
I take but the sentence trusteth wel
Therfore I make protestacion
That I wol stonde to correction
Vp on this worde we haue assentid sone
For as it semed it was for to done
To enden in som vertuous sentence
And for to yeue hym space and audyence
And bad our hoost he sholde to hym seye
That al we to telle his tale hym preye
Our hoost had the wordys for vs alle
Syr preest quod he now fayr moot you befalle
Sayth what ye liste and we shul gladly here
And wyth that worde he sayde in this manere
Tellyth quod he your medytacion
But hastyth you the sonne wyl adoun
Beth fructuous and that in litil space
And to do wel god sende you his grace
Here endyth the parsons prologue

div.ab: And here begynneth his tale

Iheremie vj / State super vias et videte ⁊ interrogate de vijs anti
quis / que sit via bona / ⁊ ambulate in ea / ⁊ inuenietis refrigeriūn
animabus vestris ⁊ c̄etc

OVr swete lord god of heuen that no man wil perisshe but
wil that we comen al to the knowlechyng of hym ⁊ to the
blisful lyf that is pardurable

amonesheth vs by the pro-
phete Iheremye that saith in this wyse /

stondeth vpon the weyes / ⁊
see ⁊ axe ye of olde pathys / that is to seye of olde sentencis whiche
is good weye /

And walketh in that weye and that is refressh-
yng for your sowlys /

Many ben the weyes spirituel that leden
folke to our lord Ihesu Cryste / And to the regne of glorye /

Of whyche wayes / There is a ful noble weye and wel coue
nable whyche may not faylle to man ne to woman that thrugh
synne hath mysgoon fro the right weye of Iherusalem celestyal /

And this weye is cleped penytence / Of which man shold gladly
herken and enquyre with al his herte

to wete / what is penytence
or penaunce / And wite whens it is clepyd penytence / And
how many maners ben the actions of werchyng of penytence

⁊
how many spyces there be of penytence / And whiche thynges be
houen and apperteynen to penytence /

Saynt ambrose sayth that
penytence is the pleynyng of the man for the gylte that he hath
do / And nomore to doo ony thyng for the whiche hym ought to
pleyne /

And som doctor sayth / that penaunce is the weymen-
tyng of man that soroweth for his synne / And pyneth hym self
for he hath mysdoon /

Penytence wyth certeyn circumstaunce is
verry repentaunce of man that holdeth hym self in sorowe and o-
ther peyne for his gyltes /

And for he shal be verry penytent
He shal first bewaylen the synnes that he hath don / And stedfast-
ly purpose in his herte to haue shrift of mouth / And to doo
satisfaction

and neuer for to doo thynge for whiche hym oughte
more to bewayle or compleyne / And to contynue in good werkis
Or ellys his repentaunce may not auayle /

For as sayth saynt
Ysodre / He is a Iapar and a gabber and not verey repentaunte /
that eftsones doth thyng for whiche hym oweth to repente ne
stynte to doo synne / may not auayle /

But netheles men shold
take hope that at euery tyme that men falleth be it neuer so ofte
that he may aryse thrugh penytence yf he haue grace / But cer-
teynly it is grete doubte /

For as sayth saynt Gregore / vnnethe
ariseth he out of his synne / that is charged of euyl usage /

And therfore repentaunte folke that stynte for to synne and for
to lete synne or synne forlete hem / Holy chirche holdeth hem siker
of her saluacyon /

And he that synneth and verily repenteth
hym in his laste / Holy chyrche hopyth his saluacion by the
grete mercy of our Lord Ihesu cryste for his repentaunce /
But take ye the siker and certeyn waye /

And now sithe I
haue declared you what thyng is penaunce / Now shul ye
vnderstande that there be thre actions /

The first is that a man be
baptised after that he hath synned /

Saynt Augustyn sayth but
he be penytent for his olde synful lyf / He may not begynne
the newe clene lyf

For yf he be baptised wythout penytence
for hys olde gylte / he reteyneth the marke of baptesme / but not the
grace ne the remyssyon of his synnes til he haue very repentaūnce

Another defaute is that men done dedly synne after they haue
receyued baptesme /

The thirde defaute is that men falle in venyal
synnes after her baptesme fro day to day /

Therof sayth saynt
Austyn that penaunce of good and humble folke is the penytence
of euery day /

The spyces of penaunce ben thre / That one of hem
is solempne / Another is comune / And the thyrd is pryue /

That
penaunce that is solempne is in two maners / as is to be put out
of holy chyrche in lenton for slaughter of chyldren and suche ma
ner thynges /

Another is whan a man hath synned openly / of
whiche synne the fame is openly knowen in the contree and thēmne
holy chyrche by Iugement distreyneth hym for to do open penaunce

Somme penaūnce is that prestes enioyne men comenly in certeyn
caas as for to goo perauenture naked on pylgremage or bare-
foot /

Preuy penaunce is that men doon al day for preuy synnes
of whiche we shryuen vs pryuely and receyuen pryuy penaunce

Now shal thou vnderstonde what behoueth and is necessarye to
euery preuy penytent / and these stonden in thre /

Contricion of
herte / Confessyon of mouth / And satisfaction /

For whyche
Iohan Crisostom sayth / Penytence distreyneth to accepte benyng-
ly euery peyne that is hym enioyned wyth contricion of herte
and shryfte of mouth Wyth satisfaction and worchyng of alle
maner humylite /

And thys is fruytful penaunce ayenst tho
thynges in whiche we wrathen our lord Ihesu cryst /

This is to
saye delyte in thynkyng / By rechelesnes in spekyng / by wicked
and synful worchyng /

Ayenst these wycked gyltes is penaūnce
That may be lykened to a tree /

The rote of thys tre is contricion
that hydeth hym in the herte of hym that is veray repentante right
as the rote of a tree hydeth hym in the erthe /

Of the rote of contri
cyon spryngeth a stalke that bereth braunchys and leuys of
confessyon and fruyt of satisfaction /

Of whiche cryst sayth in
the gospel / Do ye dygne fruyt of penytence / For by this fruyt
men may knowe thys tree and not by the rote that is hyd in
the herte of a man / Ner by the braunchys ne leuys of confessyon

And therfore our lorde Ihesu Criste sayth thus / By the fruyt
of hem ye shal knowe hem /

Of thys rote spryngeth a seed of
grace whiche seed is moder of sykernes / And this seed is eger
⁊ hote /

the grace of this seed spryngeth of god thrugh the remēm
braūnce of the day of dome ⁊ of the peynes of helle /

of this mater
The Tale of the Parson
Salamon sayth that in the drede of god a man forlettith his
synne /

the hete of thys seed is the loue of god and desyryng
of the Ioye perdurable /

This hete draweth the herte of man to
god and doth hym hate his synne /

For there is nothyng that
sauoureth so sote to a chylde as the mylke of his noryce / Ne no
thyng is to hym more abhomynable than that mylke whan it is
medlyd wyth other mylk /

Ryght so the synful man that loueth
his synne / hit semeth it is to hym most swete of ony thyng /

But fro that tyme that he loueth sadly our lord Ihesu cryst and
desireth the lyf pardurable / there is to hym no thyng more abho-
mynabyl /

For soth the loue of god is the lawe of god / For
whiche dauyd the prophete sayth / I haue loued thy lawe and
hated wickednes / he that loueth god kepeth his lawe and hys
worde /

This the prophete danyel enspyred vpon the vysyon
of Nabugodonosor whan he counceylled hym to doo penaunce /

Penaunce is of the tre of lyf to hem that it receyuen / And he
that holdeth hym verry penytent is blessyd after the sentence of

In thys penytence or contricion man shal vnderstonde
four thynges / that is to saye what is contricion / And whyche
ben the causes that meuen a man to contricion / And how he
sholde be contryte / And what contrycion auayleth to the sowle

Than is hit thus that contrycion is the verry sorowe that a man
restreyneth in his herte for his synnes wyth sad purpose to shry-
ue hym and to doo penaunce and neuer more to doo synne /

And
this sorow shal be in thys maner as sayth saynt bernard / Hyt
shal be greuons and heuy and wel sharp and poynaunt in herte

First for a man hath agylted his lord and his creatour / And
more sharpe and poynaunt for he hath agilted his fader celestyal

And yet more sharp and poynaunt for he hath wrathyd hym and
agylte hym that bought hym that wyth his precious blood hath
deliueryd hym from the bondes of synne and fro the cruelte of
the deuyl and fro the peynes of helle /

These causes that meue a
man to contricyon ben vj / First man shal remembre hym of hys
synnes /

but loke that remēmbraūnce be to hym no delite by no weye
but grete shame ⁊ sorow for his gilte / for Iob saith / synful men

Remembre me al the yeres of my lyf in bytternes of my herte /

But for

And that more

And yet
fouler for your long contynuyng in synne and your synful

Suche maner of thoughtis maketh a man a shamed for

Ye
shul remembre you of your weyes / and they shal dysplese yow /
Sothly synnes ben the weyes that lede folk to helle /

The second
cause that ought to make a man haue desdaygn of synne is thys
as sayth saynt Peter / who so doth synne is thral to synne / And

And therfore sayth the
prophete ezechyel I wente sorowful and had disdeygn of my self
Certes wel ought a man haue dysdaign of synne ⁊ withdrawe

For lo what sayth Seneca in
this mater he sayth thus / Though I wist that neyther god
ne man shold neuer knowe it / Yet wold I haue desdaygne
for to do synne /

And the same Seneca sayth I am borne to gret-
ter thynges than to be thralle to my body / more

thral may noman
ne woman make of his body than yeue his body to synne /

And
were it the fowlest chorle or the fowlest woman that lyueth and

uytude

euer fro the hyer degre that a man falleth / The more is he

O good god wel ought a man haue disdeygne of synne sith

and
therfore sayth saynt Austyn / Yf thou hast disdaygne of thy ser-

Take rewarde of thyn owen valew
that thou ne be to foul to thy self ne to thyn /

Alas wel oughten
they that haue disdayn to be seruauntes and thral to synne / Sore

that god of his endles goodnes hath

O good god ye wymmen
that ben of grete beaute remembre you on the prouerbe of salamon

he lykeneth a fayr woman that is a fool of her body to

for right
as a sowe wrotith in euery ordure / so wroteth she her beaute in

The third cause that ought to meue
a man to contrycōmn is drede of the day of dome / And the horrible
paynes of helle /

For as sayth saynt Iherome / At euery tyme
that I remembre of the day of dome / I quake

for whan I ete or
drynke or doo what so I do / euer me semeth the trompe sowneth

Ryseth vp that ben dede and come ye to the Iugement

O good god muche ought a man to drede suche a Iugement there

gement of our lord Ihesu cryst /

where as we shal make a gene-

For certes
there auayleth none essoyne ne none excusacion /

And not only
that our fautes shal be Iuged but eke our werkes shal openly
be knowen /

And that as sayth saynt bernard / There ne shal
no pletyng auayle ne no sleyght / We shal yeue rekenyng of eue

There shal we haue a Iuge that may not be
deceyuyd ne corrupt / And why for certes al our thoughtes be
discouerd as to hym ne for prayer ne for mede he wyl not be cor-
rupt /

And also he sayth / The wrath of god Wyl not spare no
wyght for prayer ne for yeft / And therfore atte day of dome
there is none hope /

wherfore as sayth saynt Ancelme / Ful grete
anguyssh shal the synful folk haue at that tyme

where shal be
the sterne and wroth Iuge syttyng aboue / And vnder hym the

his synnes whiche synnes shullen openly be shewyd before god ⁊
euery creature /

And on the lift syde mo deuylles than the herte
may thynke for to harrye and drawe the synful sowles to the
pytte of helle /

And wythin the hertes of folke shal be the bityng
conscience / And wythout forth shal his werkes accuse hym /

Thenne shal the wretchyd sowle fle to hyde hym / But certes he
may not hyde hym he must come forth and shewe hym /

For certes
as sayth saynt Iherome / the erthe shal cast hym out of hym and
the see also and the ayer also that shal be ful of thunder clappys

and lightnyng /

Now sothly who so wyl remembre hym of these
thynges I gesse that his synnes shal not torne hym to delyte but

And therfor sayth
Iob to god / Suffre lord that I may a whyle bewayle ⁊ bewepe
or I go retornyng to the derk erthe and coueryd wyth derkenes

the londe of myserye and of derknes where as is shadow of deth
where as there is none other ordenaunce but grysly drede that
euer shal laste /

Lo here may ye see that Iob prayed respyte a
whyle to bewepe and wayle his trespaas / For sothly one day
to respyte is bettir than al the tresour of thys world /

And for
as muche as a man may acquyte hym self by fore god by peny-
tence in thys worlde and not by tresour / Therfor shold he praye
to god to yeue hym respyte a whyle to bewepyn and bewaylen
his trespaas /

For certes al the sorow that a man myght make
fro the begynnyng of the worlde nys but a lityl thyng at the re-
garde of the sorow of helle /

The cause why that Iob clepeth the
lond of derknes /

vnderstondyth that he clepyth hit londe or erthe
for it is stable and neuer shal fayle derkenes / For he that is in
helle hath defaute of light naturel /

For certes the derke light that
shal come out of the fyre that euer shal brenne shal torne hem all
to peyne that be in helle / For it sheweth hym al the horryble de-
uylles that hem tormente
couerd wyth the derknes of deth that

ben the synnes that the wretchyd man hath don / whyche that des

twene vs and the sonne /

Londe of mysese by cause that there be
thre defautes ayenst thre thynges that folke of thys world
haue in thys present lyf / that is to saye / honouris / delytes / and
ryches /
Ayenst honour haue they in helle shame and confusion /

For wel ye wote they clepen honour the reuerence that men don
to men / But in helle is non honour ne reuerence / For certes
no more reuerence shal be there to a kyng than a knaue /

For
whiche god sayth by the prophete Iheremye / The folke that me
dispysen shal be in despyte /

Honour is eke clepyd a grete lordship
there shal no wyght seruen other / but of harme and turmente /
Honour is eke clepyd grete dignyte and hyghnes / but in helle
shal they alle be fortroden wyth deuylles

as god sayth / The
horryble deuylles shulle goo and comyn vpon the hedys of damp
nyd folke / And this is for as muche that the hyer that they

were in thys present lyf the more they shul be abated and defow
led in helle /

Ayenst the ryches of thys world / shal they haue
mysese of pouerte / And thys pouerte shal be in four thynges

In
defaute of tresour of whiche Dauyd sayth / The ryche folke that
enbracen and coueten in al her herte the ryches of thys world
shul slepe in the slepyng of deth / as no thyng shul they fynde
in there hondes of al her tresour /

And more ouer the mysese of
of helle shal be in defaute of mete and drynke /

For god sayth
thus by moyses / ye shal be wasted wyth hunger / And the byr

And ferther ouer her mysese shal be in
defaute of clothyng for they shal be nakyd in body as of clothyng
Saue the fyre in whiche they brenne and other fylthes /

And
naked shal they be in sowle of al maner vertues / whiche that is

Lo what sayth god of hem by the
prophete Ysaye / that vnder hem shal be strawed mothes and her

And furtherouer her
mysese shal be in defaute of frendes for he is not poure that hath

For neyther god ne good
creature shal be frende to hem / And euery of hem shal hate other
wyth dedely hate /

The sones and the doughters shal rebelle ayenst
the fader and moder / And kynrede ayenst kynrede and chyden
and despysen eche other both day and nyght / as god sayth by the
prophete mycheas /

And the louyng chyldren that somme tyme
loueden so flesshly eueriche of them wolde ete other yf he myght

For how shold they loue to gyder in the peynes of helle / whan
they hated eche other in the prosperyte of thys lyf /

For truste
wel her flesshly loue is dedely hate as sayth the prophete Dauyd
who so louyth wickednes he hateth his owen sowle /

And who so
hateth his owen sowle / Certes he may loue non other wyght in
no manere /

And therfore in helle is no frendshyp but euer the
more cursyng the more chydyng and the more dedely hate is
among hem /

And furtherouer they shal haue defautes of alle
maner delytes / for why / For delytes ben appetites of the wit-
tes as sight / Heeryng / smellyng / sauouryng / and touchyng /

but
in helle her sighte shal be ful of derknes / of smoke and ful of

Her nostrylles shal be ful of styn
kyng / And as sayth Ysaye the prophete / Her sauouryng shalle

And as touchyng her body it shal be coue
ryd wyw fyre that neuer shal be quenchyd / And with wormys

⁊ for

certes a shadowe hath a

ryght so faryth the

For as saith saynt Gregore / to wretchyd

For her deth shal alway lyue / And her ende

And therfore sayth Saynt Iohan the Euangeliste / They shalle

And eke Iob sayth that in helle is
none ordre of rule /

And al be it so that god hath created al
in ryght ordre / and nothyng without ordre / But al thynges

For the erthe shal bere
hem no fruyt /

For as the prophete Dauyd sayth / God shal des

For as sayth saynt Basyle / The brennyng of the fyre of this

But the

Right as the good man yeueth brede to his children and bones

And so they shal haue non hope to escape / And

Horrour is alle way drede of harme
that is to come / And this drede shal euer dwelle in the hertes of

First for god that is her Iuge shal be wythouten

ne they haue no voys to

And therfor saith

Who so wolde wel vnder-

For as sayth

That scyence sayth saynt Austyn makith a man to wey-

The fourth poynt that a man ought to
make contricion fore / is the sorouful remembraunce of the good

Sothly the good werkys that he hath left / eyther they be

Sothly the good that he dyd beforne that he fyl in dedely

The other werkes that he wrought whyle he lay in synne ben vt-

Than thylke good
werkes that ben mortefyed by eft synnyng whiche good werkes
he dyde whiles he was in charite mowe neuer quycken ayen with
out verey restreynt

and wythdrawyug the strenges of mannys
corage and the meuynges in his herte in suche manere as they ne

And therof sayth god by the
mouth of Ezechyel / That yf the rightful man retorne agayn

nay / For al the good werkys that he hath wrought shulle ne

And
vpon that chappytre sayth saynt gregory thus that we shul vnder
stonde pryncipally

that whan we do dedely synne it is nought /
Neyther for to drawe in to memorye the good werkys that we
haue wrought byforn /

For certes in the werkyng of dedely
synne there is no trust to good werke that we haue don beforn /
That is to say as to haue therby the lyf perdurale in heuen /

But
sothly the good werkys that men don whyles they ben in dedely
synne for as mykyl as they were don in dedely synnethey may
neuer quycken /

For certes thynges that neuer
had lyf may neuer quycken / And netheles al be it that they

or
ellys that god wyl rather enlumyne and lyghten the herte of

And eke they auayle to a

And thus the curteys lord Ihesu cryst wyl that no

but for
as moche that the good werkes that men don whyles they ben in

wel may that

For certes it bereueth a
man goodnes and nature and eke the goodnes of grace /

for soth
the grace of the holy goost fareth as fyre that may not be ydle /
For fyre fayleth anon as it leseth his werchyng /

Than leseth the
synful man the goodnes of glorye that only is behoten to good

Wel may he be sory thenne that
oweth al his lyf to god as long as he lyueth / And eke as

For trust wel he shall
yeue acountys / as sayth saynt bernard / Of alle the goodes that

ded them

not so muche that there shal perisshe an heer of his heed

The fyfthe thyng is that ought to meue a man to contrycion is

For as sayth saynt Bernard / whylis that I lyue I

his werynes in trauelyng / his temptacions
whan he fasted / his long wakynges whan he prayd / his teris

the woo and the shame
and the fylthe that men sayden to hym / of the foule spyttyng

of the nayles wyth the whiche he was nayled to the crosse
And of alle the remenaunt of his passyon that he suffryd for

And ye shal vnder-
stande that euery maner ordre of ordenaunce is torned vp so

doun /

For it is soth that god and reson and sensualite and
the body of a man ben so ordeyned / that eueryche of thyse four
thynges shul haue lordshyp ouer that other

as thus god shold
haue lordshyp ouer reson / And reson ouer sensualite and sensua-
lite ouer the body of man /

but sothly in man semeth al this order
of ordenaunce is turned vp so doun /

And therfore thenne for
as mykyl as the reson of man wyl not be subget ne obeissaunt to
god that is lord by right / Therfore leseth it the lordshyp that it
sholde haue in sensualite and eke ouer the body of man /

And
Why for sensualite rebelleth thenne ayenst reson / And by that wey
lesith reson his lordshyp ouer sensualite and ouer the body /

For ryght as reson is rebel to god / Ryght so is sensualite rebel
to reson and the body also /

And certes thys ordenaunce / And
thys rebellyon our lord Ihesu Crist aboughte upon his body well
deer / And herkeneth in Whyche wyse /

For as mykel thenne as
reson is rebel to god therfore is man worthy to haue sorowe and
to be dede /

This suffryd our lord Ihesu for man after he was be-
trayed of his disciple and distreyned and bounde so that the blood
brast out at euery nayle of his hondes as sayth saynt Augustyn /

And ferthermore for as mykyl as reson of man wyl not daunte
sensualite whan it may / Therfore is man worthy to haue shame
And this suffred our lord Ihesu criste for man whan they spitten
in his vysage /

And ferther ouer thenne for as muche as the
caytif body of man is rebel both to reson and to sensualite therfore
it is worthy the dethe /

And thys suffrid our lord Ihesu Cryst
for man vpon the crosse / Where as there was no parte of his bo
dy fre thythout grete peyn ⁊ bitter passyon /

And al this suffred
Ihesu cryst that neuer forfeted / To muche am I peyned for tho
thynges that I neuer deseruyd and to mykyl defouled for frend
shyp that man is worthy to haue /

And therfore may the synful
man wel saye as saynt bernard sayth / Acursid be the bytternes /

For certis after dyuerse dyscordaunces of our wyckednes was
the pasciyon of Ihesu crist y ordeyned in dyuerse thynges

as thus
Certes synful mannys soule betrayed the deuyl by couetyse of

for thys dyscordaunce of synful man / was Ihesu Cryst

Thenne was he bescourged
that only shold be honourid in al thynges and of alle thynges

Thenne was his vysage bespytte that ought to be desyred for to

Thenne was he scorned

Thenne were complysshed the wordes of Ysaye that
sayth / He was wounded for our mysdedes and defouled for

Now sith that Ihesu cryst toke on hym self the
peyne of al our wyckednes / mykyl ought synful man to wepe

The xj thyng that ought to meue a
man to contricion is the hope of thre thynges that is to saye for-
geuenes of synne / and the yefte of grace wel for to do / And
the ioye of heuen wyth the whyche god shal guerdon man for his

And for as muche as Ihesu Crist yeueth vs the yef
tis of his grace ⁊ of his souerayn bounte / Therfore is he clepyd
Ihesus Nazerenus Rex Iudeorum /

Ihesus is for to saye sauy-
our or sauacion on whom men shul hopen to haue foryeuenes of

And
therfore sayd the aungel to Ioseph / Thou shalt clepe hys name
Ihesus that shal saue his peple of her synnes /

And herof sayth
seynt peter / There is none other name vnder heuyn that is yeuen
to ony man by whyche a man may be sauyd but only Ihesus /

Nazarenus is as muche to saye as for florisshyng in which a man

thyng in vanyte /

There is also costlew furryng in gownes / And
also mykyl pounsyng of chesel to make hoolis so mykil daggyng
of sheris

with the superfluyte in lengthe of the forsayd gownys
traylyng in the dung and in the myre on hors and eke on fooot
as wel of man as of woman / that al that treylyng is verily as
in effect wasted / consumed / thredbare and roten wyth dung ra-
ther than it is yeuen to the poure / to grete domage of the forsayd
poure folke

and that in sondry wyse / thys is to sayn the more
that cloth is wasted the more must hit coste for the scarsenes /

And furtherouer yf they wolde yeue suche pounsid and daggid
clothes to the pour folke / it is not conuenyent to were for her
estate ne suffycient to her necessyte /

On that other syde for to speke
of the disordynat scantnes of clothyng as ben these cutted sloppis
or hanselynes that thrugh her shortnes couer not the shamefull
membres of a man to wicked entente /

Alas somme of hem
shewen in the shap and the boos of the horryble swollyn membris
that semen like to the maladye of hyrma in the wrappyng of her
hosyn

and eke the buttokkys of hem behynd that faren as it
were the hynderparte as a she ape in the ful of the mone /

And
more ouer the Wretchyd swellyng membris that they shewe in
The Tale of the Parson
disgisyng in departyng of her hosyn whyt and rede semeth that
half the preuy membrys weren fleyn /

And so by that they depar
ten her hosen in other colours as is whyt and black / or whyt and
blewe / or black and reed and so forth /

Than semeth it as by
varyannce of colour that half the part of his preuy membrys ben
corupt by the fyre of saynt antonye / or by Canker / or by other
suche myschaunces /

yet of the hynder parte of her buttoks it is
wel horryble for to see / For certes in that partye of her body
there as they purgen her stynkyng ordure /

that foul party shewe
they proudly to the peple in despyte of honeste / whiche honeste that
Ihesu crist and his frendes obserued to shewe in his lyf /

Now as to outerageous aray of woman / god woote though
the visage of hem seme ful chast and debonayr / yet notefyen they
in theyr araye of a tyre / lichorousnes and pryde /

I saye not that
honeste in clothyng of man and woman is vncouenable / But
certes the superfluyte or dysordynat skarcete of clothyng is repro
uable /

Also the synne of ornement or in appareyl as in thynges
that apperteyne to ridyng / as in many delycat horses that be hol-
den for delyte by cause they be so fayr fat and costlewe /

and also
many a vicious knaue mayntened by cause of hem / And in cu-
ryous harneys as in sadles / cropers / peytrellys / and brydels
couyrd wyth precious cloth and riche barres and plates of gold
and siluer /

For whiche god sayth by Zakarie the prophete / I wil
confounde the ryders on suche horsis

These folk taken litil regarde
of rydyng of goddes sone and his harneys whan he rood vpon
an asse and had non other harneys but the clothys of hys poure
disciples / Ne we rede not that he rode euer on ony other beste /

I
speke thus that of superfluyte / not for the honeste Whan reson it
requyreth /

And fertherouer certes pryde is gretly notifyed in
holdyng of grete meyne whan they be of litil prouffyt /

And na
mely Whan the meyne is felenous and domageous to the peple
by hardynes of her lordshyp or by weye of offyce /

For certes
suche lordys sellen her lordshippes to the deuyl of helle / whan they
susteyne the wickednes of her meyne /

or ellys whan these folke
of lowe degre as they that holden hostelryes susteyn theft by theyr
hostelers and that is in many maners of disceytes /

suche maner
of folk ben the flyes that folowen the hony / Or ellis the houn-
des that folowen the careyn whiche forsayd folke stranglen
The Tale of the Parson
spirituelly her lordshyp /

For whiche thus sayth dauyd wickednes
moot come on the lordshippis / And god geue that they mowe
descende doun in to helle / For in her howses is inyquyte and
shrewdnes and not god of heuen /

And certes yf thou doo no
mendement right as god yaf his blessyng to laban by cause of
Iacob and to Pharao for the seruyce of Ioseph / Right so wyl
god yeue his malyson to suche lordes that susteyne the wicked-
nes of her seruauntes / But the comyn

pride of the table apperith
eke ful ofte / For certes riche men be clepyd to festys and poure
folk be put awey and rebuked /

And there is excesse of dyuerce
metes and drynkes and namely of curious maner of bakemetis
and of semblable wast so that it is abusion for to thynke /

And
eke in grete preciousnes of vessel and curiosite of mynystralcye
by the whiche a man is styred more to the delites of luxurye

Yf
so be that he sette his herte the lesse vpon our lord Ihesu Cryst
certeyn it is a synne / And certes the delicate metis and the de
lite myght be so grete in the caas that men myght the lightlyer
falle by hem in to dedely synne /

The spyces that sourden of pryde
Sothly is whan they sourden of malice ymagyned and auysed
and forn cast or ellys of vsage / ben dedely synnes it is no doubte

And whan they sourden by freelte vnauysed sodeynly / ⁊ sodenly
Wythdrawe agayn / al be they greuous synnes / I gesse and
suppose they be not dedely /

Now myght men axe Wherof that
pride sourdeth and spryngeth / And I say that somtyme it spryn
geth of goodes of nature / And somtyme of the goodes of fortune
And somtyme of the goodes of grace /

Certes the goodes of natu
re stonden in the goodes of body or of soule /

Certes the goodes
of the body ben hele of body / strengthe / delyuernes / beaute / gen
trye aud fraunchises /

The goodes of nature of the soule ben / good
witte wyth sharpe vnderstondyng / subtil engyne / vertu naturel
good memorye

Goodes of fortune ben riches / high degrees of
lordshyppis and preisynges of the peple /

Goodes of grace been
science / power to suffre spirituel trauayle / benygnytees / vertuous
contemplacion / withstandyng of temptacion and semblable thyn
ges /

Of whiche forsayde goodes certes it is a grete folye a man
to priden hym in ony of hem alle /

Now as for to speke of goodes
of nature god wote that som tyme we haue them in nature as
muche to our domage as to our prouffyt /

As for to speke of hele
The Tale of the Parson
of body certes it passyth ful lightly / And eke it is ful ofte
thencheson of the sikenes of the soule / For god woot the flessh
is a ful grete enemy to the soule / And therfore the more that a
body is hool / the more be we in paryl to falle /

Eke for to pryde
hym in his strengthe of body it is a grete folye / For certes the
flessh coueyteth ayenst the spyrite / And euer the more stronger
the flessh is / the soryer may the soule be /

And ouer al thys
strength of the body ⁊ worldly hardynes causeth ful ofte many
men to perylle and myschaunce /

Eke for to pryde hym of hys
genterye / it is ful grete folye / For oft tyme the gentery of the
body begynneth of the gentrye of the soule / And eke we be alle
of one fader and of one moder / And al we ben of one nature
rotyn and corupt both ryche and poure /

For soth a maner gen-
trye is for to preyse that appareylleth mannes corage wyth vertu
es or moralitees and makyth hym a Crysten chylde /

For trusteth
wel that what man that synne hath ouer maystryde is very chorl
to synne /

Now ben there thre general thynges of gentilnes as
eschewyng of vyces or rybauldrye And seruage of synne in
worde and werke in countenaunce

And vsyng vertu as curtesye
clennesse and to be lyberalle that is to saye large by mesure / For
that that passyth mesure is folye and synne /

Another is that he
remembre hym of the bounte that he of other folk hath receyuyd

Another is to be benygne ouer his subgette / wherfore as
sayth Seneke / There is no thyng more couenable to man of high
estate than debonayrte /

and these flyes that men clepen bees whan
they make her kyng / they chesen one that hath non prycke wher-
wyth he may stynge /

Another is a man to haue a noble herte
and a diligent tatteyn to hye vertuous thynges /

Certes also
who that prydeth in the goodes of fortune he is ful like a greet
fole / For somtyme a man is a ful grete man by the morowe
that is a wretche or a caytif or it be nyght /

And somtyme dely-
tes of mān ben cause of greuous maladye thorugh which he deyeth

Certes the commendacion of the peple is somtyme ful fals and
ful brotyl for to truste This day they preyse / to moroWe they
blame /

god woot / Eke desire to haue comendacion of the peple
hath causid deth to many a man /

Now certes a man to pryde
hym in the goodes of grace is eke an outrageous folye for the
yeftes of grace that shold haue torned hym to goodnes and to
The Tale of the Parson
medecyne tornyth to venym and to confusion / as sayth saynt Gre-
gore /

Now sith that so is that ye haue vnderstonde what is pride
and whiche be the spyces of hit / And hoW mennys pride sour-
deth and spryngyth /

Now shal ye vnderstonde whiche is the re-
medye agaynst pryde / And that is humylite or mekenes /

That
is a vertu thrugh whiche man hath very knowleche of hym self
and holdeth of hym self no deynte ne no pryce as in regarde of
his desertes consideryng euer his freelte /

Now ben there thre
maners ef humylite / as humylite in herte / and another in the
mouth / And the thyrde in werkys /

The humylite in herte is in
four maners that is whan a man holdeth hym self as nought
worth byfore god of heuyn / Another is whan he despyseth none
other man /

The thyrd is / that he reckyth not though men holde
hym nought / The fourth is whan he is not sory of his humylia
cion /

Also the humyliacion of mouth is in four thynges / In
attemperat speche / And whan he knoweth with his owen mouth
that he is suche as he thynketh that he is in his herte / Another
whan he preyseth the debonayrte of another man / And also no
thyng therof amenusith /

Humylite eke in Werkis is in four ma
ners / The first is whan he put men before hym / The second is to
chese the lowest place / The thyrd is gladly to assente to good
counceyl /

The fourth is gladly to stonde in obedyence of his so-
uereyn or of hym that is higher in degre / Certes that is a grete
werk of humylite /
Sequitur de Inuidia

AFter pryde wyl I speke of the foule synne of enuye /
whiche that is as by the worde of the phylosopre sorow
of other mennys prouffyt / And after the worde of
seynt Austyn it is sorow of other mennys wele and
Ioye of other mennys harm /

This foule synne is platly ayenst
the holy ghoost / Al be it so that euery synne is ayenst the holy
ghoost / yet for as muche as bounte apperteyneth to the holy ghoost
properly / And enuye cometh properly of malice / Therfore it is
properly ayenst the bounte of the holy ghoost /

Now hath malice
two spyces that is to saye hardynes of herte and wyckednes / or
The Tale of the Parson
ellys the flessh of man is so blynde that he considereth not that he
is in synne / whiche is the hardynes of the deuyl /

That other
spyce of enuye is whan a man warryth ayenst trouth whan that
he woot that it is trouth / And eke whan that he warryth the
grace that god hath yeue to his neyghbour / And al thys is
enuye /

certes than is enuye the werst synne that is / For sothly
al other synnes be som tyme ayenst one special vertu /

But certes
enuye is ayenst al maner vertues and alle goodnes / For it is
sory of al bounte of his neyghbours / And in thys maner it is
dyuerse from al synnes /

For vnnethe is there ony synne that it
ne hath som delyte in hym self saue only enuye that euer hath in
hym self anguysshe and sorowe /

The spyces of enuye ben thyse
There is first sorowe of other mennys goodnes / And of her pros
peryte ought to be kyndly mater of Ioye / Thenne is enuye a synne
ayenst kynde /

The seconde spice of enuye is ioye of other mennys
harme /

Of this second spyce cometh bakbytyng or detraction that
hath two spices as thus / Som men preyse her neyghbour by
wicked entente /

For he maketh alway a wicked knotte at the
last ende alway he maketh a but that is signe of more blame
than worth is alle the preysyng /

The second spice is that a man
be good and doo and saye a thyng to good entente / The bacbiter
wyl torne al the goodnes vp so doun to his shrewd entente /
The thiyd is to amenuse the bounte of his neyghbour /

The fourth
spice of bacbytyng is this that yf men speke goodnes of a man
the bacbyter wil saye / perfay yet is suche a man better than he /
in dispreysyng of hym that men prayse /

The fifthe is to consente
gladly to herkne the harme that men speken of other folke / this
synne is ful grete and ay encresith after the wicked entente of
the bacbiter /

After bacbytyng comyth grutchyng or murmurance
And somtyme it spryngeth of Impacience ayenst god ⁊ somtyme
ayenst man /

Ayenst god is whan a man grutchith agaynst the
payne of helle / or ayenst pouerte or losse of catel or ayenst rayn or
tempest / or ellis grutcheth that shrewes haue prosperite / or ellys
that good men haue aduersite

And al these thynges shold men
suffre paciently / For they comen by the rightful Iugement and
ordynaunce of god /

Somme tyme cometh grutchyng of auarice
as Iudas grutchyd ayenst Magdalene whan she anoynted the hede
of our lord Ihesu crist with her precious oynement /

This maner
The Tale Of the Parson
of murmur is suche as whan men grutchen of goodnes / of that
men hem self doon / or that other folke doon of her owen catel /

Somtyme comyth murmur of pryde as whan Symon the pharise
grutchyd ayenst magdaleyn whan she approchid to Ihesu Cryst /
And wept at his feet for her synnes /

And somtyme it sourdeth
of enuye whan men discoueren a mannys harm that was pryue
or berith hym on honde thyng that is fals /

Murmur is eke ofte
among seruauntes whan her souerayns bydden hem doo leeful
thynges /

And for as muche as they dar not openly wythsaye the
commaundement of her mayster / yet wyl they saye harme and
grutche and murmure pryuely for very despyte /

whiche wordes
men clepe the deuyls pater noster / though so be the deuyl had ne-
uer pater noster / but that folke yeue suche a name /

somtyme
it cometh of yre or of pryue hate that noryssheth rancour in herte
as after I shal declare /

Thenne cometh eke bitternes of herte
Thrugh whiche bitternes euery good dede of hys neyghbour se-
meth to hym bytter and vnsauorye /

Than comyth dyscorde that
vnbyndeth alle maner of frendshyp / Thenne comyth scornyng of
his neyghbour al doo he neuer so wel /

thenne cometh accusyng
as whan men seken occasion to annoye his neyghbour / which that
is like the craft of the deuyl that wayteth both nyght and day to
accusen vs alle /

Thenne cometh malignyte thrugh whiche a man
noyeth his neyghbour pryuyly yf he may /

And yf he nought
may algate his wycked wyl shal not wante as for to brenne
his hous pryuely or empoysen hym or slee his bestys and sembla
ble thynges /

Now wyl I speke of the remedye of this foul
synne of enuye / The first is the loue of god pryncipally ⁊ louyng
of hym self and of his neyghbour / For sothly that one may
not be Wythout that other /

And crist wyl in the name of thy
neyghbour that thou shalt vnderstonde thy broder / For certes all
we haue one fader flesshly and one moder that is to saye / Adam
and Eue / And eke one fader spirituel / that is to saye god of
heuen /

Thy neyghbour art thou holde for to loue and wyl hym
alle goodnes / And therfore sayth god / loue thy neyghbour as
thy self that is to saye to lyf and to soule and saluacion /

And
more ouer thou shalt loue hym in worde and benygne chere and
monysshyng and chastysyng in a voys to comforte hym ⁊ praye
for hym wyth alle thy herte /

And in dede thou shalt loue hym
The Tale Of the Parson
in suche wyse that thou shalt doo to hym in charite as thou wol-
dest were don to thyn owen persone /

And therfore thou shalt doo
to hym no domage in wycked worde ne harme in his body ne in
his catel ne in his sowle by entysyng of Wycked ensaumple /

Thou shalt not desire his Wyf ne none of his thynges / Vnder-
stande eke that in the name of thy neyghbour is comprehendyd
his enemye /

Certes a man shal loue his enemye for the cōmmaun
dement of god / And sothly thy frende shalle thou loue in god /

I say thyn enemye shalle thou loue for goddys sake by his com-
maundement / For it were reson a man shold hate his enemye /
For soth god wil not receyue vs to his loue that ben his enemyes

Ayenst thre maner wronges that his enemye doth to hym he shall
do thre thynges as thus /

ayenst hate and rancour of herte he shal
loue hym in herte / ayenst chydyng and wycked Wordes he shall
praye for his enemye / Ayenst the wicked dede of hys enemye he
shal do hym bounte /

For Crist sayth loueth your enemyes and
prayeth for hem that speketh you harme and eke for hem that you
chasen and pursuen and do bounte to hem that you haten / Lo
thus commaundeth vs our lord Ihesu Crist to do to our enemyes

For soth nature dryueth vs to loue our frendes / And perfey our
enemyes haue more nede to loue than our frendes / And they that
more nede haue / Certes to hem shal we doo goodnes /

and certes
in that dede haue remembraunce of the loue of Ihesu Crist that
deyde for his enemyes /

And for as muche as that loue is the more
greuous to perfourme / so muche is more grete the meryte / And
therfore the louyng of our enemye hath confounded the venym of
the deuyl /

For right as the deuyl is s comfited by humylite /
Right so is he Wounded to the deth by the loue of our enemye /

Certes than is loue medicyne that chaseth out the venym of enuye
fro mannys herte /
Sequitur de Ira

AFter Enuye wyl I declare of the synne of Ire / For
soth he that hath enuye vpon his neyghbour / Anon co-
mynly wyl fynde hym mater of wrathe in worde or in
dede / Ayenst hym to whom he hath enuye

for sothly he that is
I j
The Tale of the Parson
proud or enuyous is lightly wroth /

This synne of Ire after
dyscryuyng of saynt Austyn is wycked wyll to be auengyd by
worde or by dede /

Ire after the phylosophre is the feruent blood
of man y quyckend in his herte / thrugh whiche he wyl harme
to hym that he hateth /

For certes the herte of man by enchafyng
and meuyng of his blood wexyth so trobled that he is out of
al Iugement of resons /

But ye shul vnderstonde that Ire is in
two maners / Oon of hem is good and that other is wycked /

The good Ire is by Ielousye of goodnes thrugh the whiche a man
is wroth with wickednes ⁊ agayn wickednes / ⁊ therfore saith the
wise man that Ire is better than playe /

this yre is with deboneyrte
⁊ it is wrath wythout bytternes not wroth agaynst the man / but
wroth wyth the mysdede of the man as sayth the prephete / Irasci-
mini et nolite peccare /

Now vnderstonde that wicked Ire is in ij
maners that is to say sodeyn yre or hasty Ire wythout auysement
and consentyng of his reson /

The menyng and the sense of thys
is that reson of a man ne consentith not to that sodeyn yre / And
than is hit venyal /

Another Ire is that is ful wycked that co-
meth of felonye of herte auysed and cast byfore wyth wycked
wyl to doo vengeance / ⁊ therto his reson consentith ⁊ sothly thys
is dedely synne /

This yre is so dyspleysaunt to god that it
troublith his hous and chasith the holy ghoost out of mannys
soule

and put in hym the sekenes of the deuyl and benymeth the
man fro god that is his rightful lorde /

This yre is a ful grete
plesaunce to the deuyl for it is the deuyllis furneys that he en-
chaunsith with the fire of helle /

For certes as fyre is more migh
ty to destroye erthly thynges than another element / Right so Ire
is myghty to destroye al spirituel thynges

Loke how that fyre of
smale gledys that be almost dede vnder asshen wyl quycken ayen
When they be touched wyth brymstone / right so yre wyl euermore
quycken agayn whan it is touchid with pride that is couerid in
mannys herte /

For certes pride may not come out of no thyng but
yf hit were first in the same thyng naturelly as fire is drawen
out of flyntis with steel /

right so is pride a mater of yre / right as
rancour is norissher and kepar therof /

There is a maner tree as
saith saynt Isodore / That whan men make fire of that tre and co-
uer the colys of hit wyth asshen / Sothly the fyre therof wol laste
al a yere or more /

And right so farith it by rancour / whan he is
The Tale Of the Parson
ones conceyued in the hertes of somme men / Certes it Wyl laste
perauenture from one ester day Tyl an other or more /

But certes
that man is ful ferre from the mercy of god al that whyle /

In this forsayd deuylles forneys they forgen thre shreWys /
Pryde than bloWeth and encresith the fyre by chydyng and wyc-
kyd wordes /

Thenne stondeth enuye and holdeth the yron vpon
the hertes of men / Wyth a payer of long tonges with longe ran-
cour /

And thenne stont the synne of contynuel stryf and cheest
and betith and forgyth the vylayns reprouynges /

Certes this
cursid synne anoyeth both the man hym self and eke his neygh-
bour / For sothly almost al the harm that ony man doth to his
neyghbour cometh of wrath /

For certes outrageous wrath doth
al that euyr the deuyl commaundeth hym / For he spareth neyther
for Crist ne his swete moder

in his outrageous anger and Ire
but spekyth and sklaundryth his neyghbour /

this is a cursyd
lyf whiche lyf shold be debonayr and spirituel that shold kepe
his sowle /

Certes this Ire or wrath bynymeth eke goddys due
lordshyp and that is mannys soWle and the loue of his neygh-
bours / hit stryueth alleway eke ayenst trouth / hit reueth hym
the quyete of his herte and subuertith his sowle /

Of Ire comen
thyse stynkyng engendrures / First hate that is olde wrath rene-
wyd / thrugh whiche a man forsaketh his owen frend that he hath
louyd so long /

⁊ thenue comyth werre and euery maner of wrong
that a man doth to his neyhhbour in body or in catel /

Of thys
cursid synne of Ire cometh eke manslaughter / And vnderstondeth
wel that manslaughter is in dyuerse Wyse / Somme maner of
manslaughter is spirituel / And Som bodely /

Spirituel man-
slaughter is in sixe thynges / First by hate as sayth seynt Iohn /
he that hateth his broder is an homycyde /

Manslaughter is eke by
bacbytyng of whyche bacbytours sayth Salamon that they haue
tWo swerdys with whiche they sle her neyghbours / For sothly
as wicked it is to benyme his good name as his lyf /

homycide
is eke in yeuyng of wycked counceyl by fraude / or for to yeue
counceyl for to areyse wrongful customys and talagys

of
whyche speketh Salamon / Lyon roryng and bere hungry ben
lykenyd to cruel lordes / In wythholdyng or abbredgyng of
the hyre or wagys of poure folke /

For whiche the wise man saith
Fede ye hym that almost dyeth for hungre / For sothly
