but yf thou fede hym thou sleest hym / And al thyse ben dedely syn
nys /

Bodely manslaughter is whan thou sleest hym wyth thy
tunge / Another maner is whan thou commaundest to sle a man
or ellys yeuest hym counceyl to sle a man

Manslaughter in dede
is in four maners / That one is by lawe / right as a Iustyce
dampneth hym that is culpable to the deth / but lete the Iustyce
bewaar that he doo it rightfully and that he doo it not for delyte
to spylle blood but for kepyng of rightwysnes /

Another homy
cyde is don for necessyte as Whan a man sleeth another his defen
daunt and that he ne may otherwyse ascape fro his owen deth /

But certeyn and he may escape wythout slaughter of his aduer
sarye and sleeth hym he doth synne / And he shal bere penaunce
as for dedely synne /

Eke yf a man by caas or auenture shete an
arowe or cast a stoon wyth whiche he sleeth a man it is homycyde

Eke yf a woman by neclygence ouer lyeth her chylde in slepyng
It is homycide and dedely synne /

Eke whan a man destroyeth
concepcion of a chylde or makyth a woman bareyn by drynkes of
venymous herbes thrugh whyche she may not conceyue / Or sleeth
her chylde by drynkes / or ellys putteth certeyn materyal
thyng in her secrete place to slee her childe /

Or ellys doth vnkynde
synne / by whyche man or woman shedyth his nature in place
there as a chylde may not be conceyued / Or ellys yf a woman
haue conceyued and hurte her self and sleeth her chyld /
Yet is it homycyde

what saye we eke of women that murdren her
chyldren for drede of worldly shame / Certes it is eke an
horryble homycyde /

Eke yf a man approche to a Woman by desire
of lecherye thrugh whiche the chylde is perisshed ellys smyteth a
woman wetyngly by whyche her chylde is slayn / Alle thyse
ben homycydes and dedely horryble synnys /

Yet comyn of yre
many moo synnes as in worde in thought in dede as wel as he
that aretteth vpon god or blasphemyth god of whyche he is
hym self gylty or despyseth god and alle his halowes as doon
thyse cursyd hasourdours in dyuerse contrees /

Thys cursyd synne do they whan they felen in her herte ful
wyckedly of god and hys halowes /

Also whan they treten
vnworthely the sacrament of the awter / Thylke synne is so
grete / that vnnethe may it be relecid but that the mercy of god
passyth his werkys / whiche mercy is grete and benygne /
The Tale Of the Parson

/ There cometh also of yre a tery anger whan a man is sharply a-
monesshed in his shrift to forlete his synne /

Than Wil he be angry
and answere okirly ⁊ angerly to defende or excusyn his synne /
by vnstedfastnes of his flessh / or ellys he dyd hit for to holde
company with his felawes / or ellis he sayth / the fende entised hym

or ellis he dyd hit for his yougth / or ellys his complexyon is so
corageous that he may not forbere / ellys it is destyne as he sayth
vnto a certeyn age / or ellis he saith it comyth hym of gentilnes of
his auncetryes and semblable thynges /

Al thise maner of folke
so wrappyn hem in her synnes that they wyl not delyuer hem self /
For sothly no wyght that excusith hym wilfully of his synne /
may be delyuerd of his synne / til he mekely beknowith his synne

After thenne cometh sweryng that is expres ayenst the commaūn
dement of god and thys befallith of anger and of yre /

God
sayth thou shalt not take the name of thy lord in ydyl / Also
our lord Ihesu crist sayth by the Worde of saynt mathew /

ne wyl
ye to sWere in al maner / neyther by heuen for hit is goddys trone
neyther by erthe for it is the benche of his feet / ne by Iherusalem
for it is the cyte of a grete kynge / ne by thyn hede / for thou ne
mayst make an heer whyte ne black /

but youre othe shal be / ye / ye
nay / nay / And what that is more euyl / thus sayth crist /

For
cristes sake swere ye not so synfully in dysmembryng of Crist /
by soule / herte / bonys / and body / For ye thynke that the
cursyd Iewys dysmembryd hym not ynough but ye dysmembre
hym more /

And yf so be that lawe compelle yow to swere thēmne
rewle yow after the lawe of god in your sweryng / As sayth
seynt Iherome the fourth chappytre / Thou shalt kepe thre condy-
cions / Thou shalt swere in trouth / in dome and in rightwisnes

This is to say thou shalt swere soth / for euery lesyng is ayenst
crist / for Crist is very trouth / And thynke Wel thys that euery
grete swerer not compellyd laufully to sWere / the plaghe of ven-
geaunce shalle not parte from his hows whyles he vsyth suche vn-
lawful sWeryng /

Thow shalt eke swere in dome Whenne thou
art compellyd by thy domes man to wytnesse the trouthe /

Eke
thou shalt not sWere for enuye / for fauour / for mede but for right
wysnys for declaryng of trouth to the Worship of god ⁊ to hel -
pyng of thyn euen cristen /

⁊ therfore euery mān that takith goddes
name in ydle or falsly swerith with his mouth / or ellis taketh on
I iij
The Tale of the Parson
hym the name of crist to be callyd a cristen man and liueth ayenst
cristen lyuyng ⁊ his techyng / al they take goddis name in ydle

Loke eke what saith saynt peter actuum quarto / there is none o-
ther name vnder heuen yeuen to man in which they moot be sauyd
That is to say but in the name of Ihesu Crist /

Take kepe eke how
that precious name of Ihesu crist as saith seynt poul at philipenses
In nomine Ihesu ⁊ c̄etc / That in the name of Ihesu euery kne of he-
uenly creature or erthly or of helle sholde bowen / For it is so high
and so worshipful that the cursid fende in helle shold tremble for
to here it named /

Than semeth it that men that swere so horrybly
his blessyd name that they despyse it more boldly than dyd the
cursid Iewes that tremeleden whan they herde his name /

Now
certes sith that sweryng but it be doo al lawfully is so hooly de-
fended muche werse is for to swere falsely and eke nedeles /

what
saye we eke of them that deliten them in sweryng and holde it a
gentrye or manly dede to swere grete othis / and what of hem that
of very vsage necesse not to swere grete othes and al the cause not
worthe a strawe / Certes this is horryble synne /

Sweryng also
wythout auysement is eke synne /

But late vs goo now to that
cursid and horryble sWeryng of adiuracion ⁊ coniuracion as doon
thyse fals enchauntours ⁊ nygromancers in basyns ful of water
Or in a bryght swerd / In a cercle or in a fyre / or in a sholdre
boon of a sheep

I can not saye but they doo cursydly and damp-
nably ayenst Cryst and alle the feyth of holy chyrche /

What say
ye by them that byleuen in dym naylis as by flight or by noyse
of byrdys and of bestys or by sorte / by nygromancye / by dremes /
By chyrchyng of doris by gnawyng of rattis or crackyng of
housis ⁊ suche maner of wretchidnes /

certes al this thyng is defen
ded of god ⁊ eke holy chirche / for which they be cursid til they com
to amendement / that on suche filthe sette theyr beleue /

Charmys
for woundys ⁊ maladyes of men or of bestys / yf they take ony
effect / it / may be perauenture that god suffreth it / for men shold
gyue the more feyth and reuerence to his name /

Now wyl I
speke of lesynges whiche generally is fals signyficacion of word
with entent to disceyue his euen cristen /

Som lesyng there is of
whiche cometh none auaūntage to no wight / And som lesyng tor-
neth to the ese ⁊ prouffyt of a man and to domage of another
man /

Another lesyng for to saue his lyf or catel / Another lesyng
The Tale of the Parson
comyth of delyte / They Wyl forge a long tale and peynte it with
al circomstauncis wherof al the grounde is fals /

Somme lesyng
comyth for he wyl susteyne his worde / And somme lesyng cometh
of rechelisnes wythouten auysement and semblable thynges /

Lete vs noW towche the vyce of flaterye / whiche comyth not
gladly but for drede or for couetyse /

Flaterye is generally
wrongful preysyng / Flaterers ben the deuyllis norices that no-
rissheth his chyldren wyth the mylke ef losengerye /

For soth sayth
Salamon that flatery is worse than detraction / For somtyme
detraction makyth an haunteyn man be the more humble for he
dredeth detraction / But certeyn flaterye maketh a man to en-
haunce his herte and his countenaunce /

Flaterers ben the de-
uylles enchauntours for they maken a man to wenen hym self
be like / that he is not like /

They be like Iudas that betrayed
god / And thyse flaterers betraye a man to selle hym to his ene-
mye that is the deuyl /

Flaterers ben the dyuylles chappeleynes
that syngen euer placebo /

I rekene flaterye in vicis of Ire / For
ofte tyme yf a man be wroth Wyth another / Thenne Wyl he fla-
tere somme Wyght to susteyne hym in his quarelle /

Speke we
now of suche cursyng as comyth out of yrous hertes / Malyson
may be sayd generally euery maner power of harm / suche cursyng
bereueth a man the regne of god / As sayth saynt paule /

And
ofte suche cursyng wrongfully retourneth ayen to hym that cursyth
As a byrde retorneth agayn to hys owen neste /

And ouer alle
thyng men ought teschewe to curse her chyldren and to yeue to
the deuyl her engendrure as ferforth as in hem is / Certes it is
a grete peryl and a grete synne /

Lete vs thenne speke of chidyng
and repreuyng whiche ben grete Woundes in mannys herte /

For
certes vnnethe may a man be playnly accorded with hym that he
hath openly reuyled / reprouyd and disclaundred this is a ful
grisly synne / As Crist sayth in the gospel /

And take ye kepe
now that he that reprouyth his neyghbour by somme harme or by
somme peyn

that he hath in his body / as mesil / crokyd harlote /
or by somme signe that he doth / Now yf he repreuyth hym by harm
of peyne /

thenne retorneth the repref to Ihesu cryst / For peyne
is sent by the rightwys sonde of god and by his suffraunce /
be it meselrye or mayme or maladye /

And yf he repreue hym
vncharytably of synne / thou holour / thou dronkelewe harlot
I iiij
The Tale of the Parson
and so forth thenne apperteyneth it to reioysyng of the deuyl that
euer hath ioye that men doon synne /

And certes chydyng may
not come but of vyleynous herte / For after haboundaunce of the
herte speketh the mouth ful ofte /

And ye shul vnderstonde whan
ony man chastyseth another that he bewaar fro chydyng or repre -
uyng / For trewly but he be waar he may ful lightly quycken
the fyre of angre and of wrath whiche that he shal not quenche /
And perauenture sleeth hym that he myght chastyse wyth benyg -
nyte /

For as sayth Salamon / The amyable tongue is the tre
of lyf / that is to saye of lyf spirituel / And a dyslaue tongue
sleeth the spirites of hym that is reprouyd /

Lo what sayth saynt
Austyn / There is no thyng like the deuyllys chylde as he that
oft chydeth / Seynt Poule sayth eke / I seruannt of god behoue
not to chyde /

And how that chydyng is a vileyns thyng be-
twyxt alle maner folke / yet is hit certes most vncouenable
betwyx a man and his wyf / For there is neuer reste / And
therfore sayth Salamon / An hous that is vncouerd in rayn ⁊
droppyng and a chydyng wyf be like /

a man that is in a drop
pyng hous in many places / though he eschewe the droppyng in
one place / hit droppyth on hym in another place / So farith it
by a chydyng wyf but she chyde hym in one place she wyl chyde
hym in another place /

And therfore better is a morcel breed wyth
ioye / than an hous ful of delytes wyth chydyng / Lo what sa
lamon and

saynt Paule sayn / O ye wommen be ye subgettis to
your husbondys as behoueth in god / And ye men loue your
wyuys /

Afterward speke we of scornyng whiche is a wyc
ked synne and namely whan he scorneth a man by his good wer
kys /

For certes suche scorners faren lyke the foule tode that may
not endure to smelle the swete sauour of the vyne whan it flo-
risshyth /

Thyse scorners ben partyng felowes wyth the deuyl for
they haue ioye Whan the deuyl wynneth and sory whan he lesyth

They ben aduersaryes to Ihesu crist / For they haten that he loueth
that is to saye sauacion of soule /

Speke We now of wicked
counceyl / For he that wicked counceyl yeueth is a treytour /
For he dysceyueth hym that trusteth in hym / But netheles yet
is wicked counceyl first ayenst hym self /

For as sayth the
wyse man / Euery fals lyuyng hath his properte in hym self /
For he that wyl anoye another man anoyeth first hym self /

And
The Tale of the Parson
men shal vnderstonde that a man shal not take his counceyl of
false folke ne of angry folke or greuous folke ne of folke that
louen specially her owen prouffyt / ne to muche worldly folke ⁊
namely in counceyllyng of foolis /

Now comyth the synne of hem
that maken discorde among folk / whiche is a synne that Cryst
hateth vtterly / And no wonder is / for he deyed for to make
concorde /

And more shame don they to cryst than dyd they that
hym crucifyed / For god loueth better that frendshyp be among
folke than he dyde his owen body which he yaf for vnyte / Therfor
be they likenyd to the deuyl that euer is aboute to make dyscorde

Now comyth the synne of double tongue for suche as speke fayr
beforn men ⁊ wickedly behynde / or ellis they make semblaunt as
though they speken of good entenciou / or ellys in game and
pleye / And they speken of wicked entente /

Now comyth the
wreyyng of counceyl / thrugh whiche man is defamed / vnnethis
may he restore the domage /

Now comyth manace that is an open
folye / For he that openly menaceth he threteneth more thenne he
may ouercome ful oft tyme /

Now comen ydle wordys that he
wythout prouffyt of hym that speketh the wordes and eke of
hym that herknyth the wordes / Or ellys ydle wordes ben tho that
ben nedeles or wythoute entente of naturel prouffyt /

And al be
hit that ydle wordes be somtyme venyal synne yet shalle men
doubte hem / For we shal yeue rekenyng of hem byfore god /

Now comyth Iangelyng that may not come wyth out synne as
sayth Salamon / It is a signe of appert folye /

And therfore
a phylosophre sayde whan a man axed hym how men shold plese
And he answerid doo many good werkis and speke fewe Ian -
gelynges /

After this cometh the synne of Iapers that been the
deuyllys apys / For they make folke to laughe at her Iaperye
as folke doon at gawdes of an an ape / Suche Iapes defendeth saynt
Poule /

Loke how that vertuous wordes and holy comforten hem
that traueyllen in the seruyce of Cryst / Ryght so comforten the
vyleyns wordes and the knackys of Iapers hem that traueylen
in the seruyce of the deuyl /

Alle thyse ben the synnes of the tunge
that comyn of Ire ⁊ of other synnys /

The remedy ayenst Ire
is a vertu that cleped is mansuetude that is deboneyrte / and eke
another vertu that men clepen pacience /

Saynt Iherome sayth
thus of debonayrte that it doth harme to no wyght ne sayth none
The Tale Of the Parson
harm that men hym doo ne sayn ne chaungeth not ayenst reson /

This vertu cometh somtyme of nature / For as sayth the philoso-
pher a man is a quyk thyng by nature debonayr and tretable by
goodnes / But whan debonayrte is enformed of grace it is the
more worthy /

Pacience is another remedye ayenst yre and is a
vertu that men suffre swetely euery mannes goodnes / and is not
wroth for none harme that is doon to hym /

The philosopher saith
that pacience is that vertu that suffreth debonayrly al the outrage
of aduersite / and euery wicked worde /

This vertu maketh a
man like to god and maketh hym his owen dere chylde / as saith
crist thys vertu discomfiteth thyn enemye / And therfore sayth the
Wise man yf thou wolt veynquysshe thyn enemye

see that thou be
paciente / Suffraunce is another vertu ayenst Ire / And that is
whan he suffreth swetely alle anoyaunce and the wrongys that
men doo a man outward /

Thou shalt vnderstonde that a man
suffreth four maner of greuauncis in outward thyngys / Ayenst
whiche foure he must haue foure maner of pacience /

The first
greuaunce is wicked wordes / that greuaunce suffryd Ihesu Crist
wythout grutchyng wel paciently Whan the Iewes despised hym
and reprouyd hym ful ofte /

Suffre thou therfore paciently /
for the wyse man saith yf thou stryue wyth a fool / yf the fool be
wroth or though he laughe / Algate thou shalt haue no reste /

That other greuaunce outward is to haue domage of thy catel /
There ayenst suffryd crist ful paciently whan he despoyled was
of al that euer he had in thys lyf and that nas but clothys /

The thyrd greuaunce is to a man to haue greuaunce in his body
That suffred crist ful paciently in all his passyon /

The fourth gre
uaunce is in outrageous labour in werkys / wherfore I say that
folke that maken her seruauntes to traueylle to greuously out of
tyme as in holy dayes / Sothly they doo grete synne /

here ayenst
suffred Crist ful paciently and taught vs pacience whan he bare
vpon his blessyd sholdres the crosse vpon whiche he shold suffre
despytous deth /

here may men lerne to be pacient / For certes not
only cristen men be pacient for the loue of Ihesu crist ⁊ for guerdon
of the blisse of heuen and of the blessyd lyf that is perdurable /
But certes the olde paynems that neuer were cristenyd comen -
dyd and vsyd the vertu of pacience /

A phylosophre vpon a tyme
that wolde haue beten his disciple for his grete trespaas / For
The Tale of the Parson
whiche he was gretely ameuyd and brought a yerde to scourge
the chyld /

And whan the chylde sawe the yerde he sayd to hys
mayster / what wyl ye to doo / I wyl bete the quod the mayster
for thy corection /

For soth quod the chylde ye ought first correcte
your self that hath lost your pacience for the gylt of a chylde /

For sothe sayd the mayster al wepyng thou seyst soth haue thou
the yerde my dere sone and correct me for myn vnpacience /

Of
pacience comyth obedyence thrugh whyche a man is obedyent to
Crist and to alle hem to whiche he ought to be obedyent in cryst /

And vnderstonde wel that obedyence is parfight whan men doo
gladly and hastely wyth good herte entierly al that he shold do

Obedyence generally is to perfourme the doctryne of god and to
his souerayns to whiche hym ought to be obeyssaunt in alle
ryghtwysnes /
Sequitur de Accidia /

AFter the synne of wrath I wyl speke of the synne of
accidye or slouth / For enuye blyndeth the herte of man
and Ire troubleth a man / And accidye maketh hym
heuy thoughtful and wrawe /

Enuye and Ire maken
bitternes in herte / whiche bytternes is moder of accidye and be-
nymeth hym the loue of alle goodnes / thenne is accidye the angre
of a troble herte / And saynt Austyn sayth

It is anoye of good
nes and annoye of harme /

Certes thys is a dampnable synne /
For it doth Wrong to Ihesu crist in as muche as he benymeth the
seruyce that men ought to doo to Ihesu crist wyth al dylygence /
As sayth Salamon /

But accidye doth none suche dylygence /
He doth alle wyth annoye and wrawnes Slaknes / excusacion
dulnesse and vnlust / For whiche the book sayth acursid be he
that doth the seruyse of god neclygently /

thenne is accidye ene-
mye to euery estate of man / For the estate of man is in thre ma
ners / Eyther it is estate

of Innocence as was the state of Adam
before or that he fyl in to synne in whyche estate he was holde to
worche as in heeryng and adouryng of god /

Another estate is
estate of superfluyte / In whiche estate men be holden to laboure
in prayeng to god for amendement of her synnes /

Another
The Tale of the Parson
estate is in the estate of grace / In whiche estate is he holden to
doo werkys of penytence / And certes to alle thise thynges is
accidye enemye and contrary for he loueth no besynes at alle /

Now certes this foule synne of accidye is eke a ful grete enemye
to the lyuelod of the body / For it hath no purueaunce ayenst
temporel necessyte / For it is slouthyd and forsloggyd and
destroyeth alle goodes temporel by rechelesnes /

the fourth thyng
is that accidye is like hem that ben in the peyn of helle by cause of
slouth and of her heuynes / For they that be dampned be so bounde
that neyther may they doo wel ne thynke wel /

Of accidye cometh
first that a man is anoyed and encombryd to doo ony goodnes
and maketh that god hath abhomynacion of suche accidye as
sayth saynt Iohn /

Now comyth slouth that wyl suffre no hard-
nes ne no penaunce / For soth slouth is so delycate and so tendre
as sayth Salamon that he wyl suffre non hardnes ne penaunce ⁊
therfore he shendeth al that he doth /

Ayenst thys roten horyd synne
of accidye or slouthe shold men excercyse hem to doo good werkis
and manly and vertuously catchen corage wel to doo / Thynkyng
that our lord Ihesu cryst quyteth euery good dede be it neuer so
lityl

vsage of it is a grete thyng / For it maketh as sayth saynt
Bernard the laborer to haue strong armys and hard synewys
And slouth maketh hem feble and tendre /

Than comyth drede
for to begynne to werke ony good werkys / For certes he that
is enclyned to synne hym thynketh it is to grete an empryse for
to vndertake to doo werkys of goodnes
as sayth saynt gregore /

Now comyth wanhope that is dyspayr of the mercy of god that
comyth somtyme of to mykyl outrageous sorow and somtyme of
mykyl drede ymagynyng that he hath doo so muche that it wolde
not auaylle hym though he wolde repente hym and doo good /

thrugh whiche dyspayr or drede / He aboundeth his herte to euery
maner synne As sayth saynt Austyn /

whiche that is dampnable
yf it contynue to hys ende / hit is cleped synnyng in the holy
ghoost /

This horryble synne is so perylous that he that is dispey
red that there is no felonye ne no synne that he doubteth for to do
as shewed wel by Iudas /

Certes thenne abouen alle is thys
synne most dyspleysaunt and most aduersary to Cryst /

Certes he
that dyspeyreth is lyke the coward champyon recreaunt and ne
deles dyspeyreth /

For certes the mercy of god is euer redy to
The Tale of the Parson
the penytent / hit is aboue al his werkys /

Alas can not a man
bethynke hym on the gospel of Saynt luke / Luce xv / where as
crist saith that as wel shalle there be more Ioye in heuen vpon a
synful man that doth penytence than vpon nyenty and ix right-
ful men that neden no penytence /

loke ferther in the gospel the
ioye and the festys of the good man that had lost his sone / whan
his sone wyth repentaunce was retorned to his fader /

Can they
not remembre eke as sayth saynt luke xxiij / How that the theef
that was honged besyde Ihesu / Sayde lord remembre on me
whan thou comest to thy regne /

forsoth sayd crist / this day shalt
thou be wyth me in paradys /

Certes there is none so horryble
synne of man that it ne may in his lyf be destroyed by penytence
thrugh vertu of the passyon of crist /

Alas what nedeth man thēmne
to be dispeyred sithen his mercy is so redy / aske and haue /

Thenne cometh sompnolence that is sluggy slumbryng whyche
makyth a man to be heuy and dul in body and in sowle / And
this synne cometh of slouth /

And certes the tyme as by weye of
reson men shold not slepe that is by the morow but yf it were
cause resonable /

For soth in the morowe is most couenable a man
to saye his preyers and for to thynke on god and to honoure
